Graphical abstract The graphical abstract illustrates the integration of MS-SOFCs into a hybrid electric vehicle, where bioethanol is reformed into hydrogen and carbon monoxide for onboard electricity generation by MS-SOFCs. Metal-Supported Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (MS-SOFCs) hold significant potential for driving the energy transition. These electrochemical devices represent the most advanced generation of Solid Oxide Fuel Cell (SOFCs) and can pave the way for mass production and wider adoption than Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells (PEMFCs) due to their fuel flexibility, higher power density and the absence of noble metals in the fabrication processes. This review examines the state-of-the-art of SOFCs and MS-SOFCs, presenting perspectives and research directions for these key technological devices, highlighting novel materials, techniques, architectures, devices, and degradation mechanisms to address current challenges and future opportunities. Techniques such as infiltration/impregnation, ex-solution catalyst synthesis, and the use of a pre-catalytic reformer layer are discussed as their impact on efficiency and prolonged activity. These concepts are also described and connected with well-dispersed nanoparticles, hindrance of coarsening, and an increased number of Triple Phase Boundaries (TPBs). This review also describes the synergistic use of reformers with MS-SOFCs to compose solutions in energy generation from readily available fuels. Lastly, the End-of-Life (EoL), recycling, and life-cycle assessments (LCAs) of the Fuel Cell Hybrid Electric Vehicles (FCHEVs) were discussed. LCAs comparing Fuel Cell Electric Vehicles (FCEVs) equipped with (PEMFCs) and FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFCs, both powered with hydrogen (H2) generated by different routes were compared. This review aims to provide valuable insights into these key technological devices, emphasizing the importance of robust research and development to enhance performance and lifespan while reducing costs and environmental impact. Keywords Reform Metal-supported solid oxide fuel cell Powertrain systems Fuel cell Hybrid electric vehicle Biofuel 1 Introduction 1.1 Motivation The global push towards decarbonizing transportation is well underway, mainly motivated by the urgent imperatives outlined in the Paris Agreement, a pivotal and legally binding international treaty on climate change. Conceived at the UN Climate Change Conference (COP21) in Paris, France, on December 12, 2015, the agreement garnered support from 196 parties. Taken effect on November 4, 2016, it sets targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions (GGEs) by 45% by 2030 and achieving net-zero emissions close to 2050. The overall mission of the Paris Agreement is to suppress the escalation of the global average temperature below 1.5 °C above pre-industrial levels [1,2]. The electrification of the economy is one of the most powerful tools available to reduce GGEs, as it aims to combine renewable energy generation with the high efficiency and scalability of electric engines (EEs). However, it is imperative to recognize that the power source for these EEs should not be confined solely to conventional batteries. Furthermore, the worldwide electric grids responsible for recharging these batteries remain far from renewable energy sources. In many developing or even fully industrialized countries, the exclusive incorporation of battery-electric vehicles (BEVs) could overcharge the existing power grids, requiring substantial infrastructure loans reaching hundreds of billions of dollars to accommodate the increased load [3]. In this sense, technologies that utilize H2 have shown great potential for decarbonization. One such technology is the SOFC, a high-temperature fuel cells (FCs) operating in the range of 600–1000 °C, which can be integrated with other high-temperature technologies, such as reforming systems. The operating principle of SOFCs is similar to that of H2-fueled PEMFCs. The fuel arriving at the anode undergoes oxidation, releasing electrons, which then combine with oxygen ions (O2−) that have been reduced at the cathode and conducted through the electrolyte via oxygen vacancies [4]. In this process, oxygen anions (O2−) combine with hydrogen cations (H+), forming water (H2O), releasing electrons, and generating heat. SOFCs offer fuel flexibility, capable of operating with various biofuels such as biomethane (CH4), bioethanol (C2H5OH), or any hydrocarbon, converting the chemical energy stored in covalent bonds directly into electrical energy. The use of renewable fuels for energy production in SOFCs has made a wide range of possibilities conceivable in recent years [5–9]. However, conventional SOFCs face challenges related to material stability and mechanical robustness, especially during thermal cycling, due to the use of brittle ceramic components. To address these issues, MS-SOFCs have emerged as a more durable alternative [10]. MS-SOFCs replace the ceramic support structure with metal support, enhancing mechanical strength, thermal shock resistance, and reducing manufacturing costs. The metal support also facilitates faster start-up times and better scalability, making MS-SOFCs more suitable for a wide range of applications, including portable and large-scale power systems [11,12]. Exploring an innovative electrification concept through hydrocarbon and biofuels onboard reforming into syngas composed of H2 and carbon monoxide (CO) in the majority to be used in MS-SOFCs to generate electricity in a novel hybrid powertrain system for vehicle propulsion could be the path to a faster energy transition. This also can be achieved through internal reforming processes of these fuels directly in the MS-SOFCs anodes [13]. These FCs exhibit high performance, rapid start-up, and light-off characteristics, facilitated by the ceramic thin films deposition on cost-effective stainless steel porous supports, utilizing scalable techniques with lower capital expenditure (CAPEX) [14,15]. Over the last decade, these lines of sight have saved substantial interest and investments from governments along automakers of internal combustion engine vehicles (ICEVs), BEVs, and pure FCEVs as well as power generation companies in Brazil and worldwide, promoting research and development [16,17]. However, the hydrocarbon and biofuel utilization, including C2H5OH and CH4, poses a challenge in the long-term stability of the external reformer or the MS-SOFCs anodes due to coking on the catalysts surface [18]. This challenge still requires efforts from the literature and companies to devise innovative solutions that preserve MS-SOFCs high performance and lifespan over 100,000 h. Therefore, this review provides strong and critical points offering a valuable overview of the technologies involved in electrical energy onboard generation by MS-SOFCs powered by hydrocarbon and biofuels. We provide a comprehensive overview of the current state-of-the-art materials used in MS-SOFC stacks and reformers, considering key aspects such as performance, lifespan, and LCA from the cradle to the grave. This innovative eyesight demonstrates Brazil’s commitment to sustainable and efficient transportation solutions, aligning with global efforts to reduce emissions and transition towards cleaner energy sources. But the main challenge is still the FCs. 1.2 Fuel cells Among all alternative combustion technologies, FCs can use H2, CO, hydrocarbon or biofuels for power generation in the range of 100–1000 °C with high efficiency with zero or lower carbon and other pollutant emissions [19]. Several FCs are at different technology readiness levels (TRLs), including commercial products from Ballard, Bosch, Ceres Power, Nissan, Panasonic, SOFCMAN, Plug Power, Toshiba, Fuel Cell Materials, and Elcogen, among others. The FCs are classified in agreement with the electrolyte used and the operating temperature (Top .). The main FCs are: (i) Proton Exchange Membrane FC (PEMFC); (ii) Alkaline FC (AFC); (iii) Phosphoric Acid FC (PAFC); (iv) Molten Carbonate FC (MCFC), and (v) Solid Oxide FC (SOFC) [20]. Table S1 of Supplementary Information (SI) depicts a brief FC features overview. PEMFC stacks are widely used in FCEVs powered by H2, but they cannot tolerate contaminants such as CO traces and hydrogen sulfide gas (H2S), making the H2 high-purity cryo-liquefaction process very expensive. The skyrocketing costs of H2 cryo-liquefaction and high-pressure storage tanks, besides the safe transport and logistic distribution, turn the FCEVs into a business model with high CAPEX and OPEX. This barrier has held the PEMFC vehicle widespread for more than 20 years now, as the first manufactured PEMFC vehicle, the Honda FCX, dates from 2002. Furthermore, FCEVs equipped with H2-powered PEMFC stacks show low dynamic response due to H2O flooding at the interface in the range of the electrodes and gas diffusion layers. Hence, they are unable to manage power peaks under start-up, and acceleration cannot extract regenerative energy from the EE during deceleration or braking [21]. This issue can be solved by combining a small lithium-ion or sodium-ion battery (LIB or SIB) pack with a PEMFC stack. These fuel cell hybrid electric vehicles (FCHEVs) powertrain systems show strong synergy due to the electrical power integrated supply. This achievement is due to the following aspects: (i) the battery packs which power aid under start-up and acceleration; (ii) the EE deceleration and braking energy re-absorption that also reduces the PEMFC stack power fluctuation [22]. The PEMFC stack is connected in series with the battery pack to indirectly supply electrical power to the EE. However, this system has higher synergy when the PEMFC stack is connected directly to the EE and in parallel with the battery pack. In this configuration, the PEMFC stack is the main source of electrical power to the EE and the battery pack becomes an auxiliary one. Because of this, the battery pack volume can be reduced down to one-fifth in FCHEVs, which means less cost and reduced carbon footprint through battery LCA. SOFC stacks are technologically and strategically more important than PEMFC stacks due to these three main advantages: (i) economic, because the use of nickel (Ni) based catalysts for hydrocarbon or biofuels internal reforming at the anode instead of platinum (Pt) used in the PEMFCs electrodes. Ni can also be used in an external reformer to convert these fuels into syngas before these molecules reach the SOFC anode [23]; (ii) MS-SOFC stacks can operate with fuels carrying H2S low levels as low as 50 parts per billion (ppb); (iii) CO is also a fuel, as well as H2, reacting with O2− at the anode to produce carbon dioxide (CO2) and H2O as by-products without any issue with CO poisoning [24,25]. Another SOFCs advantage is the chemical energy conversion directly into electrical up to η = 0.60 of efficiency, while PEMFCs and ICEVs (limited by the Carnot cycle) shows η = 0.50 and η = 0.35 of efficiency [26,27]. The SOFCs thermodynamic principle is similar to any other FCs because the faradaic electrochemical reactions occur at the electrode/electrolyte interfaces called TPBs. In the anode TPBs occurs the electrochemical reactions in the range of the fuel, such as H2, and O2− anions from molecular O2 present in the air, previously reduced at the composite cathode TPBs, producing besides H2O vapor, electricity, and heat [28]. The MS-SOFCs enable the use of C2H5OH and CH4 in FCHEVs displaying overall electrical efficiency between 0.45 < η < 0.60. In stationary applications using CH4, the electrical efficiency has been reported as high as η = 0.60, and if a micro-turbine is attached to harness the regenerative heat energy from the heat H2O vapor, the overall thermal efficiency could reach an impressive 100% [29]. In terms of Research and Development (R&D), SOFCs have demonstrated volumetric power densities ranging from 0.1 to 1.0 kW·L−1 [30,31], whereas MS-SOFCs have shown superior values in the range of 1.0–5.6 kW·L−1 [32,33]. The PEMFCs have shown values in the range of 1.65–3.12 kW·L−1 [34], losing to MS-SOFCs. Commercially, there are consolidated products in this area, for instance, the company Ceres Power (England) produces MS-SOFC stacks with 10 kg and 1.2 kW when powered by CH4 for stationary power generation, which roughly gives a specific power of 0.12 kW·kg−1 [35]. Nevertheless, for a light-duty vehicle, less than half of this power is needed, i.e., stacks with 200 < Weight (kg) < 400 provide 24 < P (kW) < 48, assuming that the same design and architecture of MS-SOFCs for stationary applications could be used directly without any appropriate changes. Similar products employing high-temperature solid oxide fuel cells (HT-SOFCs, 1st generation) and intermediate-temperature solid oxide fuel cells (IT-SOFCs, 2nd generation) depict a specific power range of 1 < kW·kg−1 < 3 [36]. For instance, the literature has been reporting a specific power range of 1.8 < kW·kg−1 < 2.2 for PEMFC used in light-duty vehicles [37,38]. We could argue that even the most advanced SOFC, in this case the MS-SOFC, is still far from being able to enter into mobility applications. Despite that, the commonly reported power density ranges of SOFC and MS-SOFC are 0.5 < W·cm−2 < 5 and 0.5 < W·cm−2 < 3, respectively, which shows that MS-SOFC has approximately the triple of the 0.5 < W·cm−2 < 1 power density range of the PEMFC, considering cells with similar thickness [39]. Therefore, we can realize the importance of cell architecture and stack design for the final specific power density and the constraints imposed by the different applications. Stacks that have been designed for small stationary applications will not meet the demands for mobility even if the internal cells could. These MS-SOFC stacks must be improved in size and weight to be useful in vehicle powertrain systems and adapted to be powered by hydrocarbons and biofuels. In Fig. 1 a, on a volumetric power density scale, energy technologies such as batteries, PEMFC, SOFC, and MS-SOFC easily outperform fuel cells [30,32–36,40]. However, on a gravimetric power density scale, we observe that fuel cells have superiority in terms of energy density compared to batteries, and MS-SOFCs can surpass all other technologies. 1.3 Biofuels as H2 carrier Biofuels can be considered “H2 in liquid phase” because these molecules store the element hydrogen (H). For example, Fig. 1b depicts that H2 and C2H5OH have ∼0.01 MJ·L−1 and ∼18.4 MJ·L−1 of stored energy into their chemical bonds under standard temperature and pressure conditions (STP), proving the higher C2H5OH energy density. In an external reformer, C2H5OH can be converted into H2 and CO to power MS-SOFCs, boosting the stack energy efficiency and lifespan. The bioethanol produced from sugarcane is a renewable and clean fuel source since the CO2 from the atmosphere is captured through photosynthesis by this plant life cycle, leading CO2 emission net near to zero, being practically null if its biomass is used in the FCHEVs supply chain as a circular economy [42,43]. Using standardized LCA methods, the bioethanol produced in the USA by a new fermentation process from corn stover, forest residue, or switchgrass gasification results in GGEs that are at least 60% lower than that of conventional fossil fuels such as gasoline, with biomass-based bioethanol achieving close to 90% of emission reductions [44]. One ton of corn produces in the range of 390 and 410 L of bioethanol, while a ton of sugarcane produces in the range of 70 and 90 L. Nonetheless, corn yields 6 tons per hectare, and sugarcane averages 80 tons per hectare, but can reach 381 tons per hectare with genetically designed species [45]. Brazil utilizes only 0.5% of its landfill for bioethanol production, which does not compete with food production or contribute to deforestation. This bioethanol production is currently able to fulfill more than all flex fuel cars in Brazil (∼30% of the national fleet). Moreover, the bioethanol generation and logistic distribution infrastructures are much cheaper and safer compared to H2 hubs for FCEVs and battery recharging grids for BEVs. These infrastructures are already consolidated in Brazil and other countries such as the USA, Thailand, India, and some African countries [46,47]. Besides bioethanol, biogas is another prominent biofuel which is gaining attention to energy transition. In 2020, the biogas worldwide production amounted to 1.46 EJ in terms of energy content, representing a substantial increase from the 0.29 EJ produced in the year 2000 [48]. Biogas is derived from anaerobic digestion of decomposing organic matter in biodigesters. This matter can originate from various sources, including urban and industrial sludge like sewage treatment plants, food waste, or landfills, as well as agricultural residues such as vinasse. This gas is composed of CH4 and CO2 with several trace components, including H2O vapor, nitrogen (N2), O2, CO, H2S, ammonia (NH3), siloxanes, and lightweight hydrocarbons. The biogas refining into biomethane involves purification to eliminate the trace components and an upgrade to align the calorific value. Therefore, biomethane is a clean source for H2 production as bioethanol. Biogas plants and SOFC stacks integrated, in conjunction with agricultural and biomass waste treatment plants, offer a substantial prospect in the stationary and decentralized power generation market, operating in the range of 10–103 kW. These integrated systems are highly efficient. Theexothermic power generation can supply heat and steam energy to reforming or other industrial through the exhaust gas stream from the SOFC stacks. The primary challenge for this system is ensuring the purity of the fuel gases used to feed the SOFC stacks. However, there are already technologies with high TRLs for refining and reforming biogas into syngas with ppb of sulfur, siloxanes, and halogens [49]. Bioethanol and biomethane as H2 carriers can be the solution for mobility electrification using MS-SOFCs in countries that produce these biofuels and already have the production and distribution logistic infrastructure. This outcome allows the mobility sector to gradually decarbonize without huge investments in infrastructure to recharge the BEVs or refueling H2 hubs for FCEVs. 1.4 Why do MS-SOFCs make sense? The MS-SOFC stacks can be powered by H2 and CO reformed onboarding from biofuels and extend the timeframe for clean electricity generation and smart grid distribution to charge the battery pack of the BEVs, estimated only in Brazil in 210 < USD billion < 300 [50]. This hybrid powertrain system could be comprised of: (i) one tank for liquid bioethanol or gas biomethane refueling of ∼30 L or ∼10 m3, respectively, smaller than the ∼50 L of gasoline or ∼20 m3 of compressed natural gas (CNG) of current ICEVs; (ii) an onboard external reformer to convert these biofuels in H2 and CO to be used in an MS-SOFC stack; (iii) a smaller battery pack for electrical energy storage produced by the MS-SOFC stack; (iv) a supercapacitors (SCs) bank in cases of higher energy demand as overdrives providing quickly electrical power to the EE and fast regenerative energy re-absorption from the EE when it is in deceleration or braking mode; (v) a power and energy controller management unity in the range of the MS-SOFC stack, battery pack, SCs bank, and the EE to get the best working condition [15]. The main advantages of FCHEVs comprising hybrid powertrain system with MS-SOFCs stack are the: (i) refueling tank could be fueled by these biofuels between 3 < t (min) < 5 as the same way the flex power ICEVs are refueled in Brazil; (ii) autonomy depends on the external reformer and MS-SOFC stack overall efficiencies; (iii) smaller batteries pack volume considerably reduces the system weight and cost; (iv) toxic and flammable substances present in the battery cells will be much lower; (v) reduction of critical metals such Ni, lithium (Li), cobalt (Co), aluminum (Al), copper (Cu), silicon (Si), zinc (Zn), manganese (Mn), and carbon materials present in the battery cells and (vi) the MS-SOFC high electrical overall efficiency compared to the HT-SOFC, IT-SOFC and PEMFC, with much more room to scale-up at lower costs [51–54]. However, since FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFC stacks are still under development, the main drawbacks are the: (i) MS-SOFC performance and lifespan depends on the porous metal supports (PMSs) and dense metal interconnectors (ICs) oxidation resistance which usually are made in ferritic stainless steel (FSS: Fe26Cr) and austenitic stainless steel (ASS: Fe18Cr12Ni) stainless steels; (ii) cathode degradation when steam reacts with the Cr (Cr) from the cathode IC alloy, precipitating CrO(OH)x; (iii) cathode/electrolyte degradation during the sinterization in the range of 900–1300 °C or at operation in the range of 650–750 °C; (iv) iron (Fe) and Cr evaporation and deposition on the anode Ni catalyst surface, promoting FeNiOx and CrNiOx electronic charge carrier blocking phases; (v) Ni diffusion into the FSS PMS emerge higher oxidation resistance austenitic phases but with a higher coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) which causes cracks nucleation and anode delamination from the PMS; (vi) pyrolytic coking in graphitic, fibers or nanotubes phases on the anode Ni catalyst surface deactivating and dusting it if hydrocarbon or biofuels is internally reformed; (vii) stack is still too heavyweight and large as HT-SOFCs and IT-SOFCs which are commonly used for stationary power generation, so downsizing is mandatory; and (viii) the testing standards, LCAs, recycling legislations and public policies are lacking for MS-SOFC stacks powered by biofuels, which reduces its bankability [55–57]. In contrast to HT-SOFCs and IT-SOFCs, the MS-SOFCs present fast start-up and light-off of 10 min [40], because of the following features: (i) the Top. of 700 °C is lower and (ii) they present excellent thermal shock resistance due to the thin ceramic films deposition on the PMS that promotes the components thermal integration ensuring high redox cyclabilities without device cracks and mechanical failures [58,59]. Although several papers present the state-of-the-art improvements in IT-SOFCs powered by C2H5OH and CH4 for low-temperature applications as low-temperature solid oxide fuel cells (LT-SOFCs) [46,60], there are few papers on MS-SOFCs powered by hydrocarbons, biofuels or syngas [17,61]. However, in 2016, Nissan introduced a new technology demonstrating that these FCHEVs with MS-SOFCs can be developed and improved. 1.5 Case study In 2016, Nissan in collaboration with AVL GmbH List (Germany), Plansee SE (Austria), and Ceres Power (spin-off from Imperial College London), presented on Brazilian highways the first FCHEV called Nissan e-bio (1,716 kg). This vehicle was adapted and equipped with an MS-SOFC stack that shows η = 0.55 of efficiency and 600 km of drive range. The fuel was a 1:1 vol% mix of water and ethanol (15 L each) reaching 40 km·L−1 of ethanol consumption. For comparison, a commercial BEV reaches 400–600 km with a single recharge between 1 < t (h) < 8, and an ICEV flex-fuel typically reaches 10 km·L−1 with 90 vol% of ethanol [62]. This 425 kg hybrid powertrain system includes: (i) a 30 L refueling tank of liquid hydrated bioethanol, which is converted by an (ii) onboard external reformer into syngas to power an (iii) 5 kW MS-SOFC planar stack (150 Wh·kg−1 and 50 kg) and charge an (iv) 24 kWh LIB pack; (v) a heat-exchanger; (vi) a start-burner; (vii) an air-blower; (viii) a gas-processer unit; (ix) an after-burner that uses the exhaust heat generated by the MS-SOFC stack to warm up the unreacted syngas and recirculated it to improve the overall system efficiency. This vehicle achieved high performance due to the synergy between the LIB pack of Nissan’s range extender (REX2) and the MS-SOFC stack by Ceres Power and AVL company [15,62]. The LIB pack is important to suppress the power fluctuation from the MS-SOFCs stack ensuring fast start-ups. The Nissan’s e-bio FCHEV is equipped with a LIB pack with 192 Li-ion cells that show 32.5 A·h and 3.75 V per cell. Each Li-ion cell comprises a LiMn2O4-LiNiO2 composite active cathode and Cgraphite active anode. The Nissan e-bio EE is an AC synchronous that shows 80 kW and 280 N·m of torque [14]. 1.6 MS-SOFCs limitations Despite the previously mentioned advantages, this novel hybrid powertrain system with MS-SOFC stack does not yet present an adequate lifespan compared to ICEV systems. The MS-SOFC stack lifespan is compromised by the PMS and ICs oxidation, electrodes, and electrolyte degradation, and mainly anode coking when MS-SOFC are directly powered by hydrocarbon or biofuels. The MS-SOFCs stack cost of 200 < USD·kW−1 < 400 is still a limiting factor when compared to the 140 < USD·kW−1 < 250 of the LIBs and the 35 < USD·kW−1 < 55 of the ICEVs powertrain system cost. However, MS-SOFCs stacks large-scale up production is the trigger to reduce this cost, improving market competitiveness [63–65]. More details about this analysis are made in a dedicated section in the present review. The 8 mol% Y2O3 stabilized ZrO2 (8YSZ) electrolyte, and 10 mol% Gd2O3 doped CeO2 (10GDC) diffusion barrier layer (DBL) deposition by physical vapor deposition (PVD), and the high sintering temperature (Tsint. ) to obtaining these phases in electrodes manufactured by tape casting, spray pyrolysis, airbrushing or screen-printing scalable techniques are factors that challenge the MS-SOFCs cost reduction. CoO, Fe2O3, and ZnO used as sintering additives can decrease the Tsint . of the electrodes. However, these additives reduce the 8YSZ and 10GDC ionic conductivities ( σ ion . ) decreasing the cell performance [66–69]. The main issue is the Ni/8YSZ and Ni/10GDC-based anode deactivations due to the coking when carbon-based fuels are used, reducing the MS-SOFC stack performance and lifespan. Hydrocarbon or biofuel hydration reduces the anode coking and improves the σ ion . of these devices [70]. High Top. can reduce the polarization losses and increase the kinetic rate of the electrochemical reactions in the electrodes TPBs, but thermal stresses, components delamination, and electrode coarsening arise. Thinner ceramic films onto PMSs besides the DBLs in the cell components interfaces, which avoid blocking phase precipitation, can reduce the Top ., extending the MS-SOFCs lifespan [71,72]. 1.7 What is the point of this review? The main point of this review is to organize the main scientific works on SOFCs and MS-SOFCs powered by syngas externally reformed from hydrocarbons and biofuels. Additionally, it investigates the internal reforming of these fuels directly at the anode of SOFCs and MS-SOFCs. It is worth noting that public policies and technical standards for testing, manufacturing, and recycling the MS-SOFCs are still in the developmental phase and will not be discussed here. Only a brief introduction and comparison of the LCA will be covered and correlated with this new type of FCHEV. This review is structured into the following sections: (i) section II outlines the adopted methodology for the systematic review; (ii) section III is an overview of the key features of SOFCs and MS-SOFCs, along with an analysis of their advantages and disadvantages when powered by H2, hydrocarbon and biofuels; (iii) section IV focuses on the challenges associated with MS-SOFCs and explores strategies for optimizing this device when it is powered by hydrocarbon and biofuels; (iv) section V offers an overview in LCA from the cradle-to-the-grave; and finally the (vi) section VI presents the main conclusions. 2 Methodology This review is conducted in agreement with a protocol comprising three steps. The steps undertaken consist of: (i) studies identification and contextualization regarding global warming mitigation in the mobility sector; (ii) the identification of the most pertinent studies to comply with carbon neutrality through MS-SOFCs, and (iii) the extraction data and referencing. Databases include Elsevier–Science Direct, Nature, Springer Link, Oxford Press Journal, Royal Society of Chemistry, and the Web of Science platform. The sourced references’ reliability is upheld through rigorous peer review processes involving experts in the fields of materials science and engineering, electrochemistry, renewable energy generation and storage, and sustainability. Executing queries within the database search space was accomplished by combining and linking specific AND and OR operators to execute the following queries: (a) SOFCs and MS-SOFCs powered by H2, hydrocarbons, and biofuels; (b) state-of-the-art of biofuel reformer, SOFCs and MS-SOFCs technologies; (c) LCAs for SOFCs and MS-SOFCs. An overview of the research field can be obtained by examining the number of annual publications from the last 25 years for each of the keywords used as search criteria in this systematic review. Fig. 2 depicts the number of publications per year for each search sequence utilized in the mentioned databases. Fig. 2(a, b) show the number of publications related to the keywords SOFCs and MS-SOFCs, respectively. A significant increase in SOFC publications has been observed over the past 15 years, while for MS-SOFCs, the number remained constant. This can be attributed to the challenges in obtaining MS-SOFCs. During the same period, Fig. 2 (c–f) illustrate an increase in publications focused on SOFCs powered by C2H5OH and CH4. In contrast, there were few publications on MS-SOFCs fueled by biofuels, indicating that there is still much to explore in this area. When biofuels are linked to reforming processes, a substantial rise in the number of publications can be seen in Fig. 2(g) and (i). This suggests that research is advancing towards the development of better catalysts for biofuel reforming and, consequently, for internal reforming in SOFCs and MS-SOFCs. The technological advancements in external reforming devices could facilitate their integration with MS-SOFCs in the powertrain systems of hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs), and this field remains underexplored, as shown in Fig. 2(h) and (j), where the number of publications is still relatively low, indicating significant potential for further research. Based on the observed data, it is possible to conclude that research on SOFCs and MS-SOFCs has grown significantly in recent years. The quality of the published work should be intrinsically linked to this amount, highlighting how promising this research field is. Fig. 3 presents a graphical representation illustrating the distribution of references analyzed in this review, based on impact factors (IF) and citescore (CS). The publications cited in this review include nearly 8% of journal articles with an impact factor higher than 15. Additionally, almost 10% of SOFC and MS-SOFC publications have an IF above 25, demonstrating the high impact of this research area. The largest portion of the publications fall within the 5 to 15 IF range, accounting for approximately 48.5%. Therefore, we can conclude that publications in the SOFC and MS-SOFC fields are promising and have the potential for high relevance and impact in literature. The publications cited in this review include 17.38% and 42.09% of papers from journals with impact factor and citescore higher than 15. 3 SOFCs powered by H2, hydrocarbon, and biofuels: Features, benefits, and drawbacks 3.1 Chemical composition, crystal structure, punctual defects, and electrical conductivity To recognize the MS-SOFC features, it is essential to understand the evolution from SOFCs to MS-SOFCs. The success of these devices results from: (i) the deposition of composite cermet anodes, ceramic electrolytes and cathodes, and DBLs films on PMSs; and (ii) the use of metallic ICs and (iii) the sealing between ICs and PMS by micro-welding laser. These characteristics provide cost reduction and performance improvement for applications in a lower Top . ranging from 550 to 750 °C. The SOFC electrolyte is a dense and semipermeable membrane of O2− anions. These anions are transported by the ceramic crystalline structure by oxygen vacancies ( V O ∙ ∙ ) defects. The mechanism for O2− and vacancy migration is thermally activated; therefore the electrolyte material determines the Top .. The state-of-the-art widely adopted is the Zr0.84Y0.16O1.92 ceramic, commonly referred as 8YSZ (8 mol% yttria-stabilized zirconia). This electrolyte is inexpensive and only has σ ion . over all the Top . range. Moreover, 8YSZ exhibits CTE that matches with the materials used as electrodes and can be manufactured by scalable techniques, including tape casting, screen printing, spin coating, thermal spray (TS), PVD, and additive manufacturing (AM), among others [28,73–77]. Fig. 4 (a) depicts the crystal structure of zirconia (ZrO2). Zr4+ cations occupy the regular lattice positions of the face-centered cubic (FCC) unit cell, and all eight interstitial tetrahedral positions are filled by O2− according to the ZrO2 stoichiometric ratio. This chemistry coordination is required to ensure the electroneutrality of the crystalline lattice [78–86]. However, this structure remains stable only ranging from 2370 to 2680 °C. While cooling from 2370 to 1170 °C, the ceramic cubic structure of ZrO2 undergoes a transformation into its tetragonal allotrope. At temperatures below 1170 °C, the tetragonal phase changes into a monoclinic structure. During the tetragonal to monoclinic martensitic transition, the unit cell experiences a volumetric expansion of 3%–4%. This transition triggers multiple crack propagations throughout the crystal lattice, resulting in mechanical failure of the ZrO2 ceramic after sintering. To address this issue, ZrO2 is doped with other compounds like magnesia (MgO), calcia (CaO), or aliovalent oxides such as gadolinia (Gd2O3), samaria (Sm2O3), or hafnia (Hf2O3). These dopants stabilize the cubic phase field of ZrO2 at room temperature (Troom ) [87–93]. Fig. 4(b) provides a 2D schematic explanation of the doping mechanism. If four Zr4+ are replaced by four Y3+, the lattice acquires a net negative charge equals minus four. Consequently, two O2− anions located on the crystal surface are expelled as molecular O2 in the surrounding atmosphere, resulting in the formation of two V O ∙ ∙ each one with two positive charges. This mechanism ensures the overall electroneutrality of the crystal lattice. Depending on the dopant and its concentration, typically ranging from 6 to 12 mol% for Y2O3 to obtain YSZ, the crystal cubic structure can remain stable from Troom up to ∼2500 °C. This ordered and relatively open crystal structure, as observed in 8YSZ, has the ionic jump lowest activation energy (E at.) of V O ∙ ∙ migration, resulting in an σ ion . of ∼0.05 S·cm−1 and an Eat. of ∼1 eV at 800 °C. These attributes contribute to achieving desirable efficiency and power output in SOFCs operating at this Top . [73,78,94]. The equations 1 and 2 describe the solid-state chemical reaction of the V O ∙ ∙ formation in ZrO2 as well as the chemical equilibrium, both expressed using the Kröger-Vink notation [95,96]. (1) Y 2 O 3 + 2 Zr Zr → Z r O 2 2 Y Zr ′ + 3 O O + V O ∙ ∙ (2) Y Zr ′ = 2 V O ∙ ∙ ZrO2 exhibits intrinsic formation of V O ∙ ∙ ranging from 800 to 1000 °C. However, the concentration of these charge carriers is too low, leading to insufficient transport of O2− anions, resulting in reduced values of σ ion . . The Equation 2 demonstrates that the concentration of extrinsic V O ∙ ∙ is half of Y3+ concentration. If all V O ∙ ∙ are available and can migrate freely through the crystal lattice, the mobile vacancies concentration is equal to the fraction of stoichiometric vacancies. However, if the dopant concentration becomes excessively high, coulombic interactions can give rise to electrostatic clusters such as ( Y Zr ′ V O ∙ ∙ ) ∙ and ( Y Zr ′ V O ∙ ∙ Y Zr ′ ) x decreasing the σ ion . , particularly at temperatures lower than 800 °C [97]. The 8YSZ electrolyte must also have the following attributes: (i) density higher than 98% of the theoretical density (∼5.8 g·cm−3) to prevent mixture between the fuel and oxidant gases; (ii) good mechanical properties [98]; (iii) wide electrolytic domain exhibiting transfer numbers greater than 0.99 [99,100]; (iv) physicochemical stability under thermal and redox cycling [20]. The high Top . ranging from 800 to 1000 °C of 8YSZ electrolyte limits the choice of materials for other SOFCs components. In this temperature range, the selection of advanced materials is necessary for the ICs, current collectors, and sealants, resulting in an overall increase in the final SOFC stack cost [28]. This high Top . also leads to several adverse effects, including: (i) electrodes coarsening; (ii) interdiffusion of chemical elements between electrodes and electrolyte interfaces; (iii) degradation, such as the precipitation of pyrochlores charge carrier blocking phases at the cathode and electrolyte interfaces; (iv) mechanical fatigue owing to the CTEs mismatch between electrodes and electrolytes [24,28,101–106]; (v) Cr volatilization from the lanthanum chromite (LaCrO3) ceramic ICs of SOFCs; (vi) Cr interdiffusion from stainless steel ICs to electrodes in MS-SOFCs [107–110]. These factors play a crucial role in the lifespan of these devices. Due to these factors, the SOFC still requires the use of expensive advanced ceramic materials, hindering the competitiveness of this technology in the power generation market [28,111,112]. The primary challenge lies in decreasing the Top . of SOFCs, which can be achieved by: (i) minimizing the thickness of 8YSZ electrolyte to mitigate energy losses from ohmic polarization or (ii) using electrolytes with ionic conductivity higher than 8YSZ [113–120]. Other O2− conductors’ electrolytes can be employed in SOFCs. Fig. 5 illustrates Arrhenius curves depicting the total electrical conductivity ( σ total ) as a function of the absolute inverse temperature for several O2− conductor electrolytes more conductive than 8YSZ. The electrical conductivity at 650 °C for YSZ, LSGMC, and ESB-based electrolytes are 6.9 × 10−3 S·cm−1, 2.6 × 10−1 S·cm−1 and 3.8 × 10−1 S·cm−1. LSGMC and ESB-based electrolytes are recent and require further improvement due to their physicochemical instability and strong degradation at this Top .. For instance, BCY degrades in the presence of CO2 and moisture, reverting to its precursor oxides even upon prolonged exposure at Troom . Except for YSZ and GDC electrolytes, LSGMC, LSGM, and SNDC degrades quickly ranging from 600 to 700 °C, which is caused by the precipitation of blocking phases at electrodes/electrolyte interfaces. Additionally, the high-cost of these raw materials leads to another restriction on the application. In this context, 8YSZ and 10GDC ceramic film electrolytes are commonly used in SOFC stacks for stationary power generation. These electrolytes can be deposited over the anodes of IT-SOFCs, LT-SOFCs, or MS-SOFCs. Using these electrolytes, the IT-SOFCs can achieve power densities as high as 1–2 W·cm−2 at 800 °C, and MS-SOFCs can maintain this power range at Top . = 650 °C, thanks to reductions in ohmic polarizations using electrolyte films in the range of 1–3 μm of thickness. The power losses result from: (i) ohmic polarization in the electrolyte due to the space charge layers at grain boundaries; (ii) activation polarization at the electrodes due to the sluggish kinetic of the electrochemical reactions and (iii) mass transport polarization at the electrodes due to the difficulty of the gaseous species in accessing and leaving the active regions [121–124]. 10GDC has found successful applications as DBLs covering both the PMS and 8YSZ electrolyte in MS-SOFCs [28,125–127]. However, when 10GDC is applied as an electrolyte in the range of 700–900 °C and oxygen partial pressure ( PP O 2 ) ranging from 10−25 to 10−12 atm, Ce4+ are reduced to Ce3+ [128,129]. This reduction promotes the transport of electronic charge carriers across the 10GDC electrolyte crystal lattice by small polarons, causing SOFC short-circuiting [130,131]. Furthermore, Ce3+ has a larger ionic radius, leading to chemical expansion and CTE mismatch, triggering crack propagation and mechanical fatigue failures under cycling [28,125,132,133]. The Equation 3 illustrates the solid-state chemical reaction of CeO2 reduction to produce O2, Ce3+, and V O ∙ ∙ in the crystal lattice [95]. (3) O O + 2 Ce Ce ↔ 1 2 O 2 ( g a s ) + 2 Ce Ce ′ + V O ∙ ∙ The current SOFC state-of-the-art comprising: (i) NiO/8YSZ or NiO/10GDC porous anodes; (ii) 8YSZ electrolyte; and (iii) a La1-xSrxMnO3 (LSM) mixed ionic and electronic conductor (MIEC) cathode [28]. These components are used to manufacture HT-SOFCs and IT-SOFCs that can operate ranging from 800 to 1000 °C. These SOFCs can achieve power densities ranging from 0.2 to 1.2 W·cm−2 and efficiencies ranging from 0.45 to 0.60 when powered by H2, hydrocarbon, or biofuels [28,49,134–138]. The lower power peak of 0.2 W·cm−2 is attributed to the ohmic and activation polarizations [139–142]. Fig. 6 depicts a volume element of an IT-SOFC planar cell, which consists of ceramic ICs based on LaCrO3, 8YSZ electrolyte, and composite electrodes based on Ni/8YSZ and LSM-8YSZ. The 8YSZ dense electrolyte separates the electrode chambers. The air is injected and directed through the IC channels to reach the porous cathode surface. In this surface, O2 from the air is reduced into O2− anions at the cathode active sites. The O2− anions migrate by the V O ∙ ∙ of the 8YSZ crystal lattice to reach the anode TPBs. H2, hydrocarbon, or biofuels are injected and directed via the IC channels to the porous anode surface. These fuels are oxidated at the anode TPBs, producing either H2O or H2O and CO2, heat, and free electrons. These electrons are used in an external circuit before being collected by the cathode. IT-SOFCs have demonstrated superior performance and longer lifespans in comparison to HT-SOFCs. Over the past two decades, significant advancements have been made in the development of IT-SOFCs that can be powered by hydrocarbon and biofuels, including C2H5OH and CH4 as shown in Fig. 2(c) and (e). Notably, Siemens Westinghouse (Germany) [143], Mitsubishi (Japan), Rolls Royce (England) [144], and Bloom Energy (USA) have successfully commercialized HT-SOFCs and IT-SOFCs integrated with gas-turbine hybrid systems. These systems are designed for the regenerative reuse of steam to generate stationary electric power, achieving impressive efficiencies between 0.60 < η < 0.90. Nonetheless, a significant IT-SOFC drawback arises when they are powered by hydrocarbon or biofuels. This is mainly attributed to the coking on the anode Ni surface, which leads to the deactivation of the electrocatalytic active sites [46]. The thickness of IT-SOFCs electrolytes (∼10–20 μm) can also be an issue. Down 800 °C, the IT-SOFCs exhibit high energy losses due to the following factors: (i) intrinsic ohmic polarization by the nature of the V O ∙ ∙ electrostatic migration process; (ii) extrinsic ohmic polarization due to the space charge layers created by the segregation of dopants and (iii) hindered migration of the V O ∙ ∙ due to the heterogeneity and imperfections of the crystal lattice caused by segregation of dopant and formation of microdomains inside the bulk which block the migration of the V O ∙ ∙ [145–147]. Thicker electrolytes result in a larger average free path for ionic charge carriers, leading to higher impedance. This feature induces more shock and scattering of O2− and V O ∙ ∙ inside the crystal. The ionic migration of O2− and V O ∙ ∙ across the 8YSZ crystal is thermally activated and exhibits an exponential dependence on temperature (Arrhenius Law). This activation is especially important when hydrocarbons or biofuels are directly reformed due to their highly endothermic nature, creating colder zones inside the anode with lower ionic conductivity. To mitigate this phenomenon, thinner electrolytes are employed at higher Top . to reduce the ohmic losses owing to elastic and inelastic shocks of the O2− and V O ∙ ∙ and the sub-lattice cations [148]. IT-SOFCs anode materials have been optimized for the use of low-cost logistics biofuels such as bioethanol and biomethane, which are more versatile than H2 [46,149]. The NiO/8YSZ composite anode is widely preferred in IT-SOFCs due to the following advantages: (i) exceptional particle size and size distribution of NiO and 8YSZ besides interconnected pores; (ii) efficient reactant/product diffusion; (iii) high density of TPBs; (iv) good electrocatalytic activity for H2, C2H5OH, or CH4 bonds cleavage; (v) good electronic and ionic conductivities; (vi) structural stability; (vii) low-cost of Ni compared to noble metals like Pt, rhodium (Rh), and palladium (Pd); and (viii) electrolyte CTE matching. The CTE of NiO/8YSZ composite anode and 8YSZ electrolyte is 12 × 10−6 °C−1 and 14 × 10−6 °C−1 ranging from 300 to 900 °C [150]. However, the main disadvantages of NiO/8YSZ anodes in IT-SOFCs are: (i) low redox cycling; (ii) degradation ranging from 800 to 1000 °C, and (iii) surface deactivation of Ni by coking. Many researchers have explored alternative materials with the goal of improving performance, reducing degradation caused by coking, and extending the IT-SOFCs lifespan [18,46,151,152]. Table S2 of SI presents several performance, efficiency, and durability data of IT-SOFC and HT-SOFC for several cell configurations powered by H2, C2H5OH, or CH4. These studies focus on enhancing the performance of IT-SOFCs and HT-SOFCs by: (i) reducing the coking; (ii) improving the kinetics of H2, C2H5OH, or CH4 oxidation; (iii) hydration of the fuels to mitigate coking; (iv) enhancement of the mechanical properties and physicochemical stability of the SOFC electrolyte and electrodes. As depicted in Table S2 of SI, Ni is the most used catalyst in anode for SOFCs. This is attributed to the following aspects: (i) excellent electronic conductivity and (ii) high concentration of basic sites in the metallic surface, which promote the cleavage of H2, hydrocarbons, and biofuels covalent bonds. Furthermore, Ni has proven to be an effective catalyst for the thermal decomposition (cracking) of hydrocarbons in the synthesis of nanotubes and graphene. An alternative approach involves the use of Ni-Cu alloys in SOFC anodes. Cu has a lower catalytic activity compared to Ni presenting lower coking over its surface and a slight reduction of IT-SOFC power density [46,153–155]. Noble metals such as Pt, Rh, Pd, and silver (Ag) can be used for C2H5OH reforming at IT-SOFCs anodes. Pt is an effective catalyst for methanol (CH3OH) and C2H5OH deprotonation. It also facilitates the cleavage of H2 covalent bonds. However, the use of Pt in C2H5OH reforming results in the generation of high concentrations of CO. To address this issue, Pt-Ru alloys are employed. These alloys mitigate coking because ruthenium (Ru) undergoes rapid oxidation, producing O2− anions. These anions react with the adsorbed CO, transforming it into CO2 and preventing coking on the active surface [46,153]. However, these noble metals are skyrocketing expensive. 3.2 SOFCs directly powered by biofuels SOFCs can directly reform natural gas (NG), biogas, biomethane, bioethanol and biomass-derived syngas into electricity with efficiencies higher than gas engines and turbines. SOFCs exhibit reduced emissions of CO2, sulfur oxides (SOx), CO, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and nitrogen oxides (NOx) [49]. NOx is a great concern for ICEVs, even if biofuels are employed. Other contaminants, such as siloxanes, H2S, and sulfur-containing organic compounds present in biofuels, react with Ni of the reformers and SOFC anodes. High concentrations of these contaminants are frequently found in sewage biogas, as well as in manure and food waste. Halogenated compounds and siloxanes are predominantly present in landfill biogas [49]. Ni-free anodes have been used to enhance the performance and lifespan of SOFCs powered by fuels containing impurities. Mahato et al. reviewed Ni-free anodes, including Cu and Ce-based perovskites with improved resilience against sulfur attack and coking. Anodes with higher resistance to sulfur attack might result in increased SOx emissions due to H2S oxidation. Siloxanes, even in ppb trace amounts, are a severe threat to reformers and anode SOFCs, leading to irreversible degradation by SiO2 growth over the Ni catalyst surface. Instead, the impact of H2S is lower than siloxanes, causing temporary performance setbacks without irreversible damage [28]. Logistic fuels like bioethanol and NG hold potential advantages over H2, given the undeveloped H2 hubs and pipelines distribution in the entire world. Ethanol Steam Reform (ESR), Steam Methane Reform (SMR), and the water–gas shift reaction (WGS) may occur when these fuels are used in SOFCs, impacting the partial pressures of H2 and CO, the temperatures, and the disparities in Nernst potentials at different points inside the cell [156]. For instance, Afroz et al. reported Ni-Cu/GDC nanocatalysts applied as anodes of SOFCs powered by biogas. (NiO(1-x)CuOx)/yGDC nanocatalysts with stoichiometry between 0.2 < x < 0.8 and y = 1 or 1.3 were synthesized by solid-state reaction. SOFCs were manufactured by pressing LiNiCuZnO as cathode and GDC as electrolyte. 0.2NiO-0.8CuO/1.3GDC powered by biogas showed 72 mW·cm−2 and OCV of 0.84 V at 650 °C. The biogas composition was 55% CH4, 25% CO2, 9% H2, 5% CO, and 5% N2 with 1% H2S + ash + O2 by volume. In long-term tests up to 72 h at 650 °C, the cells demonstrated voltage and power degradation of 0.14 mV·h−1 and 0.75 mW·cm−2 after two hours without coking [157]. 3.3 Coking Low-carbon fuels, such as NG or biogas with high CH4 concentration, hold promise for SOFC technological applications. The high Top . of SOFCs allows the internal cracking of lightweight hydrocarbons, eliminating the demand for external reforming. However, direct exposure can lead to SOFC anode degradation. One approach to mitigate this issue is regulating the oxygen-to-carbon (O/C) ratio in the fuel. This can be achieved by adding air to NG and partially separating CO2 from biogas (refining/upgrading). Such measures prevent degradation by coking. Researchers have reported the use of IT-SOFCs powered by air-diluted NG and upgraded biogas with 0.2 < O/C < 1.2 ratio. NG and biogas undergo air dilution and CO2 separation, respectively, before being used as fuels in SOFCs in order to avoid coking. The synthetic biogas composition used was 56 vol%CH4:36 vol%CO2:8vol%N2, with an O/C ratio of 0.8 [158]. According to Gibbs free energy equilibrium predictions, an O/C ratio of 1.2 is the minimum acceptable value to prevent coking at 800 °C [159]. However, SOFCs can operate at lower O/C ratios without experiencing coking [158]. Button NiO/YSZ anode-supported cells with 8YSZ electrolyte, GDC (gadolinia-doped ceria) DBL, and LSCF (La1-xSrxCoyFe1-yO3-δ) cathode were manufactured and tested using air-diluted NG and upgraded biogas. SOFCs operated at O/C < 1.2 did not exhibit coking. At 800 °C and a constant discharge of 500 mA·cm−2, cell performances were measured over 100 h of testing. Post-mortem analysis was performed on the samples to investigate morphological changes after exposure to high-methane fuels. For an O/C ratio of 0.8 (+63 vol% air), cells powered by air-diluted NG achieve 867 mV at 500 mA·cm−2. For upgraded biogas, partial CO2 separation to achieve an O/C of 0.4 (−60 vol% CO2) enabled better and stable performance, reaching 880 mV at 500 mA·cm−2. However, the cells running on pure synthetic biogas at O/C ratio of 0.8 at 800 °C failed due to NiO/YSZ deactivation caused by coking [160]. These carbon deposits reduce the SOFC performance by obstructing reagent access to the anode TPBs. The interfaces between Ni, NiO, YSZ phases, and the coke exhibit CTEs mismatch. During the start-up and light-off switching, and redox cycles, micro-defects emerge, propagating cracks that spread by the anode microstructure. These cracks lead to anode delamination, mechanical failure, and performance drop due to the loss of contact between the percolated electronic and ionic conductor phases. Thus, it is crucial to understand the behavior of the anode materials and fuels at the operating conditions in order to set up modifications that can mitigate coking [4,49,135–137,161–164]. Ni/YSZ anodes synthesized by sol–gel and hydrothermal combustion with distinct compositions and co-dopants have been evaluated in SOFCs powered by CH4 among 650–850 °C. The analysis of the exhaust gases has been performed using mass spectrometry and gas chromatography. The coke concentration is typically determined through temperature programmed oxidation (TPO). The coking rate on the anode TPBs can be influenced by the synthesis route, chemical composition, and the anode microstructure. The coking rate on NiO/YSZ anodes strongly depends on the O/C ratio at the TPBs. This rate can be boosted by enhancing: (i) the mass transfer of reactants across the anode to TPBs via control of diameter, volume, and orientation of the pore; (ii) the inlet concentration of CH4 gas; and (iii) the SOFCs current density. The power density of the cell increases with more efficient mass transfer of CH4 to the TPBs. However, a low O/C ratio at the TPBs results in coking. Otherwise, elevating the current density and reducing the CH4 concentration raises the O/C ratio at the TPBs, reducing the coking rate [165]. The O/C ratio affects the coking rate in SOFCs powered by CH4. Controlling the operating parameters and the anode microstructure can potentially reduce or prevent coking. Wang et al. optimized the O/C ratio changing the SOFC anodes pore structure, inlet CH4 concentration, and cell current density. Higher CH4 levels in the fuel inlet led to efficient mass transfer and elevated CH4 levels at the TPBs, ensuring a high-power density. However, coking rates have increased, reducing the SOFC lifespan. The coking rate can be also reduced by increasing the cell operating current density. Therefore, adjusting the operating parameters and anode microstructure can eliminate coking on NiO-based anodes, ensuring stable power generation by CH4 [165]. 3.4 Recent break-throughs in SOFC construction Using advanced materials for direct CH4 electrochemical oxidation represents a viable strategy for enhancing performance and lifespan while reducing coking on the SOFC anode. Researchers have explored the substitution of Ni in SOFC anodes with other metals, including Co, Cu, or bimetallic Co-Cu alloys. Sarruf et al. reported CeO2 composite anodes incorporating Co, Cu, and Co-Cu catalysts by amorphous citrate route. CeO2-10Sc1CeSZ (Ce0.01Zr0.99)0.80Sc0.20O2-δ: 10 mol% Sc2O3 and 1 mol% CeO2 stabilized ZrO2 buffer layer was screen printed on the 10Sc1CeSZ (150 μm of thickness) electrolyte and sintered at 1300 °C for 2 h in ambient atmosphere. LSM cathode slurries were screen printed on the other side of the electrolyte and sintered at 1100 °C for 2 h in an ambient atmosphere. (Co, Cu, Co-Cu)x/(CeO2)y slurry-based anodes were screen printed on the buffer layer and calcined at 800 °C for 2 h in an ambient atmosphere. Ag wires glued with Ag ink over the electrodes were employed as current collectors. The buffer layer was applied to prevent delamination during cycling due to a CTE mismatch between the electrolyte and the anode. The CTE of 10Sc1CeSZ electrolyte and CuO and CoO are 13–14 × 10−6 °C−1 and 5–7 × 10−6 °C−1, respectively. However, after the thermal reduction of CuO and CoO into Cu and Co, the CTE for both metals is ∼17 × 10−6 °C−1 [166]. Co2Cu-CeO2 anode-based SOFCs exhibited power densities of 540, 450, and 400 mW · cm−2 at 800 °C when assessed with anhydrous H2, C2H5OH, and CH4 outperforming the Co-CeO2 and Cu-CeO2 anode-based SOFCs, which demonstrated 120–150 mW·cm−2 at 800 °C. Moreover, Co2Cu-CeO2 anode-based SOFCs showed stability over 24 h of continuous operation. These cells are appropriate for electro-oxidation of hydrocarbons and biofuels exhibiting no evidence of coking. The Co2Cu-CeO2 electrocatalyst from Troom up to ∼500 °C has a biphasic microstructure comprising two solid solutions based on Co rich in Cu (HCP: hexagonal close packed) and Cu rich in Co (FCC). In the range of 700–850 °C, the same microstructure persists, with a slight chemical redistribution in each solid solution, while both phases are FCC. This architecture promotes homogeneous microstructure even with an interface of the same phase. Heterointerfaces with the same or different phases are known to yield synergistic effects, thereby enhancing electrochemical and electrocatalytic properties [121,166–168]. To prevent coking on NiO-based anode, a thin pre-catalytic layer also can be applied. This layer facilitates the conversion of hydrocarbon and biofuels into H2 and CO. Wei et al. reported SOFC anodes coated with a pre-catalytic layer of La0.60Sr0.20Cr0.85Ni0.15O3-δ (LSCrNi) with exsolved Ni nanoparticles. SOFCs were manufactured using NiO/5GDC anodes, both containing the LSCrNi pre-catalytic layer and lacking it. Fig. 7 (a and b) depict the microstructure of the anode and the catalyst layer interface cross-sectional besides the semi-quantitative Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) [169]. LSCF and 5GDC were used as cathode and electrolyte, respectively. 5GDC electrolyte was screen printed on the 60 wt%NiO:40 wt%GDC green anode previously shaped by tape casting and both were co-sintered. 70 wt%LSCF:30 wt%5GDC cathode was deposited on the electrolyte by screen printing, and the entire cell was sintered. Then, a slurry containing 80 wt% of 20 wt%GDC-LSCrNi was screen printed on the NiO/5GDC anode. SOFCs containing the 20 wt%GDC-LSCrNi pre-catalyst layer and those lacking it showed 856 and 822 mW·cm−2 when powered by H2 at 750 °C. Similarly, the SOFCs containing the 20 wt%GDC-LSCrNi pre-catalyst layer and those lacking it, powered by 50 vol%CH4:50vol.%CO2, exhibited maximum power densities of 496 and 758 mW·cm−2 at 750 °C. The SOFCs with the 20 wt%GDC-LSCrNi pre-catalyst layer show good performance and stability, achieving 0.65 V and 84% of CH4 conversion without coking despite the lower power density as shown in Fig. 7(c and d). However, the SOFCs lacking the pre-catalyst layer despite, presenting the higher power density showed a voltage drop of 76.9% over 36 h of testing under 400 mA·cm−2 at 750 °C due to the coking as depicted in Fig. 7(c and e). To confirm coking, the electrodes were characterized by Raman spectroscopy and EDS, which showed a high coking on the electrode without the catalyst and no coking on the electrode with the catalyst as shown in Fig. 7(f and h) [169]. Chen et al. reported SOFCs with power density as high as 370 mW·cm−2 at 500 °C when powered by 96.5 vol%CH4:3.5 vol%H2O. This cell has operated for 550 h without coking. The manufacturing process included: (i) synthesis of NiO/BZCYYb (BaZr0.10Ce0.70Y0.10Yb0.10O3–δ) anode by conventional oxide mixing, followed by tape casting and sintering at 1000 °C for 2 h; (ii) deposition of a functional layer of NiO/BZCYYb and SDC on the anode by suspension dripping, drying and sintering at 1400 °C for 5 h; (iii) synthesis of PrBa0.50Sr0.50Co1.50Fe0.50O5+δ (PBSCF) cathode nanofibers by electrospinning, followed by painting a ink containing the nanofibers on the other electrolyte surface, and thermal-treated at 950 °C for 2 h; (iv) infiltration of 20 μL of 0.1 Molar of SDC solution on the anode surface and drying; (v) a Ce0.90Ni0.05Ru0.05O2-δ slurry of the pre-catalytic layer was painted on the anode; (vi) infiltration of 5 μL of 0.1 Molar of Pr(NO3)3 solution on the cathode surface and (vii) sintering the entire cell at 800 °C for 2 h in an ambient atmosphere. The higher catalytic activity and coking resistance of the pre-catalytic layer can be attributed to the synergistic effect in the Ni and Ru ex-solution on the surface. This hypothesis was validated through computer simulation and in situ experiments [170]. The methodologies of ex-solution, infiltration, impregnation, and solid-state reactions of catalyst nanoparticles on the electrode pores play a crucial role in achieving electrodes with enhanced dispersion, distribution, and strong interaction in the support and catalyst particles. The degree of dispersion, distribution, and interaction significantly impacts the electrochemical properties and physicochemical stability of the electrodes. These attributes reduce the coarsening and coking on the electrodes during SOFC operation. The coarsening reduction leads to a substantial increase in the SOFCs performance and lifespan [171]. 3.5 Advanced approaches for manufacturing high-performance SOFCs Innovative techniques such as microengineering have been used for SOFCs manufacturing to enhance performance, mitigate coking, and extend lifespan. Pulsed-laser deposition (PLD) was used to construct nanocomposite layers to improve the performance of anode-supported SOFC as shown in Fig. 8 (a). Develos-Bagarinao et al. reported high-performance SOFCs with 4.7 W·cm−2 at 700 °C. This was possible by nanoengineering techniques used to construct the nanoporous active cathode LSC and the nanocomposite cathode LSCF-GDC both fabricated by PLD. Fig. 8(b–d) show high-magnification cross-sectional SEM images of the SOFC, where the nanostructures of the layers can be observed. To confirm the nanostructure patterns, high-resolution scanning transmission electron microscopy with high-angle annular dark-field (STEM-HAADF) images and EDS elemental mapping were obtained as depicted in Fig. 8(e, f). The nanostructures SOFCs demonstrated high electrochemical performance at low temperatures, the highest performance reported in the literature, showing values in the range of 2.2–4.7 W·cm−2 at 650 and 700 °C when powered by 97.0 vol%H2:3.0 vol%H2O as depicted in Fig. 8(g). The SOFCs exhibited stable electrochemical performance at ∼0.8 V for 250 h without any voltage drop [172]. Researchers have reported remarkable findings on tubular SOFCs exhibiting high performance and coking resistance. Micro-monolithic SOFCs were manufactured with an asymmetric geometry, enabling the separation of the mechanical support and anode from the electrochemically active sites. These SOFCs exhibited a notable enhancement in mass transport, achieving power densities in the range of 1,770–2,220 mW·cm−2 when powered by fuels with low calorific value gases (LCVGs). The majority of the world’s biomethane and NG sources consist of LCVGs, typically containing less than 20 vol% of CH4 levels. Exploiting these sources poses challenges due to skyrocketing costs associated with gas refining and upgrading technologies. Therefore, there is potential for developing more cost-effective alternatives for LCVG direct utilization [173]. Li et al. reported micro-monolithic SOFCs exceeding 2000 mW·cm−2 when supplied with 10–20 vol% CH4 in the fuel stream at 700 °C. This outcome results in emerge from the reduction of mass transport polarization and the effective prevention of coking for over 4,000 h, facilitated by the micro-monolithic anode support design. This design comprises six sub-channels with radial droplet morphology manufactured using the phase inversion technique of a polymeric binder precipitation by solvent-coagulant exchange under controlled isostatic pressure. This support, with an external diameter of 2.2 ± 0.1 mm and a thickness of 50 μm, played a crucial role in providing a high surface area per volume, ensuring a high volumetric power density. The YSZ electrolyte (4.5 μm of thickness) and GDC buffer (4.5 μm of thickness) layers were deposited via dip-coating on the anode support and co-sintered at 1400 °C. The LCSF-GDC cathode (25–30 μm of thickness) was deposited using dip-coating and sintered at 1000 °C for 2 h. Ag wires were utilized as current collectors in both electrodes [173]. Fig. 9 depicts this disruptive micro-tubular SOFC. The techniques, methodologies, and insights discussed above play a crucial role in enhancing the feasibility of SOFC technology for efficient electricity generation from hydrocarbon and biofuels like bioethanol and biogas. The durability of these systems is significantly impacted by the presence of impurities in hydrocarbons, particularly in biofuels. Biogas can be refined to produce biomethane, converted into syngas, and utilized as fuel in SOFCs, enabling the efficient generation of stationary and decentralized power. Moreover, bioethanol and biomethane can be onboard reformed into syngas and employed for power generation in electrified vehicles equipped with stacks of MS-SOFCs. 4 MS-SOFCs powered by H2 and biofuels: Features, benefits, and drawbacks 4.1 Innovative design, high efficiency performance, and scalability at low cost New fabrication techniques have been developed for SOFC operation in temperatures lower than 800 °C. These include the deposition of SOFC ceramic films on PMSs to obtain the MS-SOFCs which can operate in the range of 550–750 °C. In this range, cost-effective FSS and ASS-based PMSs and ICs can be used. The inclusion of metallic materials enables MS-SOFC manufacturing with lower CAPEX investments and scalable techniques, thereby enhancing the competitiveness of this technology in the mobility market. This progress is also attributed to the: (i) MS-SOFCs are sealed and integrated into stacks by laser micro-welding, ensuring robustness and gas tightness; (ii) resistance to mechanical vibrations; (iii) good redox cycling; and (iv) rapid start-up and light-off switching facilitated by the high thermal conductivity of metallic PMSs and ICs. These devices also can be powered by reformed syngas derived from hydrocarbon or biofuels, exhibiting performance higher than SOFCs. These features of MS-SOFCs can enable them to scale up in stacks at a lower cost for application in the mobility sector. This new powertrain system comprising a stack of MS-SOFCs powered by hydrocarbons or biofuels represents a wide global market, spanning cars, trucks, agricultural machinery, trains, airplanes, and cargo ships, with the key component being the MS-SOFC. Fig. 10 depicts an MS-SOFC architecture designed solely for proof-of-concept. MS-SOFCs can be manufactured using: (i) dense ICs made of FSS, ASS, Inconel 600 (NiCrFe alloy) or Hastelloy (NiMoFeCr alloy) of high oxidation resistance shaped by mechanical stamping, machining, or laser cut; (ii) PMS made from the same materials of the ICs (300–500 μm of thickness) manufactured by tape casting, 3D printing, or sheets micro-drilled by laser; (iii) 10GDC DBL layer (500–800 nm of thickness) deposited by PVD or sol–gel on the PMS; (iv) porous Ni/8YSZ base anode layer (20–60 μm of thickness) deposited by screen printing on the 10GDC DBL layer; (v) porous Ni/10GDC active anode layer (10–20 μm of thickness) also deposited by screen printing on the base anode layer; (vi) dense 8YSZ electrolyte layer (1–5 μm of thickness) deposited on the active anode layer by PVD or sol–gel; (vii) 10GDC DBL (500–800 nm of thickness) deposited by PVD or sol–gel on the 8YSZ electrolyte layer; (viii) high electrocatalytic activity cathode layers, such as LSC (La1-xSrxCoO3-δ) or LSCF with (10–30 μm of thickness) deposited on the last DBL layer by screen printing; (ix) spinels DBLs based on CoxOy, CuMn2O4, and MnCo2O4 (500–800 nm of thickness) deposited by PVD or sol–gel on the cathode layer or cathode IC. Some studies have reported the use of different materials, architectures, microstructure engineering, and techniques to manufacture MS-SOFCs, leading to remarkable performance improvements. Typically, a 10GDC DBL of 500 nm is deposited on FSS or ASS PMSs by PVD. This DBL prevents the inter-diffusion of Fe, Cr, and Ni into the anode layer, minimizing the formation of insulating blocking phases for charge carriers. Subsequently, Ni/8YSZ and Ni/10GDC suspension in an ink vehicle based on α-terpineol and ethyl-cellulose, containing pore formers (such as corn starch, carbon black, or PMMA) with suitable particle and distribution sizes are deposited on the 10GDC DBL over the PMS by screen printing using a small aperture polyester mesh. Following this, a dense 8YSZ electrolyte layer is deposited by PVD to seal the active anode surface and prevent the mixing of fuel and air. Then, a 10GDC DBL is deposited on the 8YSZ electrolyte before the deposition of the LSCF or LSC cathode layer by screen printing [10,17,55,174–183]. The hierarchical stacking of the anode layers is organized to minimize the roughness of the active anode surface to prevent issues such as 8YSZ electrolyte flaws, pinholes, delamination, and cracks. Each anode layer is designed with an appropriate particle size and distribution. MS-SOFCs play a pivotal role in the onboard power generation of FCHEVs, demonstrating high synergy when powered by logistical biofuels. This aligns with existing value chains for biofuel production and distribution established in many countries. MS-SOFCs also boast significant attributes such as a compact design, mechanical robustness, efficient power generation, and materials cost advantage compared to SOFCs [13,184]. To enhance the efficiency of MS-SOFCs powered by biofuels, improvements in performance and long-term stability are imperative. These enhancements aim to extend the lifespan by mitigating PMS oxidation and coking. Among these strategies, coating the PMS with DBLs or a pre-catalytic layer for direct internal reforming and the impregnation of catalyst nanoparticles into the PMS and anode scaffolds are the most effective method to improve electrochemical devices [13,184]. The next sections aim to discuss the challenges and advances in key components for the construction of MS-SOFCs, such as anodes, electrolytes, cathodes, DBLs, and PMS. 4.2 Anodes for MS-SOFCs Researchers have focused on enhancing the properties of SOFC anode materials to enable the use of cost-effective logistic fuels such as bioethanol and biomethane [46,135–137,161]. The NiO/8YSZ composite is the most employed anode material due to its: (i) good control over the size, distribution, and pores interconnection to promote the suitable transport of reactants and products; (ii) high surface area of TPBs; (iii) high electrocatalytic activity; (iv) high electrical conductivity, structural stability, and CTEs matching [135–137,150,161,185]. The main drawbacks of NiO/8YSZ composite anodes in MS-SOFCs powered by hydrocarbon and biofuels include the low kinetic performance of electrochemical reactions, coarsening, and coking during the long-term. To mitigate coking and achieve good stability and performance, researchers have explored the incorporation of more active materials as anodes [18,135–138,151,152]. Ni, 8YSZ, and 10GDC thin particles coarsening in the anode is the most damaging mechanism of degradation. This phenomenon arises from the auto-diffusion of nano or sub-micrometric particles at highly porous regions, leading to the growth of larger particles while smaller ones decrease. Consequently, the volume of pores increases, reducing the TPBs area and MS-SOFC performance. Researchers have addressed this issue by creating composite anodes by infiltration of Ni, YSZ, and GDC catalyst precursor salts into YSZ or GDC scaffolds, followed by calcination to impregnate these catalyst nanoparticles. Despite these efforts, the nanoparticles still undergo coarsening in long-term due to the high surface area of the catalyst material, reducing the available TPBs for redox reactions [17,177,186–189]. Dewa et al. developed MS-SOFCs with the following configuration: a Sc2O3 co-doped YSZ (Sc-YSZ) anode scaffold co-laminated with FSS 430 PMS (300 μm of thickness) by tape casting and both infiltrated with Ni/GDC followed by the deposition of a Sc-YSZ dense electrolyte on the anode and sintered at 1350 °C in a reducing atmosphere. Then, a 5 wt% Rh/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst was infiltrated in both PMS and anode scaffold and calcinated at 600 °C. Afterward, the La0.80Sr0.20CoO3-δ cathode layer was deposited on the Sc-YSZ electrolyte surface by screen printing and activated in-situ [184]. MS-SOFCs featuring an active area of 0.60 cm2 were tested using 45 vol% C2H5OH in H2O at 600 °C. The cells lacking the 5 wt% Rh/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst delivered 120 mW·cm−2 under 280 mA·cm−2 at 0.45 V, whereas those incorporating the catalyst achieved 150 mW·cm−2 under 360 mA·cm−2 at 0.60 V. For long-term, this MS-SOFC lacks the 5 wt% Rh/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst delivered 100 mA·cm−2 at 0.70 V but was deactivated by coking after 1.2 h. Meanwhile, the same configuration cell with 5 wt% Rh/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst delivered 140 mA·cm−2 at 0.70 V with a 31% of degradation in voltage over 130 h of endurance tests with lower coking [184]. Table S3 of SI presents several performance, efficiency, and durability data of MS-SOFCs powered by H2, C2H5OH, or CH4, including several cell configurations and types of anodes. Dogdibegovic et al. have developed MS-SOFCs comprising 10SDC scaffold infiltrated with a 40 vol% Ni catalyst as the anode on PMSs based on P434L alloy followed by 10Sc1CeSZ electrolyte and Pr6O11 cathode deposition. This MS-SOFC (5 cm2 of active area) is powered directly by 45 vol% C2H5OH in H2O at 700 °C delivered 250 mW·cm−2 under 0.44 A·cm−2 at 0.7 V without coking over 100 h of operation, owing to the excellent anode Ni thin nanoparticles high surface area, as shown in Table S3 of SI [17,61]. Miura et al. reported the impregnation of Ni/GDC-based catalyst nanoparticles in MS-SOFC anodes. Ni-YSZ and Ni-GDC scaffold anodes were deposited on PMSs provided by Plansee®. GDC DBLs and YSZ electrolyte were deposited on the PMS and anode by PVD. LSC cathode (50 μm of thickness) with 0.64 cm2 of the active area was screen printed over the electrolyte and dried at 80 °C [190]. Catalysts were impregnated into the anode scaffolds and PMSs by wet infiltration of Ni:Gd:Ce and Ru:Gd:Ce with a molar ratio of 5:1:4 using Triton-X as a surfactant. The PMSs and anode scaffolds were calcinated at 350 °C for 30 min in an ambient atmosphere. The process of infiltration and calcination was repeated fourfold. The weights of Ni/GDC and Ru/GDC were 74.0 and 77.7 mg. Au mesh and Pt wires were used as current collectors in the electrodes. After assembling the cell in the experimental set-up, the system was heated up to 850 °C for 2 h to activate the LSC cathode, stabilize and adhere the catalyst nanoparticles to the anode, and cure the glassy sealant used to seal the cell. During this thermal-treatment, 10 vol% H2 and air were supplied to the anode and cathode [190]. Electrochemical tests were performed using several fuels, including H2, CH4, NG, propane, and iso-octane (C8H18). The composition used for NG comprised 27.2% CH4, 1.5% ethane (C2H6), 1.2% propane (C3H8), 0.3% butane (C4H10), 34.9% H2O, and 34.9% N2 by volume. For propane, the composition included 14% C3H8, 43% H2O, and 43% N2 by volume. Iso-octane was 4.5% C8H18, 35.9% N2, and 59.6% H2O by volume. In all cases, a steam/carbon (S/C) molar ratio equal 1 was employed to prevent coking on the PMS and anode [190]. MS-SOFCs comprising GDC anodes lacking catalysts, as well as those with Ni/GDC and Ru/GDC shows 630, 1140, and 1370 mW·cm−2 at 0.70 V when supplied with 97 vol%H2:3vol%H2O at 600 °C up to 5 h of testing. At open circuit voltage (OCV), the polarization curve slope decreases proportionally to the concentration of these impregnated catalysts. This outcome implies a reduction in the resistance of the H2 oxidation reaction (HOR) at the anode with the incorporation of nanostructured catalysts [190]. When powered by CH4, the MS-SOFCs lacking catalysts, as well as those with Ni/GDC and Ru/GDC showed 300 mW·cm−2 at 0.30 V, 970 and 1160 mW·cm−2 at 0.60 V. MS-SOFCs impregnated with Ni/GDC and Ru/GDC nanocatalysts showed 1.0 V of OCV according to the equilibrium gas composition calculated by the Nernst equation. However, the OCV of MS-SOFC without catalyst was 0.95 V, suggesting a low catalytic activity for CH4 reforming. In addition, the MS-SOFC anode lacking catalyst featured a potential sharp drop in the range of 400 and 500 mA·cm−2, indicating insufficient production of H2 and CO by the CH4 reforming. These high performances are due to the small particle size (∼100 nm) of Ni, Ce, and Gd present in the Ni/GDC scaffolds. Ni and Ru nanoparticles of ∼10–30 nm and 20 nm were obtained on the GDC scaffolds. The other reason was the formation of bimetallic Ni-Ru alloy nanoparticles on the surface of Ru/GDC anode scaffold. This microstructure was responsible for the increase of H2 adsorption and surface diffusivity, improving the electrochemical performance of the cells. The presence of Ru with a high concentration of active basic sites increases the rate of electron donation, facilitating the cleavage of C–H chemical bonds and the catalytic activity increases considerably [190–192]. These results suggest that the infiltration of nanocatalysts can boost the internal reforming of CH4 at low temperatures (Top . = 600 °C) in MS-SOFCs. Udomsilp et al. reviewed the performance of SOFCs and MS-SOFCs in terms of power density [10,12]. Compared to these benchmarks, the performance of H2-powered MS-SOFCs reported by Miura et al. is the highest ever achieved in the literature in operating temperatures as low as 600 °C. This performance is similar to SOFCs operating in the range of 800–1000 °C. Table 1 shows the power density values at 0.70 V for MS-SOFCs manufactured and tested by Miura et al. [190]. For NG, propane, and iso-octane directly reformed at 600 °C in MS-SOFCs with infiltrated Ni/GDC, the OCVs were higher than 0.97 V, suggesting good catalytic activity. At 900 mA·cm−2, the cell voltage powered by propane dropped significantly. However, the use of NG and iso-octane enables a current density up to 1200 mA·cm−2. For iso-octane, the current density at 0.7 V and 600 °C was 640 mA·cm−2. These MS-SOFCs with infiltrated catalysts exhibited suitable catalytic activity for hydrocarbons reforming up to 5 h of testing. However, the application of MS-SOFCs for onboard power generation from hydrocarbons and logistical biofuels still requires long-term testing at least 80,000 h for competitiveness in the mobility sector [190]. 4.3 Electrolytes for MS-SOFC The main objective of the MS-SOFCs is to reduce the thickness of the deposited ceramic layers, aiming for “thinner” films to minimize both Top . and cell ohmic losses [55]. As previously discussed, the electrolyte functions as a selective semipermeable membrane for O2− anions by V O ∙ ∙ promoting ionic conductivity across the cell. Simultaneously, it acts as a cell gas sealer and electronic insulator, preventing contact in the range of the anode and cathode gas chambers to prevent short-circuiting by lower impedance pathways. To comply with those requirements, a dense defect-free electrolyte is crucial. Consequently, achieving thin electrolyte layers poses challenges, often requiring the use of expensive and advanced techniques of deposition. Several fluorite and perovskite structures are used as electrolytes in MS-SOFCs. Stabilized zirconia, doped ceria, bismuth oxides, and LSGM have been used as solid electrolytes [193]. 8YSZ films have been obtained by gas flow sputtering deposition and characterized to ensure a dense and defect-free electrolyte layer. MS-SOFCs comprising 8YSZ (2 µm of thickness) deposited on Ni/GDC active anode by gas flow sputtering showed 2500 mW·cm−2 at 0.7 V using H2/H2O at 700 °C [10].
