Bischof et al. investigated the impact of reducing the electrolyte layer thickness by the same technique to minimize the ohmic resistance of the cell. 8YSZ electrolyte with 2 µm of thickness exhibited higher current density compared to cell comprising 8YSZ electrolytes with 4 µm of thickness [183]. Researchers are engaged in the reduction of electrolyte layers in SOFCs, focusing on employing scale-up film deposition techniques to produce dense and defect-free electrolytes. These techniques include tape casting [178], spin coating [194], and various PVD methods such as PLD [193], atomic layer deposition (ALD) [193], magnetron sputtering (Msputt.) [10], and electron-beam physical vapor deposition (EB-PVD) [12]. The main goal is to enhance the SOFC performance and decrease the Top . by either the reduction of electrolyte thickness or the adoption of more conductive materials. These advanced fabrication techniques enable the creation of thin and dense electrolytes with superior properties, providing precise control over film thickness, microstructure, and composition, which is critical for optimizing ionic conductivity and minimizing the ohmic losses of the cell [195]. For instance, ALD allows for the deposition of ultra-thin electrolyte layers with atomic-scale precision, reducing diffusion pathways for ions and improving overall efficiency. PLD and Msputt. can create highly dense and defect-free electrolyte films, which enhances mechanical stability and prevent gas leakage, critical for long-term operation. Furthermore, these techniques enable the integration of novel electrolyte materials, such as composite and multi-layered structures, which can combine the benefits of high ionic conductivity with improved chemical and thermal stability [196]. By producing electrolytes with optimized thickness and density, these advanced fabrication methods directly contribute to the enhancement of MS-SOFC performance, durability, and operational efficiency [196]. Some of these highly conductive materials include doped ceria [125,126], lanthanum gallates [197], cubic scandium-stabilized zirconia [178,179] and doped barium-based cerates [28]. However, none of these electrolytes has matched the thermodynamic stability of YSZ electrolytes or achieved competitive commercial pricing [10,12,198]. Notably, companies like Ceres Power and research institutions such as Jülich GmbH have opted to enhance their cells using GDC and 8YSZ electrolytes, respectively, with thickness in the range of 20–5 µm [198]. Opakhai et al. reported recent developments associated with MS-SOFCs. The focus is on several materials used as electrolytes and how they influence the performance and durability of MS-SOFCs. A dense and gas-tight electrolyte is crucial to prevent the mixing of fuel and oxidant gases, which leads to lower OCVs and reduced performance. The challenge is ensuring that thin electrolyte layers maintain gas-tightness while remaining structurally during high-temperature operation. Among all electrolytes, YSZ is commonly used, but its limited ionic conductivity at lower temperatures and shrinkage during sintering processes are challenging issues. One of the issues in MS-SOFCs is the CTEs mismatch in the range of the PMS and ceramic electrolytes. For instance, YSZ has a CTE of ∼10 × 10−6 °C−1, whereas some FSS and all ASS tend to have higher CTEs (∼12–17 × 10−6 °C−1). This mismatch can lead to delamination or cracking during thermal cycling. Techniques like plasma spraying (PS) or co-sintering have been used to improve the electrolyte density, but even with these, achieving complete densification without compromising the structural integrity of the PMS remains a challenge. Wet/colloidal deposition and thin YSZ layers post-sintering can boost the electrolyte density, but these approaches introduce complexity in maintaining lower porosity and structural compatibility. As MS-SOFCs aim to operate in the range of 500–750 °C, the performance of traditional YSZ electrolytes diminishes, requiring the exploration of alternative materials such as GDC or scandia-stabilized zirconia (ScSZ). However, these alternatives come with its own challenges, such as electronic leakage or high cost. MS-SOFCs with YSZ electrolytes have shown power densities of ∼940 mW·cm−2 at 800 °C and ∼550 mW·cm−2 at 700 °C. These values are promising for mid-range temperatures, but performance decreases significantly as the operating temperature drops. OCV as high as 1.0 V is essential for efficient operation. Dense YSZ electrolytes have shown OCVs slightly above 1.0 V when H2 is used as fuel, indicating good gas-tightness under optimal conditions. However, maintaining these OCV levels consistently across varied temperatures remains a challenge [195]. Hui et al. reported the manufacturing of SOFC components by PS focusing on electrolytes. This method offers numerous advantages for MS-SOFCs, but it also presents several key challenges. While PS allows high-temperature processing, it is difficult to fabricate sufficiently dense electrolytes using single-step deposition methods. Atmospheric plasma spraying (APS) often results in porous microstructures with 5%–15% porosity, leading to lower OCVs and reduced cell efficiency due to microcracking propagation. Microcracks are a common issue during the PS process, resulting from inadequate particle melting, substrate temperature fluctuations, and other deposition parameters. These microcracks reduce the electrolytes effectiveness, as they create pathways for gas crossover, compromising the SOFCs performance. To address this, post-deposition treatments, such as spark plasma sintering or vacuum sintering, are sometimes necessary to densify the electrolytes, adding complexity to the process. Despite the challenges with porosity and microcracking, some cells achieved OCVs close to 1.0 V, particularly when optimizing post-deposition treatments to reduce defects. Although PS offers high deposition rates, achieving the desired electrolyte microstructure and thickness lower than 10 µm across large areas is challenging. This complexity increases when scaling up for industrial production. On the other hand, vacuum plasma spraying (VPS), while producing denser electrolytes, is significantly more expensive than APS. SOFCs manufactured by APS reached 770 mW·cm−2 at 900 °C and 430 mW·cm−2 at 800 °C when using H2 as the fuel and oxygen as the oxidant [199]. Coddet et al. reported on TS and PVD techniques for manufacturing SOFC electrolyte layers. These techniques are crucial for creating thin, dense, and gas-tight electrolyte layers of MS-SOFCs with high efficiency. The challenge is to produce dense and gas-tight electrolyte layers while maintaining a minimal thickness to reduce ohmic resistance. However, achieving full density in electrolyte layers using conventional TS techniques remains difficult. Porosity in plasma-sprayed electrolytes is a common issue, leading to gas leakage and lower performance. For instance, APS deposits often require post-treatments, such as microwave sintering, to reduce porosity. Another challenge is the formation of cracks and voids during the deposition process. These defects arise due to the high thermal stress involved in TS processes. As the electrolyte layer cools, cracks can form, leading to gas permeability. Coddet et al. emphasize that VPS can help reduce cracks by operating in a controlled environment but at higher costs. Another issue is the CTEs mismatch in the range of the PMs and ceramic electrolytes like YSZ. This mismatch can cause delamination and cracking during thermal cycling. Coddet et al. suggest the use of composite electrolyte layers or interlayers to mitigate this problem by introducing a graded transition in the range of the PMS and the ceramic electrolyte. Both TS and PVD technologies have limitations. While TS allows high deposition rates, the porosity and crack formation remain challenges. On the other hand, PVD offers better control over the deposition of thin, dense films but at significantly slower deposition rates, making it less feasible for large-scale production. Cells fabricated using TS and optimized deposition parameters have shown improved performance. For instance, YSZ electrolyte layers produced using low-pressure plasma spraying (LPPS) achieved power densities up to 500 mW·cm−2 at 800 °C and 0.7 V, which is a significant improvement compared to traditional APS methods. The OCV of cells with YSZ electrolytes typically reached values close to 0.95 V, which indicates good gas-tightness but still falls short of the ideal 1.0 V. Further densification and crack reduction are needed to consistently achieve higher OCVs [75]. Du et al. reported the use of APS as a cost-effective alternative compared to LPPS techniques. However, while APS shows promise, achieving consistent microstructural quality remains difficult, particularly in controlling porosity and crack formation. Key performance metrics for MS-SOFCs highlight the importance of fine-tuning deposition parameters. For instance, the optimal YSZ coating deposited at an 80 mm spraying distance shows a porosity of 3.56%, yielding a maximum power density of 902 mW·cm−2 at 900 °C. This value outperforms other configurations, but further work is needed to improve the OCV, which is still below the desired 1.0 V mark at 0.964 V for the best sample. The ohmic resistance of the optimized cell was measured at 0.10 Ω·cm2 at 900 °C, which is significantly lower than cells with greater porosity or more microcracks, indicating that the dense YSZ layer effectively reduced resistance [200]. Hermawan et al. reported on the densification of YSZ electrolytes deposited by APS and refined through chemical/electrochemical vapor deposition (CVD/EVD) techniques. The goal was to create a dense, gas-tight electrolyte suitable for MS-SOFCs, addressing key challenges in achieving an optimal electrolyte structure. The APS technique is known for its fast deposition rate, but it leaves behind residual pores and pinholes, which compromise gas-tightness. The initial N2 permeation flux through the APS-prepared YSZ layer was 1.8–2.7 × 10−7 mol·s−1·cm2 at 25 °C, indicating the presence of defects. These imperfections hinder the cell efficiency by allowing gas crossover in the range of the fuel and oxidant. The CVD/EVD process is used to refine the density and plug residual pores in the YSZ electrolyte. This method gradually fills the pores by depositing additional YSZ material, increasing the layer thickness by 4–7 µm, and ensuring gas-tight conditions after 5 h of deposition. Despite the slow deposition rate of 1.14 µm·h−1, CVD/EVD effectively addresses the shortcomings of the APS process. Achieving a homogenous, dense layer is crucial for MS-SOFC performance. The study found that the CVD/EVD process yielded a dominant cubic phase in the YSZ layer, but a small amount of a secondary phase (monoclinic) was also observed. This secondary phase may affect the long-term performance and stability of the electrolyte. It was confirmed that a combination of APS followed by CVD/EVD produced a gas-tight electrolyte. The YSZ thickness after refinement was around 24–27 µm, ensuring minimal gas permeation and higher operational efficiency. However, the process remains time-consuming due to the slow growth rates of CVD/EVD [201]. Marcano et al. reported the use of APS and plasma spray-physical vapor deposition PS-PVD for fabricating high-performance SOFCs, focusing on the development of a dense and gas-tight YSZ electrolyte. The authors used PS-PVD to deposit a 26 μm thick YSZ layer, optimizing the plasma spraying parameters to ensure gas-tightness. However, ensuring consistent gas-tightness across large areas remains a challenge, particularly when controlling variables such as plasma gas composition, spray distance, and powder feed rate. The deposition of the YSZ electrolyte using TS methods can cause bending due to thermal stresses, which affects the integrity of the electrolyte layer. Bending during deposition is difficult to avoid, but the authors showed that optimizing the spray distance and robot speed could minimize this effect, leading to better contact in the range of the PMS and the electrolyte layer. The study highlights the importance of optimizing deposition parameters. For instance, a spray distance of 800 mm and a plasma gas ratio of Ar/He = 5.5 was found to be optimal for producing a dense, gas-tight YSZ electrolyte. However, the use of different powder feed rates and carrier gas flow rates affected the porosity and thickness of the deposited layers, requiring fine-tuning for consistent results. Even with optimized conditions, the YSZ electrolyte exhibited 2% porosity and some unmolten particles. These small defects, although not significant enough to cause leakage, could potentially impact long-term performance. The MS-SOFCs with the optimized YSZ electrolyte achieved a power density of 1.125 W·cm−2 at 0.75 V and 870 °C, demonstrating excellent performance. The study shows that the power density increased with temperature, reaching over 1 A·cm−2 at 800 °C, a significant benchmark for high-performance cells. The OCV values were measured in the range of 1.021 V and 1.082 V for temperatures ranging from 611 °C to 870 °C, which is close to the theoretical value of 1.1 V, indicating good gas-tightness of the YSZ electrolyte [202]. Zhang et al. reported the fabrication of GDC electrolytes for MS-SOFCs using APS and VPS to evaluate the performance of the GDC electrolytes and compare the effectiveness of the two fabrication methods. The authors show that VPS produces denser GDC electrolytes than APS, with the VPS-deposited GDC showing fewer defects and better gas-tightness. The porosity of the APS-GDC electrolyte was approximately 8.5%, while the VPS-GDC had 5.4% porosity, which directly affects the electrochemical performance of the cells. The temperature and velocity of GDC particles during deposition play a crucial role in the film’s microstructure. In the APS process, particles were deposited in a liquid–solid state, leading to larger splat sizes and some cracks. In contrast, the VPS process, which involved gas–liquid deposition, resulted in smaller splat sizes and a denser structure. However, the high temperature in the VPS process accelerated the evaporation of CeO2, leading to a compositional shift in the GDC films, which must be considered in future applications. While VPS produced a more uniform and denser microstructure, vertical cracks were observed in both APS and VPS coatings. These cracks, while present, did not penetrate the entire electrolyte layer and did not result in direct gas crossover. The rapid cooling during deposition in both methods contributed to the crack formation, which remains a challenge for long-term performance. The authors found that during both APS and VPS processes, there was preferential evaporation of CeO2, which changed the Ce/Gd ratio in the deposited films. The atomic ratio of Ce to Gd in the VPS-GDC electrolyte shifted to 3.5 from the original 4.5, which could impact the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte. The VPS-cell achieved 175.7 mW·cm2 at 600 °C, while the APS-cell showed a lower MPD of 124.8 mW·cm2 at the same temperature. This difference highlights the superior performance of the VPS process in fabricating dense and efficient GDC electrolytes. The OCV of the VPS-cell was 0.90 V at 600 °C, higher than the APS-cells OCV of 0.86 V, indicating better gas-tightness and overall performance in the VPS-deposited electrolyte [203]. Haydn et al. have been reporting the development of multi-layer thin-film electrolytes for MS-SOFCs using PVD and gas-flow sputtering (GFS). The key focus is on improving electrolyte gas-tightness and performance by employing innovative multi-layer configurations. Single-layer electrolytes often suffer from columnar grain structures that can result in microscopic pathways for gas crossover. Haydn et al. addressed this by employing multi-layer structures (alternating oxide and metallic layers) to interrupt the columnar grain growth, significantly improving gas-tightness. These electrolytes, with two or eight layers, reduced leakage rates to less than 3 × 10−4 Pa·dm3·s−1·cm−2, meeting the required standards for high-performance SOFCs [198]. In another work, Haydn et al. reported for a single-layer electrolyte, the gas leakage rate of 1.57 × 10−2 Pa·dm3·s−1·cm−2, measured at room temperature. However, with the compound electrolyte (alternating Zr/Y and YSZ layers), the leakage rate improved to 2.9 × 10−2 Pa·dm3·s−1·cm−2, demonstrating the benefits of the layered structure in enhancing sealing. Electrochemical testing of the metal-supported cells with compound electrolytes showed impressive results, achieving OCV of 1.096 V, current densities above 2 A·cm−2 at 0.7 V and a power density of over 1400 mW·cm−2 at 850 °C. These high-power densities indicate the potential of the compound electrolyte structure for mobile SOFC applications [204]. Roehrens et al. reported a detailed study on MS-SOFCs thin-film electrolyte designed for lightweight and stationary stacks. The focus is on the performance of MS-SOFCs with thin YSZ electrolytes and the challenges encountered in their operation, particularly under mobile and stationary conditions. The YSZ layer, which is just 4 µm thick, must be dense enough to prevent gas-crossover while maintaining low resistance. The GFS method was used to deposit the YSZ electrolyte, but ensuring defect-free deposition over large areas remains a challenge. Another significant challenge is the CTEs mismatch in the range of the PMS and the ceramic electrolyte. The study uses GDC as a buffer layer to mitigate this issue, but the long-term stability of the buffer layer under varying thermal and chemical conditions poses a challenge, particularly due to cation interdiffusion in the range of the PMS and the ceramic layers. When scaling up from single-cell tests to stack configurations, there is a significant drop in performance. The authors reported a performance loss of 30% to 50% when comparing single-cell operation with stack performance, mainly due to gas transport limitations and contact resistances that arise in the stack configuration. This performance degradation is attributed to the larger cell sizes and differences in gas distribution compared to laboratory-scale single-cell experiments. Degradation of the cells during operation is another critical issue. After 43 h of operation, the study reports a degradation rate in the range of 4.15% and 8.31%, mainly due to interdiffusion in the range of the GDC and the PMS, leading to the formation of Cr/Fe oxide phases. This degradation reduces electrical performance and is a challenge for long-term durability. In single-cell tests, MS-SOFCs with thin YSZ electrolytes achieved power densities of approximately 1.0 W·cm−2 at 800 °C and 1.5 A·cm−2 at 0.8 V, which is comparable to SOFCs. However, in a lightweight two-layer stack, the power density dropped significantly, with a maximum of 300 mA·cm−2 at 0.8 V and 800 °C in the stack configuration. The OCV values were relatively high, with measurements of 1.011 V and 1.015 V for two cells in the stack at 750 °C, indicating good initial gas-tightness. However, internal leakages and degradation over time reduced the overall performance of the cells [205]. Xu et al. reported a review of recent advancements and challenges in the commercialization and industrial production of MS-SOFCs, specifically focusing on the electrolyte layers impact on overall cell performance and durability. Achieving a thin, dense electrolyte is a critical challenge for MS-SOFCs. The authors emphasize the importance of controlling electrolyte thickness, as this impacts ionic conductivity and gas leakage. Electrolyte layers, particularly YSZ and GDC, must be carefully fabricated to ensure gas-tightness, especially in reducing operational costs and improving overall performance. Achieving this balance is difficult, especially for scale-up production. One of the challenges in manufacturing MS-SOFCs is controlling the sintering temperature due to the PMS. The PMS tends to oxidize at high temperatures, and this affects the overall mechanical properties and electrochemical stability of the cell. Researchers have developed strategies to lower the sintering temperature, such as the introduction of additives like Fe2O3, which helps reduce the sintering temperature while ensuring adequate densification of the YSZ electrolyte. The CTE mismatch in the range of the ceramic electrolyte YSZ and the FSS or ASS PMSs poses a significant challenge. This mismatch can cause cracking or delamination during thermal cycling. While FSS alloys are widely used due to their relatively compatible CTE with YSZ, Cr poisoning and interfacial reactions in the range of the electrolyte and PMS remain issues that require attention. Xu et al. highlight the challenge of long-term stability for MS-SOFCs. Issues like Cr diffusion from the PMS into the electrolyte and electrode layers can cause degradation over time, reducing the cell performance. Mitigating this degradation is essential to ensure the longevity of MS-SOFCs under continuous operation. Optimized MS-SOFCs with thin-film YSZ or GDC electrolytes have demonstrated impressive power densities, such as 1.4 W·cm−2 at 850 °C. The use of GFS for electrolyte deposition further improves gas-tightness and power output. The study indicates that cells utilizing YSZ electrolytes have achieved OCV values around 1.01 V, reflecting good gas-tightness and minimal gas crossover. The introduction of additives to improve electrolyte performance is noted, but these also impact long-term stability, requiring careful balancing in the range of initial performance and degradation [32]. Sønderby et al. have reported the deposition of YSZ thin films using high power impulse magnetron sputtering (HiPIMS) and pulsed direct current magnetron sputtering (DCMS) for SOFC applications. The focus is on achieving dense, defect-free YSZ thin films suitable for MS-SOFCs while comparing the effectiveness of HiPIMS and pulsed DCMS techniques. A major challenge in the fabrication of YSZ electrolytes using Msputt. is the formation of columnar structures, which contain voids that lead to internal gas leakage. Films with such defects do not provide sufficient gas-tightness, reducing cell performance. This issue was observed when YSZ films were deposited using both pulsed DCMS and HiPIMS at a floating potential, resulting in a columnar structure regardless of the method used. The application of substrate bias voltage during deposition is crucial for improving film density. HiPIMS, in particular, showed promising results when a bias voltage of −25 V to −50 V was applied, as it disrupted columnar growth and produced dense films with a non-columnar microstructure. However, increasing the bias voltage beyond − 75 V introduced a new issue of film delamination and microcracking, highlighting the need to carefully optimize bias voltage to avoid excessive ion bombardment. While pulsed DCMS generally resulted in columnar films with voids at all bias levels, HiPIMS was able to produce dense, featureless films when the bias was set ranging from −25 V to −50 V. This improvement in film morphology is critical for MS-SOFC applications, as dense films without voids prevent gas crossover and enhance the durability of the electrolyte layer. Although dense, non-columnar films were achieved at specific bias voltages using HiPIMS, higher bias levels (e.g., −75 V) resulted in film delamination. This issue was attributed to the high stress induced by ion bombardment, leading to poor adhesion to the substrate. The stress levels must be controlled to balance density and adhesion, particularly for large-scale production [206,207]. Hagen et al. have been reporting on the robustness of metal-supported cells (MSCs) and anode-supported cells (ASCs) stacks under thermal cycling for mobile applications. The study explores the stacks’ ability to endure rapid temperature changes and thermal gradients, focusing on real-world operational conditions. One of the most critical challenges for MS-SOFCs is their robustness under thermal cycling, particularly in mobile applications where fast start-up and power modulation are needed. The authors subjected MSC and ASC stacks to thermal gradients of up to 30 °C·cm−1. The MSC stacks, with high thermal conductivity and mechanical robustness, performed better under these conditions compared to ASC stacks, which began to show degradation after several cycles. Maintaining gas-tightness during thermal cycling is another challenge. The study reports that the MSC stack maintained an OCV close to theoretical values even after multiple thermal cycles, indicating good gas-tightness. However, small leaks were observed in the ASC stack after several cycles, likely due to degradation in the sealing interfaces. While the MSC stack showed high robustness, there was still a 15% increase in area-specific resistance (ASR) after several thermal cycles, particularly after the first cycle. This increase in ASR was linked to contact issues in the range of the interconnects and the cells, as well as degradation in the electrode materials. The MSC stacks endured temperature differences of up to 300 °C in the range of different parts of the stack, corresponding to gradients of 30 °C·cm−1. These extreme conditions highlight the importance of high thermal conductivity in MSCs, which helps mitigate mechanical stress and prolongs the stacks lifespan. The MSC stack showed an OCV of 3.26 V at 690 °C, slightly lower than the theoretical value of 3.32 V. The slight decrease was attributed to the first thermal cycle, but the gas-tightness remained intact throughout the testing. The power density of the MSC stack remained stable after multiple thermal cycles. The stack was capable of maintaining its power output at 1.0 W·cm−2 under operational conditions, indicating high performance even under severe thermal stress [208]. In summary, YSZ is one of the most widely used electrolytes in MS-SOFCs due to its high ionic conductivity at elevated temperatures above 800 °C and its stability in both oxidizing and reducing environments. However, the ionic conductivity of YSZ significantly decreases at temperatures below 800 °C, which limits its efficiency in intermediate temperature applications requiring the use of very thin films to mitigate performance loss. However, depositions of thinner YSZ films can be challenging, requesting careful control over the deposition process [209,210]. Despite this drawback, YSZ remains the preferred electrolyte for high-temperature SOFCs due to its robust stability [210]. When YSZ is used as a thin film, it can significantly reduce ohmic losses, making it a good candidate for lower operating temperatures around 600 °C [209,211]. YSZ-based SOFCs typically produce power densities in the range of 200–650 mW·cm−2, depending on the operating temperature and deposition technique used. For example, YSZ films deposited by EB-PVD technique can achieve a power density of up to 650 mW·cm−2 at 700 °C [210]. GDC exhibits much higher ionic conductivity than YSZ at intermediate temperatures (500–700 °C). However, GDC is susceptible to reduction under reducing atmospheres, which increases its electronic conductivity and leads to lower OCV and long-term stability [209,211]. This chemical reduction from Ce+4 to Ce+3 introduces challenges in achieving high efficiency and requires DBLs to mitigate these effects. Therefore, it is often coupled with a protective layer of YSZ to prevent excessive electronic conductivity [212]. Moreover, the performance of GDC electrolytes also depends heavily on the deposition technique, with plasma-sprayed GDC sometimes showing porosity [211]. GDC-based MS-SOFCs typically demonstrate power densities ranging from 200 to 500 mW·cm−2. For instance, plasma-sprayed GDC achieved 386 mW·cm−2 at 700 °C, with an OCV of 0.75 V [211]. The reduction of electrolyte layer thickness represents one of the most critical breakthroughs in the development of micro-tubular solid oxide fuel cells (MS-SOFCs) [32]. For optimal performance, the electrolyte must maintain a thickness in the range of 3–5 μm to ensure the gas-tightness of the cell, effectively separating the anode and cathode and preventing cross-leakage of fuel and oxidants. Achieving such thin layers is crucial, as it significantly reduces the ionic resistance across the electrolyte, leading to enhanced power output and overall cell efficiency [213]. This performance enhancement has been extensively demonstrated in the literature, where thinner electrolytes contribute to lower ohmic losses and improved electrochemical performance, particularly at lower operating temperatures, which is a key goal for next-generation SOFCs [214–217]. To achieve these ultra-thin, defect-free electrolyte layers, advanced fabrication techniques have been developed, focusing primarily on vapor deposition methods. Both PVD and CVD have emerged as highly effective approaches [215,217]. PVD techniques, such as sputtering and thermal evaporation, allow for precise control over layer thickness and uniformity, while CVD processes, including ALD and PS offer the advantage of conformal coatings even on complex geometries [215,217]. These methods not only enable the fabrication of thin, dense electrolytes but also contribute to the scalability and reproducibility of MS-SOFC manufacturing [10]. APS is widely used for depositing YSZ layers due to its scalability and flexibility. However, the deposited layers often show some microcracks and porosity, which requires post-treatment or impregnation to ensure gas-tightness [209,211]. Power densities for APS-deposited YSZ typically range in the range of 200–386 mW·cm−2 [209]. When APS is used for GDC, it avoids the need for high-temperature sintering, which helps maintain better interface integrity with metal supports. However, achieving fully dense coatings remains challenging [211]. GDC’s high ionic conductivity makes it a promising material for MS-SOFCs, despite that achieving gas-tight coatings often requires optimized deposition parameters [211]. The microstructure of YSZ and GDC layers deposited by APS are prone to have voids and microcracks. However, these defects can be reduced by optimizing spraying parameters. For instance, GDC layers sprayed at 80 mm show improved density and fewer cracks compared to other configurations [211]. Very Low-Pressure Plasma Spraying (VLPPS) is a newer plasma spraying method that allows the deposition of very thin YSZ layers (<5 μm). This method helps reduce porosity compared to conventional APS, leading to improved gas-tightness [209]. VLPPS can produce thin layers while maintaining high deposition efficiency. VLPPS-deposited YSZ layers have fewer microcracks and voids compared to APS, making it a more promising technique for creating highly dense, thin electrolyte layers [209]. PLD is a PVD technique that allows precise control over the thickness and composition of the electrolyte layers, making it ideal for producing dense, crack-free YSZ films [216]. PLD-deposited YSZ layers are typically much thinner than those produced by APS, which helps reduce ohmic losses and improve overall performance [216]. PLD is also highly effective in manufacturing thin and highly conductive GDC electrolyte layers. This technique is often used to create uniform and dense bilayers, such as ScSZ/SDC to mitigate chemical reduction-related issues in GDC [216]. These bilayers improve both conductivity and stability in MS-SOFCs. Bi-layered electrolytes formed by PLD show excellent gas-tightness, and their uniform microstructure helps improve performance at lower temperatures [216]. EB-PVD is known for producing thin, dense YSZ films that exhibit good adhesion and minimal cracks [210]. This method achieves high power densities due to the dense and uniform nature of the films. EB-PVD has demonstrated power densities of up to 650 mW·cm−2 at 700 °C [210]. EB-PVD YSZ layers are typically free of significant defects, which ensures excellent gas-tightness and long-term stability [210]. Table 2 depicts the architecture of different MS-SOFCs alongside performance data on the presence or absence of defects in the electrolyte and the main conclusions based on different electrolyte depositions by PVD and PS techniques. 4.4 Cathodes for MS-SOFC LSM-based cathodes exhibit lower stability in temperatures in the range of 550–750 °C. The presence of lanthanum (La) in LSM leads to La diffusion toward the YSZ electrolyte interface, resulting in the precipitation of La2Zr2O7 pyrochlore phases that obstruct the transport of ionic charge carriers. In contrast, LSC, LSCF, SSC, and BSCF cathodes demonstrate higher thermodynamic stability, exhibit robustness in reducing atmospheres, good oxygen electroactivity, are MIECs, and present suitable particle size and distribution. These cathodes are typically applied on 8YSZ electrolytes by methods like screen printing or airbrushing, followed by ex situ or in situ drying and sintering [17,153,221–223]. These cathodes allow MS-SOFCs to be sintered at Tsint . = 950 °C in argon or reducing atmospheres, preventing cathode degradation and PMS oxidation. The primary disadvantages include: (i) YSZ CTEs mismatch, leading to crack nucleation and propagation, causing component delamination under cycling; (ii) the high Top . also induces cathode coarsening, and similar anode strategies are employed to mitigate this issue; and (iii) Cr volatilization from ICs, which reacts with O2 moisture stream, resulting in the precipitation of CrO(OH)x in the cathode-IC interface. These precipitates undergo dehydration at the Top ., generating Cr2O3 scales that block the charge carriers [224–226]. To promote efficient oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and prevent O2− deficiency towards the TPBs for fuel electro-oxidation, composite and MIECs cathodes must possess a high TPBs density and active surface area, respectively. The cathode materials must exhibit the following characteristics: (i) high TPBs density and active surface area with a high concentration of acid sites in the range of 550–750 °C and high PP O 2 operation range, i.e., electrolytic domain; (ii) CTEs matching with DBL and IC materials; (iii) resistance to thermal shock and thermal cycling; (iv) chemical-structural stability to prevent degradation and undesired oxide segregation [227]. The cathode is sintered to achieve the desired phases and morphology, either using in situ techniques during MS-SOFC sealing or ex situ techniques. The main challenge lies in depositing the cathode followed by stabilizing the crystalline structure. Typically, the PMS, anode, and electrolyte are sintered in a reducing atmosphere to prevent oxidation of the PMS stainless steel. Subsequently, the cathode is ex situ sintered at temperatures in the range of 900–1100 °C and 1–3 h in the ambient atmosphere, while the other MS-SOFC components are maintained in a reducing atmosphere. Therefore, in situ sintering at the Top . is the ideal technique to activate the cathodes crystalline structure and its adhesion to the DBL/electrolyte interface. In situ sintering reduces process costs while the anode and PMS remain in a reducing atmosphere, preventing oxidation. Recently, novel cathode materials for MS-SOFCs, including La2NiO4+δ (LNO), Pr2NiO4+δ (PNO), and La2-xPrxNiO4+δ (LPNO) have been synthesized and characterized to ensure stability in reducing atmospheres and high electrocatalytic activity. LPNO cathodes with stoichiometry x < 0.5 exhibited good structural stability, while those with 0.5 < x < 1.0 demonstrated higher power density but lower structural stability. These Ni-based cathodes are oxygen-saturated above 1000 °C and possess the following characteristics: (i) good electrical conductivity; (ii) CTE matching in the range of the electrolyte, DBL, and ICs; (iii) excellent charge exchange coefficients and O2− diffusibility. However, no long-term performance tests have been conducted [228]. LaNi0.60Fe0.40O3-δ (LNF) cathodes have been used due the lower reactivity with Cr from IC compared to LSM and LSCF cathodes [229,230]. As discussed earlier, one strategy to mitigate Cr poisoning involves the deposition of Co, CoOx, Co2Mn0.5Al0.5O4 or CuMn2O4 DBLs on the cathode using ALD preventing undesired chemical reactions at the cathode-IC interface [178]. Composite cathodes, consisting of LSCF and Cgraphite, were applied through plasma spray (PS) over 10 mol% Sm2O3-doped CeO2 (10SDC) DBL. This DBL effectively prevents the occurrence of charge carrier-blocking phases at the electrolyte/cathode interface resulting in area-specific resistance (ASR) values as low as 62 mΩ·cm2 [231]. BSCF-based cathodes, when sintered below 700 °C on 10GDC DBLs in MS-SOFCs supported by 430L FSS, have demonstrated the capability to supply a Ppeak = 740 mW·cm−2 [232]. Shi et al. have reported BSCF as an efficient cathode material when combined with GDC for intermediate-temperature SOFCs [193]. BSCF shows good catalytic activity for the ORR and performs well with GDC due to similar CTEs. Cathodes based on Nb5+ and Ta5+-doped SrCoO3 exhibit low activation polarization, while partially crystalline LSC-based cathodes can provide 200 < Ppeak (mW·cm−2) < 260 at 400 < Top . (°C) < 450 range [233–235]. LNBL researchers have been manufacturing cathodes through catalyst infiltration/impregnation into YSZ scaffold structures [11]. Other researchers have similarly produced symmetric electrodes of SrFe0.75Mo0.25O3-δ (SFMO) through catalyst infiltration/impregnation into YSZ scaffold structures previously deposited on YSZ electrolyte (20 µm of thickness) over FSS 430L support. After the infiltration process, all layers were sintered in an H2 reducing atmosphere. These MS-SOFCs reached 400 mW·cm−2 at 700 °C using H2/H2O [175]. The success of MS-SOFCs also stems from the utilization of high-performance thin cathodes made of LSC and LSCF. These cathodes are deposited on the electrolyte DBL by screen printing, drying, and sintering. This method yields power and current densities in the range of 1000–2000 mW·cm−2 and 1400–2800 mA·cm−2 at 0.7 V and 650 °C using H2 as fuel. The notable performance of these MS-SOFCs can be attributed to the low TPBs cathode polarizability and the minimal tortuosity of Ni/10GDC nanoparticles of the active anode. This anode microstructure contributes to low electrochemical impedance, with the Ni phase promoting electron long-range transport, and both Ni and 10GDC particles aiding the H2 electro-oxidation [10,183,198]. The early discussion depicts various cathode materials used in MS-SOFCs comprising YSZ electrolytes. It is important to address cathode materials that are compatible with GDC as these materials have been used as DBLs highlighting the importance of its properties, such as CTEs match and mechanical and chemical stability. LSCF is an MIEC perovskite cathode material for MS-SOFCs. It is commonly used in conjunction with GDC as a DBL to avoid undesirable reactions with the YSZ electrolyte and improve stability and performance. The combination of LSCF with GDC allows better integration, as GDC acts as a buffer to prevent detrimental interactions with the electrolyte at high temperatures. LSCF is recognized for its lower polarization resistance and high oxygen exchange rates, making it suitable for use in MS-SOFCs [195]. La0.8Sr0.2Co0.4Mn0.6O3-δ (LSCM) is a perovskite-type material which offers a balancing of the properties necessary for interaction with GDC DBLS or electrolytes. Higher Co content can increase the risk of reactions with the GDC or YSZ electrolyte, leading to a mismatch in the CTEs. LSM is not ideal for direct use with GDC due to high sintering temperatures, LSM is often combined with GDC as a composite material to improve the number of reaction sites and enhance oxygen diffusion [195]. Opakhai et al. reported a polarization resistivity of 1.8 Ω·cm2 for LSM-YSZ composite cathodes, whereas LSCF cathodes showed significantly lower resistivity of 0.4 Ω·cm2 at 850 °C in MS-SOFCs containing GDC as DBL. A thin magnetron-sputtered GDC DBL was used to block reactions in the range of the cathode materials and the electrolyte. This DBL enhances the long-term stability of the cell and prevents degradation of the cathode. The use of LSCF with a GDC DBL achieved 650 mW·cm−2 at 800 °C when powered with H2 [195]. Sm0.5Sr0.5CoO3 (SSC) cathode, when combined with GDC, exhibits low polarization resistance and enhanced catalytic activity, especially at lower temperatures. SSC-based cells have achieved excellent electrochemical performance when paired with GDC electrolytes in bilayer configurations. SrFe0.9Nb0.1O3-δ (SFN) material is a promising cathode compatible with GDC. SrFe0.75Mo0.25O3-δ (SFMO) has shown good compatibility with GDC electrolytes in MS-SOFC configurations. SFMO-GDC composites offer favorable electrochemical performance in MS-SOFCs [32,236]. Xu et al. reported the use of LSCF with a GDC electrolyte layer, which achieves 1.25 W·cm−2 at 800 °C when powered by H2. While SSC-GDC systems have demonstrated 3.03 W·cm−2 at 700 °C, illustrating strong performance in high-temperature ranges. The LSCF and SSC cathodes maintained OCV values above 0.9 V, which is crucial for ensuring the efficiency of the MS-SOFC systems. The current density was as high as 2.8 A·cm−2 at 650 °C and 0.7 V [32]. Singh et al. have reported MS-SOFCs using LSCF-GDC systems. These cells achieved power densities as high as 1.2 W·cm−2 at 700 °C and BSCF-GDC systems have shown 0.65 W·cm−2 at 600 °C when powered by H2. These performance figures indicate the effectiveness of GDC as a DBL for these cathode materials in MS-SOFCs. GDC-based cathodes in MS-SOFCs typically achieve OCV values above 0.9 V, ensuring high efficiency and reduced leakage. The LSCF-GDC combinations perform especially well, maintaining a stable OCV throughout the extended operation. MS-SOFCs using LSM-GDC cathodes have demonstrated current densities as high as 0.75 A·cm−2 at 650 °C [237]. Wehrle et al. reported the potential of MS-SOFCs in the mobility sector. It focuses on optimizing cell materials and designs to enhance performance metrics like power density and efficiency. The authors highlight LSCF as a promising cathode material for use with GDC in MS-SOFCs. LSCFs compatibility with GDC stems from its MIEC, which boosts ORR efficiency. When paired with GDC, it forms a composite material with low polarization resistance, leading to enhanced cell performance. LSCF is frequently combined with GDC in MS-SOFC designs to optimize ionic conductivity while maintaining good mechanical and chemical compatibility with other components in the cell. This combination is advantageous for lowering the operating temperature while maintaining high electrochemical activity, especially in mobile applications [238]. Wehrle et al. reported a Ni-fiber GDC anode coupled with an LSCF-GDC cathode, which achieved 3.13 W·cm−2 at 850 °C and 0.7 V, a significant improvement over commercial standard. Additionally, the same authors report stack power densities as high as 1.85 kW·L−1 at operating temperatures below 700 °C. The OCV for the optimized LSCF-CGO cathode system reaches 0.92 V, which is the expected range for a high-efficiency SOFC system [238]. 4.5 PMSs for MS-SOFCs The architecture of the MS-SOFCs comprises multiple layers, as detailed earlier. Each layer plays a crucial role, and it is essential to comprehend individual functions. As the acronym implies, the PMS is the support of the ceramic films. PMSs should exhibit the following characteristics: (i) porosity to facilitate the diffusion of gaseous reactants and products; (ii) mechanical resilience to be used as support; (iii) CTEs match with the other components; (iv) oxidation and degradation resistances under low PP O 2 , as well as in the presence of H2, H2O and O2 atmospheres; and (v) cost-effectiveness [11]. The commonly employed PMS is porous stainless steel typically prepared through powder metallurgy by tape casting. However, this technique lacks control over the metallic suspension rheological properties and process parameters, resulting in the production of irregularly shaped pores with small sintered necks in the range of the PMS particles. These sintered particles are susceptible to oxidation due to the high surface energy. To address this issue, a thin layer of an electronic conductor such as LaCrO3 can be deposited on the surface of the pores by dip coating (DCoat), enhancing the oxidation resistance. Nevertheless, similar to spinel-based DBLs, the deposition process is not uniform requiring optimization [239–242]. 430, 441, and Crofer 22APU FSS alloys with different Cr amounts, exhibit CTEs in the range of 10 × 10−6–12 × 10−6 °C−1, close to the CTEs of 8YSZ and 10GDC ceramics. In addition to these characteristics, PMSs also should have a foam/mesh morphology or can be thin sheets micro-drilled by laser. Several manufacturing techniques are available for PMS conformation, including powder metallurgy by uniaxial pressing with a binder (pelletizing), spray pyrolysis, electrospray, tape casting of metallic suspensions, and even 3D printing [243]. The characterization of the PMSs includes: (i) mass gain (mg·cm−2) and (ii) ASR measurement by the 4-point probe in direct current (mΩ·cm2), both by exposure to high oxidation temperatures; (iii) mechanical strength evaluation under creep; (iv) CTEs assessment; (iv) thermodynamic stability in long-term at the Top . and (v) data survey of Cr diffusion and evaporation. For ASR analysis, samples undergo oxidation in air at the Top . to promote Cr2O3 scale growth. FSS Crofer 22APU (ThyssenKrupp) and ITM (Plansee SE) PMSs alloys exhibit ASRs of 5 and 2.5 mΩ·cm2. Following, the LSM DBL deposition on FSS ITM alloy can reduce the ASR down to 1.0 mΩ·cm2 [240]. PMSs with 40% of porosity have been oxidized in an atmosphere containing 50 vol% H2 in H2O at 800 °C. The growth of oxide thickness was examined using scanning electron microscope (SEM) image processing and software analysis. Fig. 11 illustrates the evolution of polished PMS cross-sections over time. SEM image analysis revealed a substantial increase in the oxide layer after 2,500 h [244]. Reisert et al. provided insights into the oxidation behavior of P434L FSS alloys employed as PMSs in MS-SOFCs under anodic and cathodic atmospheres in the range of 600–800 °C. Notably, significant oxidation initiates at 600 °C in both moisture air and H2, characterized by a high oxidation rate and pore filling by reaction products. The study includes oxidation data recorded for samples post-sintering and those subjected to pre-oxidation. Pre-oxidation is a method for establishing a passivating Cr2O3 film, which proved effective in mitigating the oxidation rate over long-term [245]. In the case of pre-oxidized samples, the oxidation rate in air surpassed that in atmospheres with moisture H2 above 700 °C. To address oxidation challenges, coatings of Pr7O11, LSCF-SDC, and Ni-SDC oxides were applied to the P434L alloy. The oxidation behavior in the absence and presence of carbon under anodic atmospheres remained comparable for the pristine P434L alloy, regardless of the type of coating. Additionally, the introduction of CH4, CO2, and CO to humidified H2, simulating biogas and reformed bioethanol, did not exert a severe impact on oxidation behavior. Furthermore, the evaporation of Cr in air, especially in the presence of H2O vapor, undergoes a significant reduction with Pr7O11 coating, attributed to the precipitation of a passivating layer of PrCrO3 [245]. Reisert et al. also observed the formation of a dense and protective chromia (Cr2O3) scale on the P434L alloy under all investigated oxidation conditions. Another oxide layer rich in silica (SiO2) was also identified at the interface in the range of the alloy and the chromia scale. For the pre-oxidized alloy, the oxidation rate in humidified H2 at 700 °C was comparable to the oxidation rate for the non-pre-oxidized alloy at 600 °C. However, at higher temperatures the oxidation rate significantly increased in air. In contrast, the alloy with a Ni-SDC coating exhibited a moderate reduction in the oxidation rate in humidified H2. Coatings of LSCF-SDC and Pr7O11 did not significantly impact the oxide scale generated in air, but a substantial mass increase was observed and correlated with the chemical reaction in the range of CrO(OH)x and the coating film [245]. Few research has focused on the integration of PMSs with catalysts for direct hydrocarbon and biofuel reforming. Zhou et al. reported the co-lamination of 430L FSS (300 μm of thickness) and YSZ electrolyte (30 μm of thickness) scaffolds by tape casting. 10 vol%Ni catalyst was infiltrated in the PMS scaffolds, while 30 vol%LSFC cathode (45 μm of thickness) was infiltrated in the YSZ scaffold previously deposited on the YSZ electrolyte. MS-SOFCs with an active area of 0.35 cm2 powered by 3 vol% H2O in H2 provided 420–910 mW·cm−2 in the range of 700–900 °C [174]. Li et al. reported MS-SOFCs with Ni0.9Fe0.1 PMS impregnated with 0–4 wt% NiTiO3, aiming to assess electrochemical performance and CH4 steam reforming. NiTiO3 underwent a reduction in H2 at 650 °C ex-solving Ni nanoparticles on the TiO2 surface. Compositions with 3 wt% NiTiO3 showed higher electrocatalytic activity for CH4 steam reforming, resistance to coking, and good electrochemical performance. Under a flow of 97 vol% CH4 and 3 vol% H2O at a rate of 100 mL·min−1, the cell with 3 wt% NiTiO3 exhibited 1200 mW·cm−2 in a limiting current density of 2830 mA·cm−2 at 650 °C. These cells maintained an almost constant operating potential of 0.70 V at 400 mA·cm−2 during 96 h of long-term testing without coking. The presence of Ni nanoparticles on the TiO2 surface in the PMS reduced the polarization resistance due to catalytic steam pre-reforming of CH4 besides enhancing the gas diffusion in both PMS and the functional anode [246]. The Ni0.9Fe0.1 PMSs (1 mm of thickness) were fabricated by tape casting. A ceramic suspension was prepared by ball milling NiO and Fe2O3 powders in a molar ratio of 9:1 with fish oil as deflocculant, corn starch as pore former, PVB as a binder, and butyl benzyl phthalate and polyalkylene glycol as plasticizers in a xylene/ethanol mixture for 24 h. This suspension was tape casted and used to manufacture PMS samples with 25 mm of diameter. The functional NiO/10GDC anode (10 and the GDC electrolyte (each one with 10 μm of thickness)) were deposited on these samples by screen printing, followed by co-sintering at 1450 °C for 5 h in ambient atmosphere. After that, La0.80Sr0.20MnO3-δ-Ba0.50Sr0.50Co0.80Fe0.20O3-δ cathode (LSM-BSCF, 10 μm of thickness) was screen printed on the electrolyte and sintered at 1050 °C for 2 h in ambient atmosphere [246]. An aqueous solution containing Ti and Ni in the stoichiometric concentration of NiTiO3 phase was prepared using tetrabutyl titanate (C16H36O4Ti), HNO3, and Ni(NO3)2-6H2O. CA and EDTA chelating agents were added with a molar ratio of cations:CA:EDTA of 1:1:1.5. Ammonia solution was used to maintain the pH of the precursor solution neutral. This solution was infiltrated into the pores of the PMS NiO/Fe2O3 scaffold and calcined at 1000 °C for 2 h in ambient atmosphere to precipitate the NiTiO3 nanoparticles [246]. The OCV for all MS-SOFCs was 0.78 V, attributed to the current leakage of electronic carriers across the GDC electrolyte bulk. During long-term tests up to 96 h, the degradation rate of MS-SOFCs at 400 mA·cm−2 and 0.70 V was remarkably low, measuring only 0.50 mV·h−1. According to Li et al., the incorporation of TiO2 enhances the catalytic activity of CH4 reforming by increasing the H2O absorption for carbon oxidation by reducing coking. This effect is attributed to the presence of V O ∙ ∙ and interstitial Ti defects on the surface of the TiO2 nanoparticles in a reducing atmosphere [246]. 4.6 DBLs for MS-SOFCs Despite the remarkable architecture, effective materials processing, advanced deposition techniques, in situ sintering to mitigate PMS oxidation and prevent cathode degradation, signs of PMS and Ni anode oxidation persist beyond cathode degradation near the DBL interfaces despite of the high MS-SOFCs performance. The diffusion, evaporation, and precipitation of Fe and Cr from the PMS on the Ni particles in the anode lead to the formation of insulating oxides such as NiCr2O4 and Fe2O3. Cr2O3 scale formation is commonly observed on FSS and ASS particles. This phenomenon is intensified near the PMS sinter necks in the range of tiny particles. Ni from the anode also diffuses, evaporates, and precipitates on the surface of FSS PMS particles, triggering an FSS → ASS phase transition [247]. Despite the better oxidation resistance of ASS, the CTEASS = 17.3 × 10−6 °C−1 is higher than CTEFSS = 11.2 × 10−6 °C−1. This phase transition results in interface delamination and mechanical failure since the CTENi/8YSZ = 12 × 10−6 °C−1 and CTE8YSZ = 14 × 10−6 °C−1 in the range of 300–900 °C are different from the ASS PMS CTE [150]. These issues contribute to the long-term drop in MS-SOFCs performance, due to failures in the deposition of the DBL on PMS. One strategy to address this issue involves the deposition of Co-Mn or Cu-Mn on the PMS by PVD to form Co2Mn0.50Al0.50O4 and CuMn2O4 spinel DBLs which are electronic conductors. Subsequently, LSM or LSC contact layer is applied to prevent the inter-diffusion of Co and Mn to the Ni anode. However, this DBL technology is relatively recent and requires further optimization [248,249]. DBLs deposited from precursor salts of ethylene glycol, HNO3, La3+, Y3+, and Ce4+ by DCoat of sol–gel on FSS are typically prepared by drying and calcination at 400 °C and 650 °C to form Ce1-x(LayY1-y)xO2-δ oxides. These DBLs exhibit favorable electronic conductivity and excellent diffusion barrier properties [250]. Sønderby et al. reported the use of magnetron-sputtered GDC as a DBL in MS-SOFCs. The GDC is designed to prevent the diffusion of strontium (Sr) from the cathode into the electrolyte, which degrades cell performance by forming insulating SrZrO3 phases. A significant challenge is the migration of Sr from the cathode to the electrolyte, particularly during operation at intermediate temperatures. GDC layers deposited by Msputt. can effectively block Sr diffusion, but this depends on deposition parameters like temperature, substrate bias, and film thickness. Poorly controlled deposition leads to under dense column boundaries, which act as diffusion pathways for Sr. The density of the GDC DBL is critical for preventing Sr diffusion. The study shows that by tuning substrate bias voltage and deposition temperature, denser GDC films can be produced. Films deposited at lower bias voltages (e.g., floating potential) had an open, columnar structure that allowed Sr diffusion, whereas films grown under −50 V or −110 V bias were significantly denser and more effective as DBLs. Thermal expansion mismatch in the range of the GDC and the PMS is another concern. The GDC layers are deposited below 400 °C to prevent oxidation of the PMS. However, heat treatments (like cathode sintering) can release compressive stress in the GDC layers, leading to grain coarsening and potential performance degradation. The study highlights that cell with denser GDC DBLs achieved lower ASR values, indicating better overall performance. For example, a GDC film deposited at −50 V bias voltage yielded an ASR of 0.34 Ω·cm2 at 650 °C, while a less dense film deposited at floating potential had a higher ASR of 0.43 Ω·cm2. The cells tested showed excellent gas-tightness, with OCV values of 1.12 V at 650 °C, which is close to the theoretical OCV of 1.11 V. This indicates that the GDC barriers effectively prevented gas leakage in the tested cells [207]. 4.7 ICs and sealants for MS-SOFCs FSS and ASS alloys are used in MS-SOFCs as dense ICs enhancing the welding of the PMS plus the SOFC ceramic films to the IC [251]. ICs play a crucial role in MS-SOFCs as they facilitate electrical current collection, channeling the gases across the electrodes, and enable the assemble of MS-SOFCs in stacks through micro-welding by laser to ensure tightness while increasing power and electrical voltages. The most used IC material is based on Fe16Cr FSS. However, a drawback of this alloy is the evaporation of Cr and its deposition on the electrodes, leading to the formation of insulating oxide phases, which hinder electron transport. To mitigate this effect, Mn-Co spinels and LSM perovskite oxides are deposited over the ICs by PVD or APS to inhibit Cr volatilization. These spinels exhibit σ total of 60 S·cm−1 at 800 °C and CTEs of ∼9.7 × 10−6 °C−1, closely matching the CTEs of FSS alloys, 8YSZ, and 10GDC [240,252]. Companies like Sandvik Materials Technology manufacture large-scale stainless-steel alloys coated with Co-Ce alloy with 800 nm of thickness to be used as ICs in MS-SOFCs. Recently, some researchers have replicated this large-scale process by depositing a dense layer of Co with 600 nm of thickness on the surface of the cathode FSS ICs. During MS-SOFC stack operation, the Co undergoes oxidation to form Co3O4 on the surface of the cathode FSS ICs [253]. This oxide reacts with the Mn from cathode FSS ICs, creating a (CoxMny)3O4 thin spinel layer, which prevents Cr evaporation and diffusion up to 3000 h of long-term testing at 850 °C [254]. Despite the CTE mismatch with ceramic films, NiCrAlY and Hastelloy ICs exhibit high oxidation resistance [11]. However, these alloys are skyrocket expensive. For example, the powder costs for FSS 410 (USD 113.00/kg) and ASS 316 (USD 268.00/kg) are more economical than Hastelloy (USD 774.69/kg), NiCrAlY (USD 6,750.00/kg) alloys, and Ni 99.5% (USD 6,734.28/kg) powders. In comparison, the ceramic powders 8YSZ and 10GDC have costs of USD 147.10/kg and USD 1,810.00/kg, respectively. It is noteworthy that ongoing factors such as the pandemic, the conflict in Ukraine, and new contracts with BEV companies like TESLA contribute to constant instabilities in these product values. In conjunction with the laser micro-welding of ICs and MS-SOFCs stack assembly, mica-type phyllosilicates (SiO2-Al2O3-K2O-Na2O-Fe2O3) and Al2O3-SiO2 felts or glass sealants are employed. These sealants, originally utilized in HT-SOFCs and IT-SOFCs, undergo a significant reduction in application due to the scaled-up ICs laser sealing process of MS-SOFCs manufacturing. They are strategically placed in proximity to the gas inlet and outlet areas to ensure tightness [253]. 4.8 Key thoughts on MS-SOFCs powered by hydrocarbons and biofuels The stability and efficient performance of MS-SOFCs in long-term operation can be attributed to the DBLs, which mitigate the degradation of the cell under Top . < 750 °C compared to HT-SOFCs and IT-SOFCs. These DBLs contribute to maintaining the MS-SOFCs performance at lower operating temperatures while still enabling direct biofuels reforming. Lower operating temperatures also enable the application of lower-cost materials such as PMSs, ICs, and current collectors based on FSS alloys besides the cost-effective sealing of these materials by micro-welding laser. However, despite the cost-effectiveness and favorable properties of the FSS alloys, even below the austenitic transition (Ttrans . ≅ 1200 °C) and melting (Tmelt. ≅ 1450 °C) temperatures, diffusion of Fe and Cr into the anode still occurs poisoning it [255]. DBLs can be deposited using various PVD techniques such as ALD, APS, PLD, MSputt., radio-frequency sputtering (RFSputt.), or EB-PVD [55]. These layers must be dense and uniform in thickness without cracks, pores, pinholes and should exhibit excellent CTE match with the cell components [251,256]. 10GDC (CTE10GDC ≅ 12 × 10−6 °C−1) and 10SDC DBLs can be deposited over the PMS and the electrolyte [231,256–259]. Cr2O3 and Cr2MnO4 have been used as DBLs over PMSs based on Ni-Al alloys [259,260]. Co, CoOx, or CuMn2O4 DBLs are deposited over the dense ICs of the cathodes [231,261]. The degradation mechanisms of MS-SOFCs powered by H2 and CH4 have been recently investigated. However, there is a notable gap in studies regarding MS-SOFCs powered by C2H5OH. Additionally, potential new degradation mechanisms, including coking, remain unexplored [17]. Liu et al. developed catalyst nanocomposites to be used as a pre-catalytic layer for CH4 in MS-SOFCs. The main objective of the study was to demonstrate the feasibility of using MS-SOFCs operating with CH4 to generate power within a vehicle as depicted in Fig. 12 (a). Fig. 12(b) depicts the developed MS-SOFC with the pre-catalytic layer. The MS-SOFC achieved 350 mW·cm−2 at 600 °C when operating with CH4 as shown in Fig. 12(c). The catalysts were characterized by HAADF and EDS, which showed uniformity of the chemical elements as depicted in Fig. 12(d). Fig. 12(e) compares the power density of the MS-SOFCs powered by CH4 against the pristine versions. The results indicate a significant improvement in power density for the optimized cells, highlighting the effectiveness of the pre-catalyst layer in enhancing the internal SMR activity. Fig. 12(f) illustrates the long-term durability results showing stability and performance up to 1000 h of operation. In contrast, the pristine cells exhibit rapid performance decline, underscoring the importance of the catalyst layer in enhancing durability and coking resistance. Fig. 12(g) illustrates the CH4 conversion rates as a function of applied current density with other MS-SOFC. The MS-SOFCs powered by CH4 demonstrate significantly higher conversion rates compared to the pristine cells, indicating that the catalyst layer effectively promotes CH4 reforming. Fig. 12(h) shows the CO2/CO ratio in the anode outlet gas stream, which is an important indicator of the reforming process. A higher CO2/CO ratio suggests the reforming reaction is proceeding efficiently, producing more CO2 relative to CO, which is desirable for reducing coking and enhancing overall efficiency. Long-term test stability results, confirming the MS-SOFCs powered by CH4 maintain performance over extended operation up to 1000 h as depicted in Fig. 12(i). The degradation rate is minimal, indicating the pre-catalyst layer not only enhances performance but also contributes to the lifespan by preventing coking and other degradation mechanisms [262]. The main challenge associated with the use of C2H5OH and CH4 in MS-SOFCs is optimizing the interaction in the range of PMS and the anode in the presence of these low-molar-mass biofuels [263]. These biofuels induce coking on the Ni surface, reducing the MS-SOFCs performance and lifespan. The deposition of an amorphous carbon on the Ni surface stimulates the Ni oxidation into Ni2+. These cations promote the nucleation of graphite. Over time, these nuclei grow into lamellar channels and the Ni2+ diffuses through these channels, interacting with other Ni2+ to form Ni nanoparticles. These nanoparticles catalyze the growth of carbon nanotubes, decreasing the surface area of active sites available for biofuel thermal cracking into H2 and CO. The consequences include Ni sputtering, anode degradation, and a subsequent sink in MS-SOFC performance over time [264–266]. To understand the coking mechanism in SOFCs powered by biofuels, it is imperative to comprehend the elementary steps of biofuels reforming, such as ESR and SMR, into H2 and CO at the catalyst surface. Welander et al. reported the internal reforming of NG, propane, ammonia, and dimethyl ether at 700 °C by MS-SOFCs with symmetric architecture using an innovative high-entropy alloy (HEA) catalyst. The architecture of the cells includes thin ceramic electrolytes, scaffold layers, and cost-effective FSS PMSs on both sides. Praseodymium oxide and Ni/SDC catalysts were infiltrated into the cathode and anode, respectively. The initial performance and durability achieve performance and degradation rates comparable to H2 (500 mW·cm−2 and ∼12% per 100 h). Sulfur testing revealed reversible degradation at concentrations typical of NG and irreversible degradation at higher sulfur levels, as found in commercial propane. Overall, the MS-SOFCs demonstrated effective fuel flexibility [267]. The evaluation of the performance, long-term durability, and thermal cycling tolerance of MS-SOFCs running on NG reformate fuels was reported. Symmetric MS-SOFCs, comprising composite SDC-Ni anode catalysts and PrOx cathode catalysts were tested using simulated NG steam-reformate and partial-oxidation-reformate fuels containing 1 ppm and 5 ppm of sulfur. The cells were operated for 1000 h, displaying initial degradation rates comparable to those observed with humidified H2, with performance differences largely due to the lower H2 content in the reformate fuels. Furthermore, the cells exhibited resilience to multiple aggressive thermal cycles, even in the presence of sulfur, with minimal performance loss. Post-mortem analysis revealed that Ni particle coarsening and Cr deposition were primary factors in degradation, while no evidence of coking or sulfur deposition was detected. Overall, MS-SOFCs demonstrated successful operation with reformed NG [268]. Li et al. have reported Ce0.9Ni0.1O2-δ (CNO) comprising Ni nanoparticles and Ni-doped CeO2, referred to as Ni@CNO, with Ni particles uniformly dispersed on the CNO substrate. This material depicts a high V O ∙ ∙ concentration and excellent H2O absorption properties, leading to moderate catalytic activity and strong resistance to coking during SMR. When Ni@CNO is infiltrated into a Ni0.9Fe0.1 (NF) PMS, it enhances the MS-SOFC performance by increasing the H2/CH4 ratio (3.38 at 600 °C) in the reforming gas, improving coking resistance, and extending the operational durability. Using the Ni@CNO-infiltrated NF PMS (NFNC) with Ni/Ce0.9Gd0.1O2-δ (Ni-GDC) functional anode, GDC electrolyte, and La0.6Sr0.4Co0.2Fe0.8O3-δ/Ce0.9Gd0.1O2-δ (LSCF-GDC) cathode, the MS-SOFC powered by wet CH4 (3 vol% H2O) achieved a peak power density of 343 mW·cm−2. The cell voltage remained above 0.6 V at 400 mW·cm−2 over 280 h of testing at 600 °C, with no significant coking observed in the PMS or the functional anode [269]. Hu et al. have reported high-performance MS-SOFCs with internal reforming catalysts based on HEA materials. The MS-SOFCs were demonstrated for transportation applications using ethanol and methanol as fuels. The addition of the HEA catalysts significantly enhanced both cell performance and stability when powered by an ethanol–water fuel blend. The absence of coking, predicted by thermodynamic models, was verified through Raman spectroscopy of post-mortem anodes. Optimal conditions for catalyst processing, such as deposition methods, loading, and sintering temperature, as well as operating parameters including flow rates, temperature, and fuel compositions, were investigated. The infiltrated HEA catalyst formed a highly porous structure with a low loading of 6 mg·cm−2, contributing to minimal mass transport resistance in both the fuel electrode (26.2 s·m−1) and oxygen electrode (41.6 s·m−1). The best results were achieved with a 60:40 ethanol-to-water fuel mixture, delivering a power density of 830 mW·cm−2 at 700 °C, without any coking. The ethanol-fueled MS-SOFC demonstrated stable operation for 500 h, including five thermal cycles. The cell degradation followed trends similar to those observed with H2 fuel, with Ni coarsening and chromia deposition as the main degradation mechanisms, while coking was effectively avoided even after extended operation [270]. Dewa et al. reported MS-SOFCs incorporating infiltrated NiMo/CeO2-ZrO2 internal reforming catalysts. The cells were operated under direct ethanol at 700 °C, with a steam-to-carbon (S/C) ratio of 2. The addition of a catalyst functional layer was essential to reform ethanol into syngas internally while preventing rapid deactivation of the MS-SOFC due to coking. Experimental results demonstrated that the cell with the NiMo/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst achieved a higher maximum current density of 355 mW·cm−2 compared to 52 mA·cm−2 for the cell lacking the catalyst at 0.4 V. Additionally, the stability of cells at constant current was markedly improved. The NiMo/CeO2-ZrO2 infiltrated cell operated for 90 h, exhibiting lower levels of coking compared to the cell without the catalyst. The incorporation of the NiMo/CeO2-ZrO2 reforming catalyst into the MS-SOFC system presents a promising approach to extending operational lifetime and enhancing coke resistance during ESR in MS-SOFC applications [271]. In other study, Dewa reported the use of Rh/CeO2-ZrO2 (Rh/CZ) as an internal reforming catalyst layer in a high-performance MS-SOFC. The catalyst is applied by infiltrating Rh, CeO2, and ZrO2 precursors into the FSS 430 PMS. The cell was powered using 45 vol% C2H5OH in H2O at 600 °C. Button cell with the infiltrated 5 wt% Rh/CZ catalyst significantly outperforms the cell lacking the catalyst, enhancing ethanol’s internal reforming activity for syngas production. The maximum current density increased from 300 to 400 mA·cm−2, and long-term stability was also greatly enhanced. Post-mortem analysis reveals that the catalyst layer effectively prevents severe coking on the anode functional layer. The integration of the reforming catalyst layer with the MS-SOFC shows great promise for advancing bioethanol-powered MS-SOFC technology for future electric vehicle applications [184]. The electrochemical oxidative coupling of CH4 using the Sr2Fe1.5Mo0.5O6-δ (SFM) catalyst was demonstrated with MSCs. SFM anode and Pr6O11 cathode catalysts are incorporated into a porous symmetric-architecture cell through infiltration and sintering. Citric acid/ethylene glycol was identified as the most effective chelating agent, and optimal sintering and reduction temperatures (850 °C/750 °C) were determined for the SFM catalyst precursor solution based on cell testing. The CH4 conversion rate and product selectivity were significantly influenced by operating temperature, cell voltage, and oxygen concentration at the cathode, as these factors regulate oxygen ion flow. At 800 °C, a CH4 conversion rate of 85.8% was achieved, with resulting concentrations of C2H4, C2H6, and H2 at 10.5%, 12.3%, and 25.6%, respectively, in the exhaust gas. The system demonstrated stable current density and methane conversion over 200 h of operation enabling the synthesis of valuable chemicals using MS-SOCs [138]. The enhanced MS-SOFC is compared with literature reports that demonstrate high maximum power density for various anode catalysts, as shown in Fig. 13 . The MS-SOFC performance is nearly double that of the best conventional SOFCs. This improved performance reflects advancements in cathode, electrolyte, anode, and overall cell architecture. Table 3 depicts the potential of MS-SOFCs powered by C2H5OH and CH4 in long-term tests ranging from 100 to 1000 h. The published articles focus solely on the scientific demonstration of individually optimized cells, with no studies found showcasing the performance of stacks under high-power conditions with commercial relevance. 5 External ESR and SMR: A brief overview Hydrocarbons or biofuels can be converted into syngas by steam reforming. This syngas is used as fuel in MS-SOFCs. Otherwise, hydrocarbons and biofuels such as bioethanol and biomethane can be reformed directly at the anode of MS-SOFCs since the anode materials are similar to those used in external ESR and SMR. However, there is a challenge: the anode catalyst materials in MS-SOFCs for H2 cleavage need further improvement to efficiently convert higher molar mass biofuels and hydrocarbon fuels like propane, butane, and iso-octane in syngas. These fuels are converted into syngas inside a reformer reactor containing Ni, Ru, or Rh supported on Al2O3, La2O3, CeO2, ZnO, MgO, or aluminosilicates. The catalytic conversion occurs in the range of 250–950 °C relying on the catalyst/support system interaction. Salts and nitrates of metal precursors are infiltrated and impregnated inside sponges or monolithic ceramics with organized micro-channels by wet chemistry or sol–gel DCoat followed by calcination to consolidate the catalytic active metal phase. Metals such as Co, Cu, tin (Sn), Pt, Pd, Mn, niobium (Nb), or gold (Au) can be alloyed with Ni, Ru, or Rh to efficiently convert these fuels with high H2 selectivity and low coking [152,278]. Tables 4 and 5 illustrate the main external ESR and SMR systems. Systems incorporating Ni, Mn-Co-Si, Pt, Ru, and Rh on Al2O3, MgO, La2O3, CeO2, and aluminosilicates exhibit the highest conversion and H2 selectivity. However, the key drawbacks of onboard external reformers in FCHEVs powertrain systems include heat management, size, weight, cost, reuse difficulty, and recyclability challenges. Therefore, scaling up internal ESR and SMR directly at the MS-SOFCs anode emerges as a viable alternative. However, it still faces challenges due to the lack of optimized materials for hydrocarbon and biofuel reforming [17,61,279]. The optimal materials used in reformers are improper for use as MS-SOFCs anode catalysts due to the following reasons: (i) Rh, Pt, and Pd are excellent catalysts for CC and HH cleavage but are skyrocket expensive; (ii) Si and SiO2 are contaminants of 8YSZ and 10GDC polycrystalline ionic conductors creating during the thermal-treatment an amorphous SiO2 thin film in the grain boundaries which blocks the charge carriers increasing polarization losses; (iii) the concentration of V O ∙ ∙ in pure Al2O3, MgO, and CeO2 ceramic supports is insufficient for O2− transport by the crystalline lattice. Therefore, these oxides need to be doped with aliovalent metal to be used as MS-SOFCs anodes. Furthermore, the kinetic modeling of reformers should incorporate intrinsic thermodynamic information about the chemical elementary reactions as a function of the reformer properties to derive the ESR and SMR conversion rates r ̇ ESR and r ̇ MSR . This information is crucial for a more comprehensive understanding of the ESR and SMR. The kinetic behavior of ESR has been investigated in several reformers, such as the Ni/Al2O3-based state-of-the-art in the range of 200–900 °C. The description of r ̇ ESR involves equations based on experimental data fitting, using either power law rate (PLR) [250,279–288], or Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanistic assumptions [284,289–297]. Similar to ESR, the kinetic behavior of SMR has also been studied for various reformers in the same ESR temperature range, also employing equations from experimental data fitting [135–137,161]. Kinetics data can be modeled using the PLR without considering the elementary reaction mechanisms of the ESR. These data are fitted using the Eq. (4) below. (4) - r ̇ ESR = k 0 . ( e E act . RT ) . P C 2 H 5 O H α . P H 2 O β where k 0 represents the collision frequency in (kgcat·s)−1, E act . denotates the activation energy in kJ·kmol−1, R is the universal gas constant in kJ·kmol−1·K−1, T represents the absolute temperature in Kelvin (K), P is the partial pressure of the gas, and α and β are the chemical reaction orders. The parameters k 0 , E at . , α and β vary based on factors such as particle size and size distribution, crystal structure, morphology, catalysts and support microstructures, gas diffusion channels architecture and operating conditions including catalyst temperature (Tcat. ), reactants mass fluxes, PP O 2 , and the catalytic activity of catalysts [151,280,283–285,298–300]. However, certain details extracted from the chemical elementary reactions are overlooked when using PLR. In contrast, the ER kinetic model incorporates mechanistic assumptions involving elementary reactions that occur in ERS. Broadly, during ESR, besides the C2H5OH decomposition to produce CH4, CO, and H2 the following elementary reactions also take place: (i) dehydrogenation of C2H5OH to produce H2, resulting in the generation of acetaldehyde (CH3CHO); (ii) decomposition of CH3CHO to produce more CH4 and CO; (iii) dehydration of C2H5OH, giving rise to H2O and ethylene (C2H4), which may polymerize and degrade into carbon on the catalyst active surface also generating H2 [151,280,283–285,298–300]. The ESR kinetic modeling by the ER mechanism involves the following elementary reactions: (i) adsorption of C2H5OH on the active site of the active catalyst; (ii) dissociation on the adjacent active site, leading to the formation of oxygenated and hydrogenated hydrocarbons; and (iii) these hydrocarbons react with non-adsorbed H2O molecules to produce H2 and CO2 [151,280,283–285,298–300]. The dissociation of C2H5OH is the slowest elementary reaction. Consequently, it is the rate-determining step (RDS) in the overall process. However, this elementary reaction effectiveness depends on the active catalyst surface site concentration for C2H5OH adsorption [284,300]. Only the global reactions of ESR and SMR for catalyst supported on O2− anion conductors’ electrolytes will be considered, which aligns with the anode reality of MS-SOFCs [46,269,301,302]. The ESR occurs according to Eqs. (5) and (6), and the SMR according to Eqs. (7) and (8), both to produce H2. (5) C 2 H 5 O H ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) → 2 C O ( g ) + 4 H 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K 0 = 256 k J · mol - 1 (6) C 2 H 5 O H ( g ) + 3 H 2 O ( g ) → 2 CO 2 ( g ) + 6 H 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K 0 = 174 k J · mol - 1 (7) CH 4 ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) → CO ( g ) + 6 H 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K 0 = 206 k J · mol - 1 (8) CH 4 ( g ) + 2 H 2 O ( g ) → CO 2 ( g ) + 4 H 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K 0 = 165 k J · mol - 1 The C2H5OH and CH4 can also react with O2 by partial oxidation of ethanol (POE) and partial oxidation of methane (POM) in the auto-thermal reforming (ATR) to produce CO, H2O, H2 and heat according to Eqs. (9) and (10) for POM and POE. (9) C 2 H 5 O H ( g ) + 1 2 O 2 ( g ) → 2 C O ( g ) + 3 H 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K 0 = - 14 k J · mol - 1 (10) CH 4 ( g ) + 1 2 O 2 ( g ) → CO ( g ) + 2 H 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K 0 = - 36 k J · mol - 1 At low molar ratios of Oxygen/Ethanol (O/E) or Oxygen/Methane (O/M), CO production can occur in MS-SOFCs at low current densities. However, this reaction is not thermodynamically preferred at Tcat. ≅ 600 °C. Finally, H2 and CO are converted by the O2− anions at the MS-SOFCs anode according to Eqs. (11) and (12) below. (11) H 2 ( g ) + O ( T P B ) 2 - → H 2 O ( g ) + 2 e - Δ H 298 K 0 = - 241 k J · mol - 1 (12) CO ( g ) + O ( T P B ) 2 - → CO 2 ( g ) + 2 e - Δ H 298 K 0 = - 283 k J · mol - 1 Coking can occur by the decomposition of C2H5OH or CH4, or by CO disproportionation reaction (Boudouard reaction) also generating CO2, leading to the formation of carbon on the catalyst surface of the MS-SOFC anode according to the Eq. (15). This process also produces H2, as described by Eqs. (13) and (14) for C2H5OH and CH4. (13) C 2 H 5 O H ( g ) → CH 4 ( g ) + CO ( g ) + H 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K 0 = 49 k J · mol - 1 (14) CH 4 ( g ) → C + 2 H 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K 0 = 75 k J · mol - 1 (15) 2 CO ( g ) → C ( s ) + CO 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K 0 = - 171 k J · mol - 1 However, reactions in the range of CO and H2O can enhance the production of H2 and CO2 by the WGS reaction reducing coking on the reformer catalyst and the MS-SOFC anode, as indicated by Eq. (16) below. (16) CO ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) → CO 2 ( g ) + H 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K 0 = - 41 k J · mol - 1 The C2H5OH and CH4 hydration is crucial to ensure free-coking on the active catalysts of reformers and MS-SOFC anodes. Additionally, it contributes to cost reduction since hydrated ethanol has a lower energy input compared to 100 vol% ethanol due to a basic distillation process in biorefineries.
