This not only makes the fuel less intensive in industrial processing but also contributes to a further reduction in GGE. Moreover, hydration enhances the surface ionic conductivity due to the Grotthuss mechanism [358–360]. Endothermic reactions are favored by increasing temperature, while exothermic reactions are favored by decreasing temperature. Therefore, the C2H5OH reformers have two stages: (i) an ESR by Ni/Al2O3 or Ni/CeO2 state-of-art catalysts at 600 °C; (ii) POE and WGS by FexOy catalysts producing more H2 at 300 °C [361]. For 0<(S/E) < 10 and 0 < O/E < 3 M ratios, no coking occurs in the range of 200–1000 °C due to the Gibbs free energy minimization in the range of the ESR, POE, and ATR. For the ESR, POE, and ATR the main features are: (i) in ESR and POE, the C2H5OH decomposes in the range of 200–1000 °C; (ii) for Tcat. < 400 °C, CH4 and CO2 generating occurs; (iii) for Tcat . > 400 °C the CH4 concentration decreases and H2 and CO increase; (iv) in ESR for S/E > 4 in the range of 550–650 °C the H2 productivity can be as high as 4 mols of H2 per mol of C2H5OH with CO < 0.1 mol without coking; (v) in POE, high H2 and CO formation can occur in the range of 0.8 < O/E < 1.5 and Tcat . > 600 °C without coking; (vi) the ATR is used at any S/E to reduce the ESR energy demand and (vii) for O/E up to 0.75 and Tcat. < 600 °C no H2 and CO productivity reduction and coking occurs [361]. Due to these characteristics, ESR and SMR emerge as viable solutions for the internal reforming of C2H5OH and CH4 directly at MS-SOFC anodes. It is noteworthy that the bioethanol available in Brazilian gas stations may contain up to 7 vol% of H2O. This concentration corresponds to an S/E of 0.24. This powertrain system proves economically attractive as it allows C2H5OH dilution down to 24.6 vol%, i.e., 75.4 vol% of H2O (S/E: 10) without experiencing coking, thanks to the WGS reaction. Moreover, the S/E can be increased by recirculating the steam-rich exhaust gas from the SOFC, which carries the additional benefit of energy integration in the range of the exothermic SOFC and the endothermic reformer. However, MS-SOFC performance diminishes when the H2O concentration exceeds 55 vol% H2O due to the fuels reduced electrocatalytic activity [17,61]. Ma et al. conducted thermodynamic simulation studies on a powertrain system incorporating ESR and a stack of MS-SOFCs powered by H2 reformed from C2H5OH at 600 °C, providing a current density of 300 mA·cm−2. In this investigation, the MS-SOFC stack achieved a maximum efficiency of η = 0.50. This low efficient value is attributed to the presence of ohmic, activation, and mass transport overpotentials, leading to energy losses. These characteristics stem from the inherent material parameters of MS-SOFCs employed in this simulation [362]. To understand these mechanisms of energy loss, it is imperative to quantify each of them. Electrochemical models can be explored to validate experimental observations of the energy conversion phenomenology. However, this matter will not be discussed in this review. 6 Re-engineering PMSs for direct and efficient reforming of biofuels As early discussed, new degradation mechanisms may emerge when MS-SOFCs are directly powered by hydrocarbon fuels and biofuels. To address this issue, the PMS and anode redesign becomes essential. Over the last two decades, the PMS architecture and manufacturing techniques have only been well-established for MS-SOFCs powered by H2. Typical manufacturing techniques for PMSs by powder metallurgy involve processes such as powder pressing, tape casting, and spraying of metallic suspensions. These techniques produce PMSs with randomly dispersed pores and high tortuosity channels. The drawback of using powder metallurgy is the difficulty to control: (i) the particle and pores size and size distribution; (ii) the lateral gas diffusion; (iii) the sinter neck sizes of the PMS particles, which are highly susceptible to oxidation. The main challenge of powder metallurgy is developing PMSs with open and interconnected porosity. The morphology, connectivity, and size of the pores depend on the incorporation of suitable pore formers and sacrificial templates. This procedure, combined with a well-designed sintering program, contributes to achieving a suitable microstructure with highly efficient gas channels. Nielsen et al. reported a ∼40% increase in the Ppeak of MS-SOFCs powered by H2 using PMSs with straightforward, open, and interconnected pore channels. The enhancement was ascribed to the efficient gas diffusion across highly dense pores with low tortuosity [363]. Ceres Power uses a laser to drill straight channels (25 μm of diameter) in PMSs of 500 μm of thickness. However, the laser drilling process is expensive and complex impairing the scale-up manufacturing. The process involves the use of fast laser pulses to melt and drill small perpendicular channels in thin FSS alloy sheets [364,365]. The control of the sinter neck morphology and size of the metal particles can effectively mitigate PMS degradation due to oxidation and coking. These vulnerable regions exhibit high surface energy, leading to elevated chemical reactivity. Additive manufacturing has emerged as a promising technique for manufacturing porous structures. This technique employs 3D printing by laser sintering to create micro-organized porous structures with interconnected channels in the range of 100–400 μm of thickness using a laser or electron beam [185,366–369]. Bineli et al. explored the reforming of bioethanol to produce syngas using micro-reformers (MRs) with micro-organized channels obtained by AM [369]. MRs could integrate into the ICs of MS-SOFCs for catalytic pre-reforming of hydrocarbon fuels and biofuels into syngas before reaching the TPBs of the active anode. Fig. 14 illustrates the proof-of-concept of this novel device integrating MRs and MS-SOFCs. MRs with organized micro-channels in the range of 100 < Thickness (μm) < 400 exhibits a reduced pressure drop and shorter gas residence time. This is assigned to the higher surface area provided by nanocatalysts impregnated on the surface of the organized micro-channels [369]. These attributes the following advantages: (i) enhanced conversion of hydrocarbons and biofuels with H2 selectivity; (ii) rapid start-up and light-off promoted by thermal integration in the range of the PMSs and ICs; (iii) good thermal shock resistance; (iv) improved control over the gas mass transport; (v) increased oxidation resistance of the PMS due to the preferential thermal cracking of the hydrocarbons and biofuels on the nanocatalysts of the MR which does not show small sinter necks; (vi) enhanced robustness and safety; (vii) long lifespan; (viii) and (ix) the prevention of coking on the MS-SOFCs anode [369]. This concept is currently in the experimental phase, limited to 3D metal printing, and further engineering studies are required before making any assertions about the economic viability of this integration. Fig. 15 provides a schematic of the MS-SOFC cross-sectional view depicting the MR, PMS, DBLs, electrolyte, and electrodes. Fig. 16 depicts the integration of PMSs and MRs in terms of oxidation resistance and lifespan. The figure compares the organized, robust, and sinter neck-free micro-channels obtained through AM with those produced by other powder metallurgy methods with less dimensional control. This approach aims to prevent the long-term performance decline of the MS-SOFC stack due to the PMS oxidation and coking at the MS-SOFC anode. The use of external reformers for hydrocarbon and biofuels in syngas to power SOFC stacks has been extensively documented. The advent and evolution of MS-SOFCs have stimulated technological interest. Therefore, MS-SOFCs can be used in FCHEVs enabling the use of hydrocarbon and biofuels [14,17,61,184,362]. Ni is the most used catalyst in MS-SOFC anodes, typically in Ni/YSZ or Ni/GDC composite anodes, which suffer from coarsening. This degradation occurs through Ni-Ni interdiffusion, a thermally activated mass transfer process. Over time, this results in the formation of larger, isolated Ni particles, reducing catalytic efficiency. This process reduces the TPB length, crucial for electrochemical reactions and long-distance transport of charge carriers. Methods to manufacture nanostructured anodes such as infiltrated Ni nanoparticles have shown promise in mitigating coarsening, though these approaches still face challenges from nanoparticle aggregation at high temperatures [55]. In a conventional process described by Tucker et al., NiO was co-sintered with YSZ and the PMS support under a reducing atmosphere (4% H2/96% Ar) at 1300 °C for 4 h. This process resulted in an increase in particle size from 3 µm to 10 µm as NiO was reduced to Ni. The coarsening, driven by Ni-Ni interdiffusion, is characterized by mass transfer from regions of high chemical potential to low chemical potential [370]. This directional diffusion causes the formation of isolated Ni particles and a reduction in TPB length, as demonstrated by Angelis et al. using ex situ ptychographic nanotomography. Rapid diffusion during annealing at 850 °C led to isolated Ni particles within 3 h [371]. One strategy to address the Ni coarsening is the use of Ni nanostructuring. Infiltrated anodes, where Ni nanoparticles are embedded into the porous backbone of YSZ or GDC, prevent coarsening at high temperatures. Ovtar et al. infiltrated 10GDC nanoparticles into Ni/YSZ electrodes and tested the cell at 800 °C in SOEC mode. Even after 1000 h of operation, no isolated Ni particles were observed. The strong adhesion of 10GDC nanoparticles on the Ni surface, along with heterogeneous mass diffusion in nanocomposites, helps to prevent surface diffusion [372]. Despite the advantages of infiltrated electrodes, nanoparticle coarsening, and aggregation still occur, driven by the high diffusive activity of the nanoparticles at elevated temperatures. Tucker et al. observed that infiltrated nano-Ni particles coarsened during operation at 700 °C, leading to rapid degradation of MSCs. To address this, thermochemical treatments were applied to stabilize the microstructure by pre-coarsening the nanoparticles at a higher annealing temperature (800 °C). While this approach provided stability, it came at the cost of performance loss [373]. Blennow et al. found that combining nano-sized GDC with 10 wt% of nano-Ni to form a conductive cermet anode helped stabilize Ni particles. This configuration provided sufficient catalytic activity while reducing the risk of Ni agglomeration. Subsequent research confirmed that MS-SOFCs with this anode achieved 500 mW·cm−2 at 650 °C with a degradation rate of 4.5% over 1000 h [187]. More recent studies by Dogdibegovic et al. demonstrated that the infiltrated 40 wt% Ni samaria-doped ceria anode showed almost no coarsening after 100 h of annealing at 700 °C in 3 vol% humidified H2 [178]. In addition to infiltrated electrodes, the in situ ex-solution method has gained attention for producing nanostructured electrodes. For example, Tan et al. used thermally driven in situ ex-solution to uniformly distribute Ni nanocatalysts on GDC surfaces. This method increased TPB density while avoiding nanoparticle agglomeration, achieving 1 W·cm−2 at 650 °C in humidified H2. However, the isolated Ni particles led to increased ohmic resistance, and an annealing process at 1250 °C was necessary to recover the GDC phase, limiting its application in MSCs [188]. H2 is considered an ideal fuel for SOFCs since it produces only water vapor, with no harmful by-products that would negatively impact cell performance or lifespan. While H2 is advantageous, biofuels like bioethanol and biomethane are more compatible with existing infrastructure, offering cost-effective solutions. However, these fuels lead to coking, as already discussed which reduces performance and shortens the cell’s lifespan [55]. The accumulation of graphite and other carbon-based materials on the Ni surface results from a catalytic graphitization process. Ni cations migrate to the outer surface of the graphite, forming small Ni particles. These particles then catalyze the formation of filamentous carbon, such as carbon fibers and nanotubes. This carbon buildup clogs pores and reduces the availability of catalytic sites, leading to further degradation of the cell [55]. Fig. 17 depicts this degradation phenomenology. One approach to address this issue is to incorporate Cu into the Ni-containing cermet anode or even replace Ni with Cu altogether, as Cu lacks the catalytic activity needed to break C–H and C–C bonds. However, while this reduces coking, it also lowers the power density of the cell, achieving only around 370 mW·cm−2 at 700 °C. In 2020, Li et al. designed an MSC featuring a Ni-Mn spinel anode (Ni-MnO-Mn/Fe-doped GDC) that operated stably at 650 °C in humidified H2 for 100 h without coking delivering 869 mW·cm−2. The high resistance to coking was attributed to fine MnO particles adsorbed on the Ni surface, while the increased catalytic activity of the GDC contributed to the cell’s improved performance [374]. In addition to coking, sulfur poisoning also occurs in the anode when carbon-based fuels such as biogas or biomethane-derivated from biogas are used. Sulfur, often present in methane from NG or CO sources, adsorbs onto the Ni surface, leading to decreased catalytic efficiency and TPBs blocking [55]. The reaction for sulfur poisoning is (17) H 2 S ( g a s ) + Ni ( s o l i d ) → Ni - S ( s u r f a c e ) + H 2 ( g a s ) This adsorption separates the Ni from the fuel gas and reduces the active sites available for electrochemical reactions. Regeneration or desulfurization processes can reverse some of the damage caused by sulfur poisoning. For instance, Zha et al. found that when 50 ppm of H2S was introduced into the fuel, there was a 20.6% decrease in current density. However, after removing the H2S from the fuel, performance gradually recovered due to sulfur desorption from the Ni surface, facilitated by reactions with H2 from the fuel and O2− from the electrolyte [376]. Proton ceramics have shown high resistance to both coking and sulfur poisoning due to their ability to conduct protons and oxide ions efficiently. For example, Duan et al. found that using an yttrium-doped barium zirconate anode (Ni-BZY) improved carbon cleaning by facilitating water adsorption and decomposition. This process removes carbon from the Ni surface by converting it to CO2 or hydrocarbons. Proton ceramics have also demonstrated better conductivity at lower temperatures compared to O2− conductors. Cells using a Ni-BZCYYb anode, BZCYYb electrolyte, and BZCY-LSCF cathode achieved excellent power densities as high as 1.1 W·cm−2, even in fuel containing 20 ppm of H2S at 750 °C. For more in-depth information on the degradation mechanisms of SOFCs and MS-SOFCs, you may kindly refer to the following references [32,49,377,378]. The MS-SOFCs performance and lifespan must be improved to enable the cells operation in the range of 500–600 °C. This improvement is crucial for external or internal reforming of hydrocarbon fuels and biofuels with 80,000 h of lifespan. It is imperative to adopt scalable manufacturing techniques to reduce FCHEV costs and market competitiveness. The next chapter will explore new materials and manufacturing techniques to mitigate the degradation mechanisms of MS-SOFCs directly powered by hydrocarbons and biofuels. 7 MS-SOFC advanced materials and manufacturing techniques In recent years, several researchers have reported new materials and manufacturing techniques for MS-SOFCs based on the: (i) deposition of a thin catalyst film on the MS-SOFC anode by spin and spray coating or ALD and PLD to create a pre-reforming catalytic layer, (ii) infiltration of catalyst in the electrodes and PMS scaffolds, (iii) pre-homogenization of electrode and catalyst materials, followed by impregnation in the electrodes and PMS scaffolds [172]. Table S4 of the SI provides guidance for developing MS-SOFCs directly powered by hydrocarbons and biofuels. The previous reform of hydrocarbons and biofuels into syngas by a pre-reforming catalytic layer before reaching the anode TPBs boosts the overall efficiency, ensuring higher cell performance without coking. However, the recent techniques present the following drawbacks: (i) lower adhesion of the catalyst thin film deposited on the anode by spin or spray coating causing delamination; (ii) increase in the total volume and impedance of the SOFC stack [13]. These emerging techniques target the enhancement of the anode performance. However, the ORR exhibits a sluggish rate compared to the HOR due to the difficulty of the 4e− pathway to fully oxidize the O2 molecule in a single step. Consequently, the ORR stands as the main limiting factor in SOFC performance powered by H2. The low TPBs density or active sites in LSM-based cathodes constrain the ORR. Advanced techniques like ALD enable the deposition of nanostructured cathodes with high surface area and TPBs density (or active sites). ALD is less common for anode fabrication due to the high charge transfer kinetics of the HOR. Several research groups have successfully employed ALD to deposit a pre-reforming catalytic layer on the SOFCs anode [379]. Given the skyrocketing costs associated with scaling up ALD for film manufacturing, some researchers have opted for more economical techniques. These techniques involve the infiltration of catalyst precursors by wet chemical or sol–gel routes followed by impregnation of desired crystalline phases into electrodes and PMS scaffold. This process is accomplished by successive calcinations, avoiding the deposition of a pre-reforming catalytic layer on the MS-SOFC anode. The impregnation techniques offer: (i) higher electrocatalytic activity and power density; (ii) good physicochemical stability; (iii) reduction and suppression of coking without increasing the final volume of the MS-SOFC stack. Moreover, the catalyst precursors infiltration and impregnation of active catalysts in the PMS and electrode scaffolds should possess the following characteristics: (i) the catalyst precursor solution or sol–gel must exhibit favorable rheological properties, including viscosity, rheopexy, and wettability, enabling penetration into the pores of the PMS or electrodes; (ii) the catalysts impregnated after heat treatment should feature a high surface area with nanoparticles in the range of 1–10 nm of average particle size (A-PSize). This A-PSize is achievable with good dispersion [380–382]. However, at elevated temperatures, the nanoparticles of impregnated catalysts undergo coarsening, leading to a reduction in active surface area and TPBs density (or active sites), catalytic activity, and resistance to coking [383,384]. To enhance resistance against catalyst coarsening, co-doping the electrolyte of Ni/YSZ-based anodes with Al2O3, TiO2, and CeO2 proves effective, as these oxides function as sintering/coarsening inhibitors. However, it is noteworthy that Al2O3 and TiO2 oxides contribute to a decrease in the electrical conductivity of the electrode [385]. The pre-homogenization of these materials can be conducted before the infiltration step into the PMS and electrode scaffolds to improve the infiltration. This process aims to enhance the infiltration, dispersion, and impregnation of active catalyst nanoparticles while reducing the coarsening of both nanoparticles and the electrode scaffolds [13]. High and medium entropy alloys show a stabilization effect against coarsening compared to supported nanoparticle Ni. Fig. 18 depicts a schematic of the impregnation of catalysts in the MS-SOFC electrode scaffolds. An approach for optimizing MS-SOFCs anodes for direct ESR and SMR involves the use of catalyst-support reformer systems used in the reforming of high molar mass hydrocarbons. For example, biomass gasification yields medium and low molar mass products, including syngas and by-products such as tar. These systems exhibit notable resistance to coarsening, sulfur poisoning, and coking. Table S5 of the SI outlines some of these systems and highlights key conclusions that can guide future testing as MS-SOFCs anodes. To enable the internal reforming of biofuels directly inside MS-SOFCs anodes, it is imperative to optimize the materials or the anode architecture to improve the power density, coarsening, and coking resistance besides the stability of the pre-reforming catalytic layer [386]. To present good electrocatalytic activity, the SOFC or MS-SOFC anode architecture should embody the following key features: (i) high concentration and mobility of V O ∙ ∙ without undesirable crystal structures; (ii) high density of TPBs; (iii) high surface adsorption of hydrocarbon and biofuels molecules on basic active sites to promote the production of hydrogenated and oxygenated hydrocarbons; (iv) good exchange kinetics for O2− release, and storage redox processes; and (v) strong interaction in the range of the catalysts active metal and the O2− ceramic conductor phase to prevent coarsening and coking [386]. Perovskite-structured MIECs exhibit elevated concentrations and surface mobility of the V O ∙ ∙ . Co-doping these perovskites with alkali metals reduces the chemical bonding energy in the range of these metals and oxygen ions enhancing the V O ∙ ∙ surface concentration and bulk mobility. However, alkali metals like potassium (K), sodium (Na), Li, and magnesium (Mg) possess low Tmelt . and high vapor pressures. These elements may evaporate and diffuse at the MS-SOFC during the thermal treatment and operation promoting the formation of insulating glassy phases that hinder electronic and ionic charge carriers transport [386]. Metals such as potassium (K), ruthenium (Ru), tungsten (W), tin (Sn), and boron (B) serve to mitigate Ni poisoning by sulfur (S) from H2S when SOFCs and MS-SOFCs anodes are powered with sour fuel such as biomethane, NG or diesel. This protective mechanism changes the electronic configuration of Ni in the conduction band, thereby safeguarding it against the formation of undesirable alloys with low active site density. The presence of V O ∙ ∙ not only facilitates the gasification of coke from the anode surface but also accelerates the removal of S and H2S through gasification by SO2 and H2O, respectively. Additionally, ions like Mn and cerium (Ce) exhibit low oxygen binding energy, demonstrating good redox capabilities and proficiency in oxygen release/storage cycling [386]. Enhancing the SOFCs and MS-SOFCs anodes coarsening resistance involves the following mechanisms: (i) confining the nanocatalysts on the ceramic phase; (ii) robust interaction in the range of nanocatalysts and ceramic phase; (iii) employing bi-metallic alloys with synergistic properties [386]. In recent developments, SOFCs and MS-SOFCs anodes featuring micro and mesoporous core–shell structures with ordered architecture and high surface areas demonstrate significant reductions in the nanocatalysts coarsening. These structures prove effective due to steric hindrance, which impedes the coarsening of nanocatalysts either when embedded on the surface of the core–shell (on the shell) or inside (in the core). In this context, new materials can drive the optimization and adaptation of SOFC and MS-SOFC anodes for power generation using hydrocarbon and biofuels. However, the introduction of new materials gives rise to additional degradation mechanisms. In the next section, we will explore the iceberg tip of the recycling and LCA and public policies concerned about this introduction of the MS-SOFC in a novel hybrid powertrain system designed for onboard electricity generation in FCHEVs powered by hydrocarbons and biofuels. 8 MS-SOFCs recycling Nowadays, there is a lack of research on the recycling and reuse of materials in MS-SOFC cells and stacks. However, there are few studies on HT-SOFCs and IT-SOFCs EoL when those devices are powered by H2, CH4 and other hydrocarbon fuels for decentralized stationary power generation. Unfortunately, there is an absence of studies addressing the EoL considerations specific to MS-SOFCs powered by biofuels such as C2H5OH and CH4 for the mobility sector, as this is still an emerging area. Nonetheless, since C2H5OH and CH4 can be considered biofuel and hydrocarbon, it is possible to draw comparisons with existing EoL literature on SOFCs powered by these fuels. The main material employed in MS-SOFCs anodes is Ni and/or NiO. Both Ni and NiO fall under carcinogenic classifications, specifically category 3 and 1. Consequently, there is a pressing need to either gradually substitute these materials or restrict their usage to minimal quantities. Recycling technologies for Ni and NiO are already established in the electrochemical sector, and several metallurgical companies have successfully incorporated recycled Ni and NiO alongside pure counterparts. Ni can undergo recycling from MS-SOFCs stacks EoL using conventional methods based on physical separation, involving processes such as size reduction and magnetic separation. However, when Ni is in combination with other materials inside the MS-SOFCs anode, more intricate separation procedures, such as hydrometallurgical processes used in battery recycling, become necessary. In the hydrometallurgical recycling process, Ni dissolves from the MS-SOFCs anode by chemical etching with acids or bases. Subsequent separation occurs by precipitation, solvent extraction, distillation, ion exchange, and filtration. This hydrometallurgical approach exhibits high recycling metal selectivity and reutilization of reactants. Nevertheless, the process requires a prior mechanical milling step to increase the material surface area exposing them to reactants. This process involves high electricity consumption and the generation of corrosive and toxic wastewater [387]. NiO holds the potential for recycling and subsequent utilization in the automotive and petrochemical industries [388,389]. The recycling process for NiO entails reactions with sulfuric acid (H2SO4), resulting in the formation of Ni sulfate (NiSO4) with an efficiency of 99%. This NiSO4 can be reused in galvanoplasty processes. Several methods employed by recycling industries for Ni and NiO recycling include chemical leaching or microbiological processes followed by solvent extraction, ion exchange columns or pyrolysis, and electrochemical refining [390]. On the other hand, the YSZ ceramic used as an electrolyte and often together with electrode composite materials is not a health hazard. This material can be recycled by hydrometallurgical or hydrothermal processes. The hydrothermal process has widely been used for recycling ceramics in dental prosthesis such as tetragonal zirconia 3Y-TZP (Z0.94Y0.06O1.97). This process involves the use of water at 250 °C to disintegrate the 3Y-TZP. The powder is filtered and dried at 50 °C, milled, granulated, and graded below 100 μm to be reused [391]. However, due to the high-purity requirements of YSZ raw materials for SOFCs and MS-SOFCs high electrochemical performance, its reuse for the same application becomes impractical. This recycled material may find utility in the electrochemical industries as a low-purity and lower-grade alternative rather than being reintroduced into SOFCs. Another viable option involves recycling this ceramic by milling and mechanical separation for repurposing in the construction sector, such as a filler in the manufacturing of highly mechanical resistant bricks or incorporation into cement compositions [56,390]. Concerning the cathode materials, LSM is commonly used in SOFCs, while LSCF and LSC are used in MS-SOFCs. These materials, such as YSZ ceramic, are amenable to recycling and reuse. MS-SOFCs stacks contain stainless steel ICs and Al2O3-based glass sealants. These materials can be recycled by mechanical milling processes and magnetic separation. They can be reused in the metallurgical or construction industry. The recycling and reuse process complexity escalates when additional materials are incorporated into the manufacturing of SOFCs and MS-SOFCs cells and stacks. MS-SOFCs are currently being commercialized by several companies across Europe, North America, and Asia. The urgency to produce solutions for the EoL of MS-SOFCs stacks is evident due to the: (i) recent imposition of responsibility on the mobility sector for recovery and recycling; (ii) potential conflict with EoL legislations in several countries if low-cost recycling technologies are unavailable; (iii) despite the high efficiency and reduced GGEs during MS-SOFC operation, environmental impacts of the cradle-to-the-grave cycle life must be considered to accurately assess the technology overall benefits [56,390]. One extreme approach to recycling the most resilient components involves grinding and segregating materials based on size and density, followed by managing the dense fractions abundant in Fe, Ni, and Cr towards the raw material feedstock for the steel industry. Conversely, the less dense fractions rich in ceramic materials such as Zr, Y, and Ce can find purpose in the cement industry. By reimagining recycling processes, not only the waste management challenges could be addressed, but also unlock avenues for resource optimization and circular economy practices, marking a significant stride towards a greener and more sustainable future. In addition to the recycling of FC stacks, another significant challenge lies in the disposal of FCHEVs battery packs. The second life and recycling of batteries are critical considerations for transport electrification. Inherent to the chemistry of these devices during operation or even in non-operation, batteries undergo continuous wear. After numerous charging and discharging cycles, the batteries experience a reduction in nominal capacity, rendering them impractical for use in BEVs. The typical lifespan of a battery pack is in the range of 5–8 years, and beyond this period, recharging no longer achieves 80% of the nominal capacity [381]. However, these battery packs can still find utility in “second life” applications, extending the lifespan to 7–10 years. This second life primarily involves energy storage from the grid, transforming them into large unity power storage (UPS) systems that release energy to the grid during peak times or in intermittent power generation periods. Through this utilization, the battery lifespan can be extended up to 15 years. Subsequently, recycling or disposal of these batteries becomes necessary [392,393]. A notable drawback of batteries lies in the substantial quantity of metals, including Li, Cu, Co, Ni, Mn, P, Fe, and Al, necessary for production. The extraction of these metals through mining contributes significantly to environmental impacts (EIs), such as GGEs released into the atmosphere. Recycling presents a viable solution to mitigate these impacts by minimizing the need for additional ore mining. Battery recycling has the potential to reduce GGEs by up to 30% [394–396]. However, the recycling process is complex due to the batteries being encased in robust containers that are challenging to open and separate [397]. Several other issues persist regarding the current scale of second-life batteries and MS-SOFCs recycling. Nonetheless, it is acknowledged that this aspect is highly imperative for BEVs and FCHEVs to constitute a sustainable solution amid the ongoing global energy transition. 9 MS-SOFCs LCA: From the cradle-to-the-grave The current literature exhibits a gap on the life-cycle inventory (LCI) and EoL aspects of MS-SOFC technology, imposing barriers to in-depth LCAs. The LCA methodology enables the quantification of EIs by assessing harmful emissions or other chemicals throughout the entire life-cycle of a product, service, or technology. Several reviews on LCA for SOFCs are available, but the focus is mostly on examining the environmental impacts of FCEVs compared to BEVs and ICEVs. However, a reliable LCA specific to FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFCs remains missing, as this technology is still under development [15,56]. Furthermore, there is a lack of comprehensive studies specific to the Brazilian scenario, mainly due to unique characteristics such as: (i) the availability of biogenic feedstocks for H2 production by steam reform; (ii) limited data on renewable energy share in the energy matrix, (iii) the introduction of a new powertrain system based on MS-SOFCs powered by syngas reformed from bioethanol and biomethane from sugar cane and biogas. Currently, only one available study quantifies the EIs of FCEVs considering H2 production under existing Brazilian conditions and estimates for a future scenario. It compares these impacts to FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFC stacks [15]. The majority of LCA studies comparing ICEVs, plug-in hybrid electrical vehicles (PHEVs), non-plug-in HEVs, and FCEVs concludes that the FCEVs are non-competitive across all assessed impact categories (ImC). In terms of global super-warming potential (GSWP), FCEVs exhibit performance as poorly as conventional fossil-fueled ICEVs. Nowadays, all FCEVs are equipped with PEMFCs stacks and a compact battery pack. This choice is driven by the ability to achieve rapid start-up at a lower 60–85 °C range and fast dynamic response to power fluctuations provided by the battery pack [398]. However, the drawback is the requirement of pure H2, mostly from electrolysis, and the need for high-pressure tanks, which considerably lowers the round-trip efficiency from the main power source. Currently, SOFC stacks find applications in commercial settings as auxiliary power units (APUs) or range extenders providing electrical efficiency and fuel flexibility, facilitating integration with existing infrastructure in numerous hydrocarbon and biofuel-producing countries [15,399]. LCA outcomes for several light-duty transport vehicles exhibit significant variability. These variations stem from factors such as study geolocation, temporal considerations, diversity in the supply chain, power matrix, ore extraction routes, ore scarcity, transportation, and rejects toxicity and carcinogenicity [15,400]. Although FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFCs are still in development, an estimated assessment with FCEVs can be conducted. For this purpose, the LCA methodology can utilize software such as ReCiPe® and SimaPro® to evaluate and compare the studied technologies. The results typically consider five ImCs: (i) GSWP; (ii) Human-Terrestrial Ecotoxicity (HTE); (iii) Human-Toxicity Carcinogenic (HTC); (iv) Mineral Resource Scarcity (MRS); and (v) Water Consumption (WC). Boundary conditions can be established, including the manufacturing of FCHEVs and FCEVs based on: (i) raw biogenic H2 resource and H2 production from water electrolysis (WElisys) for FCEVs; (ii) bioethanol and biomethane production for H2 and CO onboard reforming; and (iii) the use of these gases as fuels in FCHEVs powertrain system, considering the entire life-cycle of these vehicles [15]. Usually, the mineral extraction and production of steel, Al, and Cu to be used in vehicle manufacturing, as well as the production and logistics infrastructures for H2, bioethanol, and biomethane, should be considered in the LCI of these technologies. PEMFCs used in FCEVs consist of several membranes based on perfluorosulfonic acid and tetrafluoroethylene (Nafion®) copolymerization. Besides the acid being a risk for HTE and MRS, porous carbon electrodes decorated with Pt catalysts are highly sensitive to deactivation by CO, requiring an additional reactor to remove traces of this gas (<10 ppm) from H2 reformed from hydrocarbons or biofuels. Moreover, the carbon fiber of the high-pressure H2 gas storage vessels in FCEVs is not only skyrocket expensive but also designed to store only 5.6 kg of gas H2 at 700–900 bar [15,401]. Unlike PEMFCs, MS-SOFCs operate at higher temperatures in the range of 550–750 °C, with one of the main advantages being the utilization of Ni and CeO2-based catalysts instead of noble metals. The world’s first and only FCHEV prototype equipped with MS-SOFCs is Nissan’s e-Bio Fuel Cell. However, due to the scarcity of data surveys on SOFCs for vehicle applications, many LCAs utilize data extracted from SOFCs operating in decentralized stationary power generation. Other crucial data for these vehicle LCAs include the: (i) curb weight (kg); (ii) battery chemistry; (iii) power (kW) and the battery pack capacity (kWh); (iv) fuel consumption (km·L−1); (v) vehicle lifespan (km); (vi) catalysts used in the FCHEVs external reformer and inside of the FC electrodes of the FCHEVs and FCEVs; and (vii) the origin of materials and components used in these vehicles. Other important data are the weight of the: (i) FC stack; (ii) balance of plant (BoP); (iii) powertrain system; (iv) battery; (v) glider; (vi) FCEV H2 gas storage vessels and FCHEV fuel tank [15]. Unfortunately, comprehensive EoL information remains unavailable for most materials used in FC stacks. While hydrometallurgical routes exist for the treatment of Ni and YSZ, there is a lack of information concerning the treatment of LSM, LSC, and LSCF-based materials used in the MS-SOFCs cathodes [15]. Nowadays, global H2 demand stands at ∼70 Mton·year−1. The main sources for H2 production include NG reforming (76%) and coal gasification (23%), resulting in a substantial emission of 830 Mton CO2·year−1 [15,402]. In the Brazilian context, low GGEs routes for H2 production are imperative to establish it as a viable energy vector. Nowadays, Brazil’s landscape comprises five routes: (i) two ESR routes utilizing sugarcane and corn feedstocks; (ii) two SMR routes involving biomethane capture from landfills (BioMe) and SMR from NG; and (iii) an additional route through WElisys. By 2030, the production of syngas from biomass could be harnessed for combustion and electricity generation. This electricity could assist the conversion of lignocellulosic materials into second-generation ethanol (2G Ethanol) by enzymatic hydrolysis and fermentation of the resultant syngas [15]. The WElisys for H2 production consumes a substantial amount of energy, and its EI is highly contingent on the electricity supply type. Notably, in 2020, Brazil’s share of renewable energies was approximately 48%, contrasting with the global figure of around 14%. This peculiarity is important for a country’s energy sustainability and its transition toward a lower carbon economy, especially when considering WElisys with low EIs [50]. However, aside from generation, establishing a dedicated infrastructure for H2 storage and logistics for FCEVs is essential. Safety standards also play a critical role, with the SAE J2601 protocol stipulating that H2 gas storage vessel temperatures should not exceed 85 °C, even during rapid refueling. In the LCA of these vehicles, it is crucial to consider if the H2 production occurs in a central hub, such as a refinery for biomethane or NG reforming, a distillery for bioethanol reforming, or a WElisys plant. It is well-established that H2 production based on small reforming stations requires less CAPEX and entails higher sales rates and lower costs than centralized productions. However, the emergence of large-scale H2 production geographical centers to ensure a scale economy is a possibility in the near future [15,403]. Additionally, it should be assumed that the vehicles can be at least partially manufactured in Brazil, enabling the adaptation of LCIs for the glider components and the powertrain system, consisting of either PEMFCs or SOFCs cells stacks to Brazilian manufacturing conditions. Fig. 19 depicts the data corresponding to each ImC for FCEVs and FCHEVs. Due to the mass, both the glider and powertrain FCEVs and FCHEVs significantly contribute to each ImC, given the substantial use of materials such as steel, Al, and other alloys. The battery weight of 24 kWh of the Nissan’s e-Bio Fuel Cell has a notable impact on each ImC. The adjustment of design parameters, particularly the shift from power to energy density in FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFCs stacks, results in a subsequent reduction in the weight of the battery pack and also leads to a decrease in the ImCs of these vehicles [15]. While FC stacks have a relatively low impact on EIs, it is essential to carefully analyze the data due to the scarcity and outdated nature of manufacturing processes and material specifications. FCs stacks and BoPs components exhibit a minimal contribution compared to other ImCs [15]. Concerning the fuel type in LCA of these vehicles, H2 production from biomass with carbon capture and storage can potentially yield negative carbon emissions, particularly when predominantly using ESR from sugarcane, corn feedstocks, or SMR from biomethane refined from biogas lagoon or landfills. However, the impact on HTE is significant due to the agricultural stage of these feedstocks [15]. Regarding WC, the WElisys exhibits a significant impact due to its extensive hydroelectricity consumption. In the current Brazilian scenario, the common practice for biomethane upgrade involves biogas purification using pressure swing adsorption to extract moisture, CO2, and H2S. The biomethane can be compressed, like CNG, for use as fuel in ICEVs or as fuel in FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFCs. However, this purification technology still allows for an 8 vol% methane leakage, contributing to the GSWP. Despite its maturity with TRLs in the range of 8–9, there are alternative options available which can eliminate such leakage. While biogas burning occurs in landfills in certain regions of Brazil, it is not a nationwide practice. Therefore, biomethane upgraded from biogas and captured in landfills can be used for syngas reforming, resulting in carbon credits [15]. If bioethanol undergoes reforming by steam reforming with carbon capture and storage to address biogenic CO2 emissions, the resulting syngas can indeed contain green H2, leading to potentially negative carbon footprints. HTC and MRS are the main ImCs dominated by vehicle production. Reduction in vehicle weight, the use of alternative materials, and improvements in production efficiency can contribute to reducing these impacts. WC has a significant impact on FCEVs powered by H2 generated by WElisys in the current Brazilian scenario context due to substantial hydroelectricity consumption. However, in the near future, all H2 generated by WElisys will use a peak power supply from wind and solar renewable power in the northeast of Brazil. On the other hand, HTE is primarily influenced by all bioethanol reforming routes, with the agricultural stage of feedstock production by pesticide use, and subsequent emissions to air, water, and soil being the key factors contributing to this ImC [15]. In the context of FCEVs and FCHEVs, the dominant impacts on ImCs do not originate from the FC stacks. The glider, BoP, and battery weight remain crucial factors for mitigating the ImCs of these vehicles. For instance, the majority (70%–95%) of the total cost of ownership (TCO) for a FCEV with PEMFCs stack is attributed to the purchase cost. Hence, reducing the cost of the FCEVs and FCHEVs, particularly the FC stack and the carbon fiber H2 gas storage vessel, is essential for enhancing competitiveness against BEVs and ICEVs. Achieving cost reductions can be facilitated by economies of scale [15]. H2 production from WElisys, and from biomass, bioethanol, and biomethane reforming should be prioritized due to the ability to add value to the product by diversifying H2 sources. WElisys, especially in countries like Brazil, which has a significant share of renewable energies, and large hydroelectricity power generation can significantly contribute to reducing GGEs. This is particularly relevant in Brazil, where the biofuel tracking management policy called RenovaBio is in place, issuing carbon credits to producers who efficiently produce these fuels [404]. Nevertheless, those practices can also be implemented in other countries with biofuel production ability, such as Thailand, India and even USA and Canada to increase their portfolio of solutions for the energy transition, especially for the heavy-duty transportation where BEVs cannot meet the intercontinental demands of large countries. RenovaBio program in Brazil exemplifies a public policy initiative designed to mitigate GGEs. This program incorporates the following key elements: (i) impelling biofuel production; (ii) performing control and responsibility measures for GGEs by biofuel production tracking; (iii) emphasizing environmental sustainability, and (iv) promoting economic sustainability. In 2016, Brazil operated more than 350 sugarcane mills, employing 794,000 individuals in rural areas, surpassing the 700,000 employees engaged in the urban-based Brazilian oil industry [16,405–407]. This program introduces a payback known as decarbonization credits (CBio) for biofuel producers. Biofuel producers, upon accrediting sugarcane mills, landfills, and biogas lagoons, gather CBio entitlements proportionate to the volume of biofuel generated. Notably, this system allows producers to purchase CBios to offset GGE emissions. A higher CBio score is assigned to more efficient production practices, thereby inspiring the reduction of GGEs [404]. Governments and private entities are actively researching and developing a myriad of advanced power generation technologies for the mobility sector to achieve carbon neutrality. During these early stages, substantial government subsidies are essential. Examples include the exploration of solar and wind renewable power generation for charging BEVs and the investigation of emerging technologies which use renewable fuels. This includes FCEVs and HBVs with FCs powered by green H2 [408,409]. The energy transition of the mobility sector is crucial. In 2020, the fossil fuel consumption sector contributed ∼23% to global CO2 emissions. During the same period, the R&D public budget allocated to energy technologies by International Energy Agency (IEA) member countries amounted ∼USD 23 billion. In this budget, renewable energies accounted for 14.5%, while H2 and FCs constituted 4.3%. Consequently, R&D centers focusing on H2 and FCs in IEA member countries received ∼USD 1 billion of financial incentives. Brazil became an IEA member in 2017. In 2020, Brazil allocated ∼USD 1.7 billion to its public R&D budget in energy technology, acquiring the 5th position among member countries with heavy investments in this sector. From 2013 to 2017, Brazil did not witness significant investments in the field of H2 and FCs. However, in 2018, the Brazilian government initiated the ROTA2030 program under Federal Law No 13.755/2018. This program aims to lead investment to reinforce the mobility sector by stimulating the development and implementation of new technologies, which also improve fuel efficiency. Over the past three years, ROTA2030, administered by the Brazilian Research Development Foundation (FUNDEP), has approved and shell out ∼USD 35 million. These funds were allocated across 59 biofuels and alternative combustion propulsion research projects, supporting collaborations in the range of ISTs and industrial companies. Fig. 20 depicts the relationship of energy consumption and GGEs, specifically well-to-wheel, for several vehicle types across different scenarios outlined by ROTA2030. Each data point on the respective top-down curve denotes the product of energy consumption (MJ·km−1) and carbon intensity (gCO2eq.·MJ−1). The data spans from 2017, the baseline year for the diagram, to the projected dates of the new phases introduced by ROTA2030, namely 2022 (phase 1), 2027 (phase 2), and 2032 (phase 3). It is noteworthy that each line in the graph illustrates the progression of several propulsion and energy combinations over time, utilizing the most reliable data available from the Ecoinvent and BEN (Balanço Energético Nacional) database for energy inputs. Additionally, the authors estimations, derived from multiple sources, inform the evolution of efficiency for each powertrain technology. In this context, FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFCs stacks emerge as potentially optimal choices in the current Brazilian scenario and are projected to maintain this status in 2032. This designation is attributed to the potential for substantial carbon emission reduction and low energy consumption throughout the well-to-wheel life cycle. This analysis holds importance not only for compliance with emerging legislations and policies in the mobility sector but also for alleviating concerns related to the potential impacts of the widespread adoption of BEVs and FCEVs. Such adoption has the potential to disrupt existing biofuel value chains in producing countries, leading to unemployment and economic imbalances which could have an impact on the global economy. The revolution in the mobility sector must align with the peculiar characteristics of each country, ensuring the preservation of established value networks developed over decades/centuries. This approach not only safeguards against market competitiveness but also promotes a more sustainable and modern transition to address challenges stemming from a growing population, ecosystem imbalances, and escalating energy demands over the years [15]. Any emerging technology with the capacity to mitigate EIs of the mobility sector requires initiative-taking encouragement from stakeholders to ensure economic viability. The implementation of such innovations triggers deep modifications in both supply chains and business models. In tandem, incentives and market adjustments must be coordinated to collectively contribute to the mitigation of global warming, enhancement of air quality, and improvement in energy efficiency, all of which significantly impact the biosphere quality and human health. The robustness of LCA studies heavily relies on the availability and quality of data, along with the boundary conditions and assumptions made by the referenced authors. Additionally, the adaptability of studies to diverse regional scenarios is a crucial factor. It is important to highlight those other kinds of emissions related to biofuel generation and reforming are inadequately addressed in existing literature for LCAs. Specifically, FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFCs, it is pertinent to acknowledge that these analyses are grounded in information from two decades ago, lacking consideration for emissions during the life-cycle manufacturing process. Moreover, there is a notable scarcity of information on the LCIs of materials used in FCs, along with EoL details for each component or device. These gaps contribute to an incomplete understanding of the EI associated with FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFCs. Onboard biofuel reforming into syngas for MS-SOFCs stacks of FCHEVs, could represent a viable alternative for GGEs reduction by 2030. This comparison is made in the scientific international literature against BEVs and FCEVs. The advantage lies in the fact that FCs contribute minimally to ImCs, apart from the MRS category. Reduction in FCs impact on MRS is associated with weight reduction or the manufacturing scale-up. The impact of FCHEVs on the HTE is associated with the agricultural stage and the overall biofuel supply chain. However, in comparison in the range of FCEVs and FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFCs, the latter demonstrates numerous advantages, particularly in scenarios where biofuel is produced. In contrast, FCEVs do not exhibit competitiveness across the discussed categories. For GSWP, these vehicles perform as unfavorably as ICEVs powered by fossil fuels. Even flexible-fuel ICEVs manufactured in Brazil and fueled with 100 vol% of bioethanol exhibit a lower EI than both BEVs and PHEVs in both European and Brazilian contexts [15]. H2 from biofuels holds significant potential as a net carbon sink. The effectiveness of this strategy depends on the appropriate handling of feedstocks and the successful launch of carbon capture systems. FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFC stacks avoid the substantial investments required for H2 hubs and logistics. Vargas et al. reported the LCA of light-duty FCEVs and FCHEVs equipped with PEMFC and MS-SOFC. The analysis considered the impacts associated with different H2 production methods, including viable reforming routes of bioethanol, biomethane, and WElisys. The study evaluated scenarios where H2 is produced onboard in the case of FCHEVs with MS-SOFC stack and an external reformer or reformed externally [15]. Results indicated the potential for GGEs reduction in FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFC stacks. However, future studies should enhance reliability by utilizing more robust LCIs and EoL data. A more comprehensive examination of the integration of this new powertrain system into the Brazilian market and other biofuel producer markets is recommended. This solution brings a robust synergy in the range of electrification and biofuels in the mobility sector [15]. Gauto et al. reported LCAs from the cradle-to-the-grave of ICEVs, plug-in and non-plug-in HEVs, and BEVs. These vehicles were fueled with bioethanol and biomethane or charged with electricity from either the Brazilian or European energy matrix. The study revealed that GGEs for HEVs fueled with these biofuels are lower than those observed for BEVs in the Brazilian scenario. This is attributed to the lower carbon intensity emission of the electricity matrix in Brazil compared to many other countries. In 2022, Brazil produced 677 GWh of electricity, with 88% from renewable sources including hydropower (63%), wind (12%), and biofuels (8.1%). ICEVs using biomethane exhibit lower GGEs than a BEV charged in the Brazilian energy matrix, known for its environmental cleanliness. The authors reported that an HEV powered with 100% of biomethane and 100% of bioethanol can travel 16.8 and 12.9 km/kgCO2eq., respectively. In comparison, a BEV charged in the Brazilian and European energy matrix can only cover 9.5 and 6.9 km/kgCO2eq. The study suggests that even considering potential GGEs reductions during BEV battery manufacturing in future scenarios, biofuels remain a more favorable option [392]. Emissions linked to biofuel production are set to decrease in the coming decade as Brazilian biofuel producers actively pursue decarbonization to acquire carbon credits from RenovaBio program (CBios). This is achieved through various measures, including: (i) the biodigestion of the filter cake, vinasse, and straw to generate biomethane replacing diesel in sugarcane farming, harvesting, and transportation; (ii) the substitution of chemical fertilizers and pesticides with natural ones derived from the biodigestion process or other biological alternatives like nutrient-fixing microorganisms, algae, and biological pesticides; (iii) the cultivation and utilization of more productive biomass sources, exemplified by genetically modified Energy Cane, able to produce 280% more bioethanol per hectare; and (iv) strategic investments in technology and precision agriculture to enhance overall production efficiency [392]. It is important to highlight the production of 2G Ethanol from sugarcane by current technology which results in GGEs of 13.6 gCO2eq./MJ. Besides this significant value, the decarbonization of biofuel production coupled with carbon capture holds the potential for achieving negative emissions. Moreira et al. reported data about capturing CO2 emitted during the bioethanol fermentation and injecting it into deep aquifers which would result in a fuel cost increase of only USD 0.0334·L−1, corresponding to a price increment of 3.5% or a cost of USD 30/tCO2. Such minimal costs are feasible because the effluent gas from fermentation may contain up to 99% CO2, excluding water and bioethanol vapors, thereby reducing the need for expensive purification processes. If all the fermented CO2 generated from bioethanol production in Brazil could be sequestered, annual extraction of 27.7 MtCO2 from the atmosphere would be achieved, representing approximately 4% of the 650 MtCO2/year estimated by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change as requiring removal from the atmosphere Moreover, if these findings were extrapolated to global bioethanol production, this process could contribute substantially, accounting for 10% towards the world’s CO2 removal target. Similarly, the upgrade from biogas to biomethane inherently involves the removal of excess CO2, which could potentially be stored, thereby leading to negative emissions. Consequently, these findings reinforce the pivotal role of fermented biofuels in the endeavor to decarbonize the economy [410]. In lack of EoL and LCA data for MS-SOFCs, despite their lower EI, potential hazards during manufacturing stages could emit pollutants. This poses a risk of detriment to the entire manufacturing chain of FCHEVs and may lead to the imposition of trade barriers. Consideration should be given not only to the EoL and LCA of MS-SOFC stacks but also to the powertrain system. This system comprises fuel and air supply pipes, a fuel tank, early-burners, after-burners, air-blowers, electro-electronic systems for heating and operational control, as well as a thermal insulation system. Despite the superior efficiency and lower GGEs of MS-SOFC stacks, the lack of scientific studies on EoL and LCA requires further research. More studies are required to assess GGEs release of the manufacturing of these devices to evaluate the economic feasibility of recycling. Despite being a recent technology with limited information on EoL and LCA, the recycling of MS-SOFCs devices holds the potential to establish a promising new market in Brazil and other countries. 10 Advances and perspectives in R&D The development of MS-SOFCs has advanced significantly over the past decade, driven by the need for high-performance, cost-effective, and durable energy solutions. Companies like Ceres Power and consortia, including DLR, Plansee, and Topsoe have pioneered advancements in stack architecture, employing novel materials like ferritic steel substrates and innovative fabrication techniques such as plasma spraying and screen printing. These innovations have led to improved power densities, reduced degradation rates, and enhanced operational stability, but challenges remain. Issues such as electrolyte gas leakage, complex multi-layered cell structures, and the need for reliable sealing techniques persist. Patents filed in this space reflect the progress made in addressing these difficulties, with key developments in cathode materials, protective coatings, and electrolyte deposition methods. Despite the advancements, the scaling of MS-SOFCs for commercial use still faces technical and economic hurdles, particularly in achieving long-term durability and cost reduction. The economic viability of SOFCs must be assessed in comparison to competing technologies available in the market, such as natural gas turbines, solar photovoltaics, onshore wind, PEM fuel cells, and battery storage. In 2022, the estimated production cost for SOFC stacks was around 13,260 USD/kW, with a levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) of approximately 190 USD/MWh [411]. For context, the installation costs and LCOE of commercial energy sources in 2024 are as follows: natural gas turbines range in the range of 800–1,200 USD/kW and 40–110 USD/MWh; solar photovoltaics range from 800 to 1,300 USD/kW and 20–45 USD/MWh; onshore wind is in the range of 1,100–1,600 USD/kW and 30–50 USD/MWh; PEMFC are estimated at 1,000–1,500 USD/kW and 150–200 USD/MWh; and LFP battery storage at 53 USD/kW and 100–150 USD/MWh. These costs clearly indicate the current economic disadvantage of SOFC compared to these more mature energy sources. However, it is essential to recognize that SOFC technology has not yet benefited from cost reductions associated with large scale production. The Commercial-scale SOFC systems (COMSOS) project targets a cost of 3,700 USD/kW for 10–60 kW modules, while Nielsen et al. predict that SOFC stack costs could drop to 300 USD/kW in an industrial plant with a production capacity of 50 MW/year, and as low as 200 USD/kW for plants producing over 1000 MW/year [412]. Furthermore, SOFC provides distributed and dispatchable power, can co-produce hot water, and operate on renewable fuels like biomethane and ethanol. These competitive advantages can be leveraged to stabilize the electrical grid, serve as backup power systems, and support transport applications, demonstrating the transformative potential of this technology for the energy transition. To understand the advancements toward mass production, patent grants and their trends can be evaluated as indicators of technological maturity, and in this analysis, Google Scholar was employed for the research. Since 2004, a total of 32,271 patents have featured the term “SOFC” in their title, abstract, or claims, categorized under the Cooperative Patent Classification as 83% in Energy Generation through Renewable Energy Sources (Y02E), 66% in Processes for the Direct Conversion of Chemical Energy into Electrical Energy (H01M), and 23% in Climate Change Mitigation Technologies in Manufacturing (Y02P). These results indicate the potential of SOFCs as a promising solution for energy transition and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. When narrowing the search by fuels, “natural gas” produced 14,538 results, “ethanol” 1266, “methane” 661, “ammonia” 626, and “biogas” just 106. These results reveal a strong interest in logistical fuels like natural gas, ethanol, and ammonia, whereas methane and biogas are less frequently referenced—likely because they are largely equivalent to natural gas in their characteristics and applications. Further refinement by production methods highlights “screen printing” with 5045 results, “spray” with 991, “tape casting” with 334, “spin coating” with 188, and “physical deposition” with only 94 results. This trend clearly points toward a preference for scalable and cost-effective techniques, with screen printing and spray processes leading the development. Although physical deposition can produce superior devices, its high costs limit its exploration. Regarding critical components for enhanced durability, “interconnect” appears 1631 times, while “diffusion barrier” is mentioned in just 73 instances, underscoring the priority of optimizing the durability within the fuel cell. For mobility applications, “start-up” shows up 1325 times and “metal supported” 177 times, emphasizing the ongoing challenge of managing the on–off cycling necessary for transport modes, where reliability under dynamic conditions is key. In this sense, some companies have started to develop SOFC and MS-SOFC on a large-scale. Ceres Power has developed a robust MS-SOFC stack design using a ferritic stainless steel foil substrate with a perforated central region for gas permeability. The cell structure includes a thick-film cermet anode, a tri-layer electrolyte (GDC, YSZ, and a GDC buffer layer), and a bilayer cathode for efficient current collection. Early stack performance (from 2004) demonstrated power densities of 300 mW·cm−2 at 600 °C. As of 2015, Ceres reported stacks generating 10–15 kW with a power-to-weight ratio of 0.12 kW·kg−1 and a degradation rate of 0.3%–0.45% per 1000 h over 6400 h of operation. Ceres MSCs operate at around 600 °C, making them suitable for APUs in vehicles [40,364,365,413–415]. German Consortium (DLR, Plansee, Elring Klinger, BMW) developed a high-performing MSC stack based on TS processes (plasma spraying) for the catalytic and electrolyte layers [416,417]. The stacks featured diffusion barrier layers to prevent the migration of metallic species, improving durability. The stacks demonstrated power densities of 600 mW·cm−2 at 800 °C, with advancements like GDC barrier layers reducing cathode ASR to 0.26 Ω·cm2. The stacks produced 160–200 W in a 10-cell configuration. Achieving gas tightness in the plasma-sprayed electrolytes was identified as a key challenge. NextGen MSC development is a German initiative led by AVL List GmbH aimed at developing a 3 kW SOFC APU system using NextGen MSCs [417]. The Gen A and Gen B MSC configurations incorporated advancements in anode and electrolyte structure, reducing the thickness of the electrolyte and improving performance. The Gen B cell exhibited power densities of 1064 mW·cm−2 at 820 °C, but OCV measurements indicated persistent gas leakage issues. Topsoe Fuel Cells (TFC), DTU, and Riso worked on developing MSC stacks as part of the EU METSOFC project, focusing on improving performance at lower operating temperatures (600–700 °C) [418]. These efforts included infiltrated nanostructured electrodes and ScSZ electrolytes. A 25-cell stack operating at 700 °C delivered 450 W with a degradation rate of 160 mΩ·cm2 per 1000 h. RAMSES EU Project developed both tubular and planar MSCs using a ferritic steel substrate with protective coatings to enhance corrosion resistance [419]. The stacks achieved power densities of over 500 mW·cm−2 at 800 °C, demonstrating robust performance over thermal cycles. In summary, MS-SOFC stacks have seen significant developments, with advancements in materials, fabrication processes, and operational durability. Various groups have contributed patented technologies to improve the overall performance and manufacturability of MSCs. These developments hold promise for both stationary and mobile applications of fuel cells, particularly in distributed power generation and APUs. 11 Conclusions and future perspectives Global efforts to decarbonize mobility are progressing strongly, driven by the Paris Agreements directives to cut GGEs by 45% by 2030 and achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, limiting the increase in the global average temperature below 2 °C over pre-industrial levels [1,2]. This review explored the concept of electrification by reforming hydrocarbons and biofuels to power MS-SOFCs stack with syngas for onboard electricity generation and EE propulsion. This approach presents a promising alternative, aiming to diminish reliance on batteries and mitigate the EIs associated with production, including resource-intensive mining and manufacturing processes. The higher energy density of some biofuels allows the integration in the range of onboard external reformers and MS-SOFCs stack in a new powertrain system enabling drive-range transportation in biofuels producing countries also reducing the scarce mineral mining and GGEs. This concept reduces the necessity for extensive infrastructure modifications to fit widespread vehicle recharging since bioethanol and biomethane can be easily integrated into gas stations as the Brazilian 30 years’ experience already proves to be commercially viable. This solution may be vital in our collective efforts to combat climate change and reduce CO2 emissions. The energy transition should primarily center on reducing GGEs emissions and adoption of the most efficient scale-up technologies currently available. The potential exists to mitigate GGEs while promoting prosperity and wealth for communities worldwide. MS-SOFCs promotes the utilization of hydrocarbons and biofuels, such as bioethanol and biomethane, in FCHEVs. This can be achieved by external reforming or directly internal reforming. The high performance, rapid start-up, and light-off stem from the ceramic film deposition on cost-effective stainless steel porous supports, accomplished by scale-up techniques with lower CAPEX. Over the past eight years, this technological advancement has garnered interest and investment from governments, several ICEVs, BEVs, and FCEVs automotive manufacturers, and power generation companies in Brazil to support R&D. This review discussed several insights aimed at addressing challenges in the utilization of hydrocarbons and biofuels, particularly bioethanol and biomethane, in MS-SOFCs. Key considerations include: (i) 3D print PMSs as MRs integrated with MS-SOFCs; (ii) pre-catalytic thin layer deposition on the MS-SOFCs anode through spin, spray coating or PVD to create a pre-reformer layer; (iii) infiltration and impregnation of catalysts into electrodes and PMS scaffolds; (iv) pre-homogenization of catalysts and electrode materials, followed by infiltration and impregnation into the same electrode and PMS scaffolds; (v) optimization of MS-SOFCs electrode materials to address the issues caused by coking on the anode and coarsening of the electrodes, exploring those resistant to carbon and sulfur deposition, potentially employing materials used in high mass molar biomass and tar reformers. However, the use of new materials and manufacturing techniques, while enhancing the MS-SOFCs performance and lifespan requires careful application. This caution stems from the challenges associated with the reuse and recycling of these new materials at the EoL. LCAs of several technologies reveal HEVs, plug-in PHEVs, and non-plug-in HEVs powered by biofuels exhibit lower GGEs than BEVs in both Brazil and Europe. The implementation of the MS-SOFC stack in a hybrid powertrain system powered by biofuel may can help decarbonize the mobility sector in a more sustainable way. It has the potential to increase energy efficiency up to fivefold compared to Brazilian commercial FlexPower ICEV powered by bioethanol, as demonstrated by the Nissan prototype powered by heavily hydrated bioethanol, achieving an efficiency of 40 km·L−1. The synergy in the range of biofuels and electrification by FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFC stacks may be a pathway for the decarbonization of the entire automotive fleet in terms of sustainability and global economic impact. This synergy extends beyond Brazilian biofuels, offering a viable alternative for over 3 billion people worldwide which rely on the entire biofuel production chain. The 2G bioethanol production release 13.6 gCO2eq./MJ and the decarbonization of the chain production and new bioenergy carbon capture and storage process could bring this number to negative values. Advances in biotechnology for farming, harvesting, transportation, and the decarbonization of production, coupled with policies involving carbon capture, are expected to reduce the GGEs associated with biofuels to levels that may be lower or even negative. The journey toward the widespread commercialization of MS-SOFCs faces challenges that need to be addressed to unlock the full potential of the next generation of electrochemical energy devices. Despite ongoing research, substantial issues persist requiring continued focus and solutions. To address these issues, the following perspectives and research directions for future endeavors are emphasized below. (1) The exploration of high-entropy materials as a promising strategy. HEAs have garnered attention as prospective materials for MS-SOFCs due their excellent physico-chemical stability, good catalytic activity, and electrical conductivity [420]. HEAs exhibit the potential to be used as DBLs on ICs of SOFCs and MS-SOFCs [420]. High-Entropy Oxides (HEOs) with proton conductivity are promising electrolytes for SOFC applications. HEOs with perovskite structure enhance the catalytic activity and diminish polarization resistance in SOFC cathode materials by the mitigation of Sr-segregation [420,421]. Ex-solved catalysts have been shown efficiency and long-term stability due to small and well-dispersed nanoparticles, which reduce the coking and coarsening, ensuring higher TPBs density. (2) There is a lack of mechanistic studies regarding the use of fuels with higher molecular mass. The elementary steps of the catalytic reactions at different electrode materials need to be more investigated. At the TPBs of the anode, it is necessary to understand the oxidative steps of the fuel on the catalyst, the cleavage of C–H and C–C bonds, and how O2− reacts with H2 and carbon at the TPBs generating electrons, H2O and CO2. It is necessary to understand the mechanism of the ORR over different cathode materials since the overall process involves four electrons. Modeling the electrochemical data of SOFCs to extract kinetic parameters leads to improvements in overall efficiency, especially in reducing coking and coarsening [422]. (3) The microstructural architecture of the SOFCs plays multiple roles during its operation, such as allowing the reactant gas diffusion in and products out; enabling ionic charge transfer and electronic conductivity at the electrodes and gas impermeability and electronic insulation at the electrolyte layer. To achieve all these features not only must the material properties attend to the demand, but also the thickness, porosity, active surface area, and interconnectivity must match the specific needs of each layer. The evolution of the microstructure during the operation is a crucial degradation mechanism and encourages the development of innovative assembling strategies to mitigate nanocatalyst coarsening, de-wetting from scaffold, and components delamination. Tomography studies using synchrotron X-ray allow high resolution and fast acquisition of data to improve the reliability of SOFCs [423], and inexpensive non-destructive testing must be developed [424,425]. (4) The use of heterointerfaces in the range of electrodes and electrolytes stands as a pivotal approach to significantly enhance not only ionic and electronic conductivity but also the electrocatalytic activity and stability of Solid Oxide Cells (SOCs) components [426]. Precise control over the composition and microstructure of heterointerfaces becomes imperative for the design of novel electrode and electrolyte materials by interface engineering [426]. Thin film deposition techniques such as PLD, ALD, and Molecular Beam Epitaxy (MBE) offer distinct advantages in precisely controlling the atomic structure of heterointerfaces, making invaluable tools for the synthesis of novel heterostructure SOC components [426]. The integration of microelectronics manufacturing techniques could improve the TRL and attract experienced stakeholders to boost the commercial implementation of SOFCs, closing the gap in the range of academia and industry. (5) The higher SOFC operating temperature is known to induce substantial structural and morphological changes in electrode and electrolyte materials, reducing the performance. Some electrode material compositions have demonstrated the potential to enhance performance during operation due to the in-situ formation of new catalytic sites. Given these challenges and the pressing need for a deeper understanding and the formulation of more precise mechanisms, the development and application of in situ and operando techniques become indispensable for accurate interpretation and progress in the field. Indeed, this matter requires the utilization of numerous in situ and operando spectroscopic and structural characterization techniques. Advanced spectroscopic methods, including synchrotron light-based techniques such as Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS), X-ray Absorption Near-Edge Structure (XANES), Near Edge X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (NEXAFS), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) are essential tools. In addition, a thorough exploration of in situ and operando electron microscopy is imperative for advancing research on SOFC electrode materials. For example, a detailed in situ TEM examination of the morphological evolution during the in situ synthesis of alloys through emerging ex-solution materials during cell operation can yield valuable insights [427]. (6) Fuel cells are suited for carbon capture storage given the exhaustion gases from anode contains only H2O vapour, CO2, and residual fuel. This mix could be directly used in carbon capture storage processes like geological storage or purified to high purity CO2 with less energy spent than traditional thermoelectric facilities, where CO2 is diluted on burned air–fuel mixture. This can lead to a sharp GGEs reduction towards the Paris Agreements goals even when using fossil fuels; moreover, in bioenergy carbon capture storage context, this could lead to precious net atmosphere CO2 removal when biofuels are used. (7) Despite high electricity efficiency, the commercially available Elcogen SOFCs stacks already reaching 75% in 2024, the SOFCs fuel utilization is still underwhelming, with only 70% utilization, and then only 52.5% net fuel efficiency. The unreacted fuel usually is partially recycled back into the SOFC stack or catalytically oxidized on an afterburner. If any carbon-based fuel is utilized, CO must be completely reacted to meet hazardous and environmental criteria. Therefore, research to increase fuel utilization and lower CO emissions at the anode level could simplify the stacks and improve commercialization. Considering the latest findings and the expected future directions, we aspire that this review serves as a valuable contribution to establishing and acknowledging MS-SOFCs and hydrocarbon and biofuel reformers as pivotal technologies for global decarbonization. Furthermore, research in these domains should continue to advance, with the goal of developing systems that pave the way for future breakthroughs in addressing the energy demands of our society.
