Antunes is a PhDstudent in materials science and engineering atUFSCar. He has experience in the manufacturing of solid oxide cells (SOCs), and electrochemical, structure and microstructure characterization of SOCs. He is a currently post-doctoral student in the Center for Innovation on New Energies (CINE) at CEPETRO/UNICAMP developing SOFCs for biofuels on-board electrical and stationary power generation besides H2 generation using SOECs to produce green ammonia. João P. J. de Oliveira is a Ph.D.student at the University of Campinas (UNICAMP), and a researcher in the Center for Innovation on New Energies (CINE). He has experience in the manufacturing of solid oxide cells (SOCs), electrochemical and microstructure characterization of SOCFs. He graduated in Energy Engineering in 2021, with international experience at the Autonomous University of Barcelona. He holds a master’s degree in Electrical Engineering from UNICAMP. Ricardo S. de Abreu is a consultant in sustainable mobility, mechanical engineer with expertise in internal combustion engines, and former university professor in engines and energetics. Currently he is a Ph.D. candidate in Bioenergy at UNICAMP/USP/UNESP.Consultant for ÚNICA, research engineer for the Methanol Project at IMT, and former executive at Mercedes-Benz andMahle. Co-founder and advisor at AEA, and member of SAE. Thiago Dias is a postdoctoral researcher in the Advanced Energy Storage Division at the Center for Innovation on New Energies, Campinas. He holds a bachelor’s degree in Physics (2002), a Master’s degree (2005), and a Ph.D.’s degree (2009) in Materials Engineering from the Federal University of São Carlos, with a specialization in solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs). His research interests span construction and testing SOFCs, varistors and supercapacitors. Bruno B. N. S. Brandão is a post-doctoral researcher at the Advanced Energy Storage Division, Center for Innovation on New Energies. He holds a bachelor’s degree in Chemistry from the Federal University of Minas Gerais and a Ph.D.’s degree from USP (2021). Previously he led an open-innovation project with USP and Metal Chek, synthesizing magneto-fluorescent materials. Currently he develops high-entropy andnano-microstructured materials for catalytic reforming, battery cathodes, and SOFC anodes, focusing on scalable processes. Josué M. Gonçalves is a researcher at the Mackenzie Institute for Research in Graphene and Nanotechnologies (MackGraphe), Brazil. He graduated in Chemistry in 2014 and received his PhD degree from the USP in 2019. He developed cutting-edge research during his postdoctoral internships at USP (2019–2021), the University of Illinois-Chicago (2021–2022), and the University of Campinas (2023–2024). His current research interests include applications of high-entropy materials for energy conversion and storage. Josimar Ribeiro is a full professor at the Federal University of Espírito Santo. He holds a BS degree (1999), a MS degree (2002), and a PhD degree (2006) from USP/FFCLRP. He is the recipient of the Lavoisier Prize (1999) and IAAM Scientist Medal (2017). He completed postdoctoral research on fuel cell catalysis at Université de Poitiers, France, and specializes in Physical Chemistry and Electrochemistry, with over 100 research publications, 52 papers, 10 books, 4 book chapters, and 2 patents. Julian Hunt is a research scientist at KAUST working on water, food, and energy inventions for Saudi Arabia. He holds a chemical engineering degree from the University of Nottigham, a D.Phil degree from the University of Oxford and worked for 7 years at the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis prior to joining KAUST. Hudson Zanin is a professor at the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Campinas, and a researcher at the Center for Innovation on New Energies. His research develops functional nanomaterials for energy storage and conversion, focusing on supercapacitors, batteries, and fuel cells. He is the founder of the first South America Lab-scale batteries and supercapacitors manufacturing. Dr. Zanin holds a Ph.D. degree in Electrical Engineering from the University of Campinas (2012). Gustavo Doubek is an associate Professor at UNICAMP and a researcher at the Center for Innovation on New Energies (CINE). He holds a degree in Chemical Engineering from UNICAMP and Ph.D. degree in Nuclear Technology from IPEN/USP, with research experience at Yale University and 3M. He specializes in nanomaterials for energy storage and conversion, focusing on Li-ion, Na-ion, Li-O2, and Li-S batteries, fuel cells, biofuel reformers, and catalyst synthesis for public and private projects.

coredata.dc:description: Metal-Supported Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (MS-SOFCs) hold significant potential for driving the energy transition. These electrochemical devices represent the most advanced generation of Solid Oxide Fuel Cell (SOFCs) and can pave the way for mass production and wider adoption than Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells (PEMFCs) due to their fuel flexibility, higher power density and the absence of noble metals in the fabrication processes. This review examines the state-of-the-art of SOFCs and MS-SOFCs, presenting perspectives and research directions for these key technological devices, highlighting novel materials, techniques, architectures, devices, and degradation mechanisms to address current challenges and future opportunities. Techniques such as infiltration/impregnation, ex-solution catalyst synthesis, and the use of a pre-catalytic reformer layer are discussed as their impact on efficiency and prolonged activity. These concepts are also described and connected with well-dispersed nanoparticles, hindrance of coarsening, and an increased number of Triple Phase Boundaries (TPBs). This review also describes the synergistic use of reformers with MS-SOFCs to compose solutions in energy generation from readily available fuels. Lastly, the End-of-Life (EoL), recycling, and life-cycle assessments (LCAs) of the Fuel Cell Hybrid Electric Vehicles (FCHEVs) were discussed. LCAs comparing Fuel Cell Electric Vehicles (FCEVs) equipped with (PEMFCs) and FCHEVs equipped with MS-SOFCs, both powered with hydrogen (H2) generated by different routes were compared. This review aims to provide valuable insights into these key technological devices, emphasizing the importance of robust research and development to enhance performance and lifespan while reducing costs and environmental impact.
